title: State caucus criticizes Hogan on LGBTQ+ issues
author: MARIJKE FRIEDMAN Capital News Service
content:
State caucus criticizes Hogan on LGBTQ+ issues

 September 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIJKE FRIEDMAN Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 856
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — Members of the Maryland Legislative LGBTQ+ Caucus are accusing former Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan of not standing up for the LGBTQ+ community.Hogan, the Republican nominee for Maryland's U.S. Senate seat, has proven he is not an ally to LGBTQ+ Marylanders, a statement from five members of the caucus reads. All are Democrats. Caucus members said it is critical that the Democratic candidate, Prince George's County Executive Angela Alsobrooks, beats Hogan in November.
"I see the indifference that Larry Hogan expresses, and it causes me great pause," Del. Kris Fair (D-Frederick) told Capital News Service. "It should cause every LGBTQ+ community member great pause about his ability to support our community."
The caucus spoke out after Hogan recently dismissed an LGBTQ+ Maryland voter's concerns about his record at a campaign event, according to the statement and reporting from The Advocate.
In addition to Fair, who is the chair of the Maryland Legislative LGBTQ+ Caucus, the statement was signed by Del. Anne Kaiser (D-Montgomery), Del. Joe Vogel, (D-Montgomery) Del. Ashanti Martinez (D-Prince George's) and Del. Bonnie Cullison (D-Montgomery).
During his time as governor, Hogan elected to not sign several LGBTQ+ rights bills, including one that protects victims from hate crimes based on their identity. Hogan did not veto or directly oppose the bill, and it ended up becoming law without his signature.
Hogan choosing not to sign bills that would protect LGBTQ+ individuals indicated to Cullison that he doesn't understand the challenges facing the community. LGBTQ+ people rely on laws to give them protections, she said.
"For political reasons, he felt it was important that his name not be on those bills," Cullison told CNS.
In 2018, Hogan signed a bill into law that bans conversion therapy for LGBTQ+ youth. Cullison — who was a leader in this effort — said it was "an easy one for him to sign."
Anti-conversion bills were already passing across the country and politics were on his side, she said. Since Hogan signed the bill, similar laws have been enacted in Utah, Virginia and Michigan.
"He's just been responsive," she said. "He hasn't been proactive."
Martinez thinks Hogan has been silent about the concerns of LGBTQ+ community members and that indicates how the former governor would act in the U.S. Senate if he is elected.
"He decided not to sign these bills," Martinez told Capital News Service. "I think that's a clear indiciation to LGBTQ folks and our allies across this state that he is not the champion that we know Angela Alsobrooks will be."
As governor, Hogan allowed measures to take effect that extend coverage of IVF treatment to same-sex couples and allow transgender people to revise their birth certificates, Hogan campaign spokesperson Blake Kernen said said in a statement. He also appointed the first openly LGBTQ+ person to serve as chief judge of a Maryland appellate court, Kernen wrote.
"After calling for 'tolerance and mutual respect' in his inaugural address, Gov. Hogan supported LGBTQ community priorities throughout his time in office," she wrote. "Maryland has a bipartisan legacy of supporting the LGBTQ community, and Gov. Hogan looks forward to building on this work in the Senate."
Hogan walked in the Annapolis Pride Parade in June, sporting a Pride sticker and lei. His campaign posted on Facebook dozens of pictures of Hogan with attendees at the parade.
"Maryland is a mosaic of diverse communities and cultures, and that's one of many things that makes our great state so special," Hogan said in a statement. "As governor, I was proud to represent all Marylanders, and that's exactly the leader I'll be in the United States Senate."
Martinez, a resident of Prince George's County, said he has witnessed Alsobrooks supporting the LGBTQ+ community during her time as county executive. He appreciates that prominent members of her staff are part of the LGBTQ+ community.
Alsobrooks has held listening sessions, attended Pride events and created an LGBTQ+ liaison position in her office, Martinez said.
"It is really important that we have ourselves represented in all facets of government," Martinez said.
Cullison agrees that Alsobrooks is the candidate for U.S. Senate that will stand with LGBTQ+ community members.
"Angela Alsobrooks will be the senator who will fight the fight with us," she said. "She's supportive and advocates and won't back down and won't hide behind not signing something."
If elected senator, Alsobrooks said she plans to co-sponsor the Equality Act — a bill that would prohibit discrimination on the basis of sex, sexual orientation and gender identity in public accommodations and facilities — and oppose Republican efforts to undermine equality, she wrote in a statement to CNS.
The Human Rights Campaign, an LGBTQ+ civil rights organization, endorsed Alsobrooks this summer.
"What we understand is that this race in Maryland will likely decide whether Democrats or Republicans control the Senate Majority. Republicans have made it clear that no such votes to protect and elevate our LGBTQ+ community will come to the Floor if they take back the Majority," Alsobrooks wrote in her statement.
Fair said that while Hogan may not propose bills that directly harm the LGBTQ+ community, he will likely allow other Republicans to do so.
"Larry Hogan is the symptom of a problem coming down the road that's going to be devastating for our community," Fair said.

title: Easton celebrates the beginning of Hispanic Heritage Month
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Easton celebrates the beginning of Hispanic Heritage Month

 September 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 483
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Hispanic Heritage Month started with a bang as families gathered on Saturday to partake in the annual Hispanic Heritage Festival Block Party hosted by the Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center.The block party, which took place near the Rails and Trails between Dover Street and August Street, brought together families through music, games, face painting and activities. Dozens of businesses and organizations from throughout the Eastern Shore partook in the festival to better engage with the local Hispanic community.
Victoria Gomez Lozano, deputy director of the Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center, led in organizing the event and said she is proud of how much it has grown over the years.
"As you can see, we have a lot of things to do," Gomez Lozano said, gesturing to the many tables of activities and food. "We have really good food. We have a lot of agencies visiting and giving us information. We're gonna have activities for the children, like piñatas, face painting. So I'm just very, very thankful to have everyone here to join us and celebrate Hispanic Heritage Month."
National Hispanic Heritage Month is celebrated from Sept. 15 to Oct. 15 each year. It recognizes the contributions of Hispanic people to the history, culture and achievements of the United States.
Among the many businesses tabling for the event Saturday, the vast majority were Hispanic-owned, offering everything from handmade soaps and lotions to authentic Hispanic foods. Many Latin American countries were represented, with offerings from Mexican horchata, tacos and buñuelos to fresh Venezuelan cheese and bread.
Additionally, there were organizations at the event to provide support for the Hispanic community. English language learning teachers from Talbot County Public Schools passed out coloring sheets of different Latin American countries to young people.
Patty Hamsher and Brianne Niewinski, teachers at Easton Elementary School, said they were happy to be at the event to celebrate the culture and heritage of their students.
"So many of our families, we hope, will be here today," Hamsher said. "So we're just out to give an opportunity for kids to color flags of other Hispanic countries and also take home some supplies, because a lot of them come to school with supplies, but they might not have supplies at home to do this kind of stuff, so we're just providing fun to connect with families."
Surrounding their table were young children wearing soccer jerseys representing their countries looking through the pictures of flags and pointing out the ones for the countries they were from. On their faces were flags and symbols of different Latin American countries including Honduras, Guatemala and El Salvador.
Niewinski said it's important for teachers to celebrate the heritage of their students, especially when they are learning English.
"I think it's important for the students to see us celebrating their culture and understanding that we, as teachers, want to teach them English. We don't want them to ever forget about their culture and their native language," Niewinski said.

title: Frederick Douglass Day continues to share abolitionist's legacy
author: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com
content:
Frederick Douglass Day continues to share abolitionist's legacy

 October 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 577
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The first time Harriette Lowery heard that Frederick Douglass had grown up in Talbot County was when she moved back to Easton with her husband in the early 2000s.Lowery was surprised to hear of Douglass' local origins. She had grown up in Talbot County, but she had never known it was the famed abolitionist's birthplace.
"The historical society had put a notice in the paper asking for people to respond to a question — 'Is anybody interested in honoring Frederick Douglass in some way since he's our native son.' And I read that and thought, 'I knew a lot about Frederick Douglass, but I did not know he was from Talbot County,'" she said Saturday, surveying the crowd outside the Talbot County Free Library that had assembled for the annual Frederick Douglass Day celebration.
"... I was a little embarrassed by that but more interested in doing something because of that," Lowery said.
Lowery and her late husband became founding members of the Frederick Douglass Honor Society, the group that spearheaded the process of having a statue of Douglass erected on the Talbot County Court House lawn. The statue was unveiled to a crowd of thousands in June, 2011, after years of sometimes tense back-and-forth between the honor society, members of the community and local governments.
Frederick Douglass Day evolved from that unveiling ceremony in an effort to continue the honor society's mission of educating the community about Douglass.
"Since 2011, the Frederick Douglass Honor Society decided that it wanted to continue efforts to continue the legacy of Frederick Douglass," said Walter Black, another founding member of the Frederick Douglass Honor Society. "So the main thing that we concentrated on is the Frederick Douglass Day."
On Saturday, Frederick Douglass Day filled downtown Easton with a parade, a ceremony, a lecture, a children's village and a city block filled with vendors, nonprofits and live entertainment.
"The event gets bigger and better every year," said Debbi Dodson, the Frederick Douglass Day event coordinator. "More people get involved and more people attend, so that is a sign that people appreciate it and really support it."
The keynote speaker for this year's event, Keidrick Roy, said that although this was his first time visiting Talbot County, he has been working with the Frederick Douglass Honor Society for several years.
Keidrick Roy, a fellow at Harvard University, signed copies of his new book, "American Dark Age: Racial Feudalism and the Rise of Black Liberalism," at the event. Roy said Douglass is heavily featured in the work.
"I've always wanted to be in the place where Frederick Douglass walked and talked and had many of his formative experiences, so it's very special for me to be here to do this," he said. "I loved the celebration this morning, seeing so many people from different parts of the city, different parts of the town come out and honor Douglass in a variety of ways."
In holding the event every year, Lowery said the honor society hopes to ensure that all members of the community are aware of Douglass's ties to Talbot County and of how the principles of equality and freedom that Douglass espoused are still relevant today.
"What we wanted was for everybody to look at Douglass as an American hero and not an African American hero," Lowery said.
On Saturday, Lowery remarked that Talbot County had made progress toward that goal since 2011.
"We're always growing and getting better, or we should be anyway," she said. "Every year, I know that there's progress."

title: Maryland approves $2.75 million settlement for discrimination by state police
author: MARISSA YELENIK Capital News Service
content:
Maryland approves $2.75 million settlement for discrimination by state police

 October 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARISSA YELENIK Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 548
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Top state officials approved a $2.75 million settlement on Wednesday after a federal investigation turned up evidence of discriminatory hiring practices by the Maryland State Police.The U.S. Department of Justice conducted a two-year investigation into state police hiring practices for a violation of Title VII, which prohibits discrimination against employees or applicants based on race, color, religion, sex and national origin.
The investigation found that the state police engaged in discriminatory practices against Black and female applicants, agency officials acknowledged in a meeting of the Maryland Board of Public Works on Wednesday.
The DOJ said that MDSP written tests disproportionately impacted Black candidates, while their physical fitness tests disproportionately impacted female candidates. The tests discriminated against candidates while failing to "meaningfully distinguish between applicants who can and cannot perform the position of Trooper," according to a Department of Justice press release.
"Discrimination in any form has no place within the Maryland State Police, and it will not be tolerated," Col. Roland Butler Jr., superintendent of MDSP, told the board Wednesday. "We're committed to making meaningful and lasting change … [and] to develop new policies and procedures that ensure equitable treatment for all applicants."
The board — made up of Gov. Wes Moore, state Comptroller Brooke Lierman and Treasurer Dereck E. Davis — signed off on the settlement. The agreement must also be approved by a federal court before moving forward.
In response to the investigation, MDSP will change its current testing methods to prevent future discrimination in hiring, but the new practices will not be ready until after the next two MDSP classes start, Butler said. To adapt, he said, MDSP intends to change existing standards, including eliminating time requirements from different portions of the physical fitness tests.
Members of the Board of Public Works raised concerns about this interim period, with Davis questioning whether the unclear guidelines would lead to more discrimination.
"Now it becomes subjective, so doesn't that lend itself, potentially, to be more discriminatory?" Davis asked. "Now we don't know what's good or what's not as it relates to that time."
Butler assured Davis that strict monitoring of who passes and fails the tests would be in place, allowing MDSP to monitor areas of improvement.
"We won't have the other test in place at this time," Butler said. "However, we're relaxing the standards that we have … We will be allowed to use those tests under the condition that we provide strict monitoring to see what the results are, to see who's passing, who's failing and we do think that we'll get a larger pool of applicants when we start to look at how we measure that test and how we evaluate it."
Officials said the new tests would emphasize fairness while maintaining safety requirements, including a test that would receive ongoing validation to guarantee it was modern, fair and relevant, as well as an aptitude test to look for integrity, self-motivation, critical thinking and judgment skills.
The settlement involved 48 Black and female individuals who were prevented from becoming state troopers due to the discriminatory practices, according to Butler.
Since his appointment in 2023, Butler said, he has worked to evaluate and modernize the agency's practices.
"I remain steadfastly committed to cultivating a culture that will ensure inclusiveness," Butler said, "one that allows the fulfillment of our mission, of values centered around integrity, fairness, and service."

title: Federalsburg celebrates voting rights on anniversary of historic election
author: Tom McCall
content:
Federalsburg celebrates voting rights on anniversary of historic election

 October 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: News 
 
 529
 Words 

 Read News Document

 FEDERALSBURG — Sept. 26 marked the first anniversary of the historic election of the first Black Town Council members in Federalsburg. The community gathered over several days to celebrate.Many Black residents of the town and NAACP members marked the occasion by observing Voting Rights Day on Sept. 26, participating in Unity Day activities on Sept. 28, and appreciating the new signage placed at the entrance to the primarily Black residential community of Brooklyn in Federalsburg.
"Federalsburg was hosting. The town was the organizer of the event. It is the first anniversary," Willie G. Woods, president of the NAACP Caroline County Branch, said. "We were there to support what was happening in Federalsburg. They had a cross section of vendors and participants and music and food."
Woods said it is important to stand up and be heard.
"You have to come together and share your ideas, your viewpoints and your respective cultures. And you have to respect the contributions that the diverse population is making," she said.
Brandy James, a Federalsburg Town Council member elected in last year's historic election, said the event was a success and that there was a good crowd.
"It symbolized unity to me. We had people from every aspect of Federalsburg. The faith-based community was there. Law enforcement was there. Not just Federalsburg police, but also the Caroline County Sheriff was there," said James.
She said there were many vendors there, including the Caroline County Health Department and smoking cessation resources.
"The NAACP has a table, Men For Change, there were churches with tables out there. They were giving away free cotton candy, and the kids had a blast. It was a great way to see everyone from across the lifespan come together and celebrate the unity of Federalsburg," James said.
She said the actual business of sitting on the council is slower than she would like, but she said everyone is being fairly heard.
"I am hopeful to see more African American people run for office in the future, and I am hopeful that the town business will get a little more streamlined and more organized," she said.
The Sept. 26 celebration and plaque were requirements of a settlement in a 2023 lawsuit brought against the town in federal court under the Voting Rights Act of 1965. Through months of charter amendments, legislation and federal court rulings, the town's previous at-large election system was changed in June to a two-district system to ensure more representation of Federalsburg's Black residents. District 1 has a 64% Black population and District 2 is predominantly white.
The sign that was placed at Brooklyn said, in part, "In coordination with the Mayor and the Council of Federalsburg, created an opportunity for Federalsburg's Black community to elect two representatives to the Federalsburg Town Council. Through their efforts, with support of the ACLU of Maryland and the guidance from the United States District Court, the town adopted and implemented a new and fair election system, undoing the 200 year exclusion of Black residents from town government. Federalsburg's historic election on September 26, 2023 resulted in two Black women winning seats to the town council: Darlene Pitt Hammond and Brandy James. This day forever marks a turning point in Federalsburg's diverse community."

title: Understanding Latinidad: Educator speaks to Chesapeake College students
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Understanding Latinidad: Educator speaks to Chesapeake College students

 October 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 639
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WYE MILLS — Dozens of students, faculty and community members gathered at the Wye Mills Humanities Cadby Theatre and enjoyed jamaica (hibiscus) agua fresca, fresh fruit, piles of spicy chips and an encouraging message of embracing their native cultures.In celebration of Hispanic Heritage Month, Chesapeake College's Hispanic/Latino Student Union hosted advocate, educator and teacher Samantha Martinez to speak on what her Latinidad means to her.
Lindsay Velasquez, president of the Hispanic/Latino Student Union, said she was excited to bring Martinez as a speaker and loved the encouragement she shared with students in attendance to feel empowered by their cultural identity.
"I just feel like all of us feel like we can do it, and that little doubt that we had of not being able to do something, like, we can do it," Velasquez said. "And she's an example of anything that is possible if you put your mind to it."
Latinidad is a particular experience that contains the complexities of immigration, race, color, class and language. Martinez said her story stems from an immigration story.
"I'm really proud of that because of (my parents') struggle, and their survival and their grit, I'm able to stand here in front of you today," she said.
Her mother migrated from Mexico and her father from El Salvador. She grew up in Chicago, which she describes as "a city that really appreciated and celebrated what it means to be Latina," though the city was heavily segregated.
After meeting her husband and getting married, she moved to New York and became a teacher in the South Bronx, known as the poorest school district in the country. There, Martinez learned of excellence.
She said she was expected to perform at a level of excellence that she had never been asked to before, and in turn she learned to expect it from the people and students around her.
She said the South Bronx "will forever be a part of my story and my legacy."
After spending her time in the South Bronx, Martinez moved to Talbot County. It was a culture shock, but to her surprise, she found a growing Latino population. Her new home also forced her to affirm and challenge her own identity as a Latina.
Martinez worked for Talbot County Public Schools and then founded Mid-Shore Scholars, a college prep program that serves first-generation college students.
When leading the program, she decided it was time to focus on the marginalized student population. The program was meant to target a population of students who had the potential to go to Ivy Leagues, but she pushed for a different perspective. Martinez said it was important to focus on the students who lacked the resources to get to college.
"It's these students who don't have any help at home, who don't have any representation, whose parents want to give them the best life but didn't go to college here, who don't know the ropes or don't know how to navigate the system," Martinez said.
During the pandemic, she decided to focus on building an institution to better assist marginalized communities and helped create the Polaris Village Academy. Martinez said the academy centers joy, celebrating culture and empowering students and families, making them feel safe and seen.
Martinez ended her presentation with photos of her family visiting their native countries and the importance that focusing on her roots allowed her the opportunity to help those around her to grow.
"My superpower is that I am bicultural, that I have roots in (El Salvador) and in Mexico, and I have roots here, and that I can be both from there and from here, and then it's not 'and/or.' I could bring my whole self," Martinez said. "And I encourage all the students here who are questioning their identity or wondering if they can be authentically themselves when they go to class or when they step into white institutions that yes, you can."

 Benjamin Hance and Charles Whitley are tied together through dark periods of Southern Maryland's past, and healing for the two lynchings will continue when the Maryland Lynching Truth and Reconciliation Commission holds a public hearing on Nov. 16 in Leonardtown.The hearings are a part of the commission's ongoing effort to bring awareness to Maryland's history of racial violence and to foster reconciliation in the present.
"People should go to this event to be a part of this important moment of racial healing and being an active participant in determining the direction we go as a society," Michelle Coles, a member of the commission, said.
The hearing will focus on Hance, who was killed June 17, 1887, in Leonardtown, and Whitley, who was killed June 6, 1886, in Prince Frederick.
"You'll learn about the lynching that occurred in Calvert County and what followed after that and how we've come a very long ways since that time," said historian Michael Kent, who is part of Maryland's Historic Preservation Commission and past president of the Calvert County NAACP, and who is scheduled to speak at the hearing.
The event is part of the St. Mary's County Museum Division's bi-annual Social Justice & Equity programing, in commemoration of the Nov. 1, 1864, ratification of the new Maryland Constitution, which ended slavery in the state.
About 40 lynchings across Maryland were documented to have occurred from 1854-1933.
"It's a part of our history and an important part of our history, and I think it's also an opportunity to learn from our past so that these types of things don't continue to occur in our present and in our future," Coles said. "I think when it comes to history you have two choices; it's either to learn from it or repeat it and I'm an advocate of [the former]."
"The point of it is to educate the people in the county and reconcile those who have had issues with this for a long time," Kent said.
The Maryland Lynching Truth and Reconciliation Commission, which was established in 2019 by the General Assembly, is the first statewide commission of its kind in the nation and works with local historians in researching cases of lynching throughout the state.
The hearings are held in communities where lynchings took place to shine a light on the dark legacy of lynching in Maryland and its enduring impacts on the Black community and communities of color.
Over the past few years, Leonardtown has installed a memorial to Hance and "Stopping Stones" at the Old Jail Museum in Leonardtown.
"I think people are energized about the opportunity to heal from these wounds," Coles said of the remembrance events, "instead of covering up these wounds."
Descendants of the victims and aggressors, expert witnesses, community members, scholars and archivists will have the opportunity to provide testimony and make recommendations for achieving racial healing.
"It's an opportunity to really remember the people whose lives were taken in a deprivation of their due process rights as United States citizens," Coles said, "and also to chart a path forward toward genuine racial healing and reconciliation."
Community members are encouraged to submit testimony or bring written testimony to be collected at the public hearing.
"[Testimony] can be along the lines about how learning about a lynching having taken place in their county has affected them and perhaps changed their perception of things," Coles said. "Or on the reconciliation side, they could say, 'As a result of this being part of our county's history and state's history, I really think the following things should take place that could help us heal.'"
Coles added that written testimony may be read at the hearing.
To submit written testimony in advance, email it to mltrc@maryland.gov.
For more information on The Maryland Lynching Truth and Reconciliation Commission, go to msa.maryland.gov/lynching-truth-reconciliation.

title: Can America elect a woman president?
author: Staff Writer
content:
Can America elect a woman president?

 November 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editorials 
 
 769
 Words 

 Read News Document

 There are many reasons why Kamala Harris lost to Donald Trump.She failed to articulate how her presidency would differ from the highly unpopular term of Joe Biden.
Voters had tired of high prices that in effect reduced their income and spending power.
There were the millions of immigrants who streamed across the country's southern border following Biden's election.
And Harris was burdened by Biden turning a blind eye to the atrocity of tens of thousands of Palestinian women and children being killed by the Israelis while others claimed he did not do enough for Israel.
Those are understandable reasons for voters to cast ballots for someone else.
What is not understandable are the many voters who would not vote for a woman for president.
This is 2024. We should be long past the patriarchal notions that see political power and leadership as male domains. Sadly we are not.
Those stereotypes could be heard in voter interviews throughout the campaign. Sometimes the prejudices were thinly veiled. Too often they were overt. I can't see a woman as commander in chief. She doesn't look like a president.
Donald Trump contributed to this with his derogatory comments on Harris' intelligence. He called her lazy and stupid.
The Associated Press wrote about Maya Davis, a 27-year-old North Carolina attorney who theorized that Harris' identity as a Black and South Asian woman "absolutely" played a role in her defeat. As a Black woman herself, the 27-year-old North Carolina attorney said she is constantly forced to prove herself.
"I don't think there's anything she could have done differently unfortunately," she said of Harris. "Maybe not be a woman."
The discrimination Harris faced is not new. This country has had a long history of holding women back from fulfilling their potential. America denied women the right to vote until 1920. They are vastly underrepresented in the corner offices of corporations. Women were kept from military front-line combat positions until 2013. They often are paid less than men for doing the same jobs. Some elite universities barred women from attending until the 1970s, about the time that women could finally get a credit card on their own.
A commercial in the 1970s said, "You've come a long way, baby." Yes, but there is much farther to go.
There have been pioneers who have blazed the way for women in a male-dominated world. They faced many challenges of people — both men and women — who frequently questioned the appropriateness of the example these women provided to young girls.
Those people who raised questions were wrong. The women shattering stereotypes were excellent role models for young girls. They showed that girls could grow up to follow their dreams, to be whatever they dreamed they wanted to be. Young girls saw someone who looks like them in these roles.
As Harris gave her concession speech on Wednesday, cameras panned through the predominantly female audience. Faces were streaked with tears, but there was something else in those faces — something far sadder. Those faces conveyed hopes that were crushed.
A friend recently took her 3-year-old daughter to the National Portrait Gallery in Washington, D.C. Walking through the grandeur, majesty and elegance of the presidential portrait hall, the youngster asked, "But where are the girls?'
"There are none," her mom replied, repeating wistfully, "There are none."
Hopefully that will change. Hopefully that girl will see a woman leading the most powerful country in the world.
There are promising signs on the horizon, signs that old stereotypes are becoming a relic for history books rather than a reality.
Kamala Harris has been a trailblazer all of her life. First as the first woman attorney general in California. As a U.S. senator. As the country's first female president. As a major party nominee for president.
In Maryland and Delaware this week, voters sent two Black women to the U.S. Senate, where they will be both race and gender minorities in the chamber. Angela Alsobrooks and Lisa Blunt Rochester are pioneers. They are leading the way, just as Harris has done throughout her career.
Even Donald Trump made history this week announcing the appointment of the first woman chief of staff.
These are strides, but they are not enough.
Can America elect a woman president?
Changing public attitudes, more females in political offices and a surge in women running for leadership positions suggest that the country may be on the cusp of electing a woman to the nation's highest office.
There is no doubt that one day the highest glass ceiling in American politics will shatter and a woman president will be elected. Then our friend's 3-year-old one day will walk the presidential portrait gallery and see a painting of a girl hanging among all of the male portraits.

title: Native American heritage honored
author: Madison Bateman Special to Star Democrat
content:
Native American heritage honored

 November 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Madison Bateman Special to Star Democrat | Section: State News 
 
 483
 Words 

 Read News Document

 "Native Americans were here first, and they are still here."With that statement, Rod Cofield, executive director of Jefferson Patterson Park and Museum, summed up the reason for the annual American Indian Heritage Day, which drew more than 400 guests to the park on Nov. 2.
"Many gloss over the fact there is still an indigenous population in the area. … Their culture and history is worth acknowledging," Cofield said.
The annual event, usually held on the first Saturday of November, aligns with the national recognition of Native American Heritage Month.
He said programs such as American Indian Heritage Day at the park in St. Leonard provides local Native groups the opportunity to "tell their story, in their words, in their way."
"People really enjoy the event," Cofield said, adding the celebration was supported by Friends of Jefferson Patterson Park and Museum and the Southern Maryland Folklife Center.
Brent Meadows of Port Republic attended the celebration for the first time this year with his 3-year-old son Ian and 5-year-old daughter Isla.
"We like taking advantage of the park's free and educational events," he said.
Meadows and his family spent some time making cordage out of plants, led by Clare Walker from Irvine Nature Center in Baltimore County.
The event featured local Native dancers, demonstrations and educational activities such as clay pot-making, archery, painting, fishing and more.
"We are the original people to inhabit what is known today as the state of Maryland," Mark Tayac, Piscataway Indian Nation chief, said. "We called it home for 15,000 years. Our presence has been documented by anthropologists and archeologists."
Tayac's son, Naiche, spoke and performed at Saturday's program.
"We are not part of the past, relics in museums. … We are human beings, and we are still here today," he said.
Especially during Native American Heritage Month in November, Tayak explained participating in celebrations such as the one held at the park gives them an opportunity to educate people about their culture, a culture that is thousands of years old.
By the time the Europeans embarked on the New World at the dawn of the 17th century, the Piscataway was the largest and most powerful tribal nation in the lands between the Chesapeake Bay and Potomac River, according to the Maryland Department of Natural Resources website.
Traditional territory primarily included present-day Charles, Prince George's and St. Mary's counties, and extended north into Baltimore County and west toward the Appalachian Mountains.
"We are now centrally located in Southern Maryland," Tayac said.
The Piscataway people faced many challenges in Maryland, colonization being among the largest. English colonists began taking over the Piscataway's homelands in 1634, converting them to Catholicism and forcing them to surrender their beliefs.
"There was a time in history when Native people were not allowed to practice their culture," Tayac said. "The history is hard to talk about, but it must be talked about. That's how we begin to comprehend that we are all the same, that we all have the same heart."

title: Federalsburg unveils sign to recognize historic 2023 election, people who made it possible
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Federalsburg unveils sign to recognize historic 2023 election, people who made it possible

 November 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 744
 Words 

 Read News Document

 FEDERALSBURG — The Rev. Jeffrey Butler, a Federalsburg resident, remembers when Brooklyn Avenue went from being a dirt road to a paved one in the late 1970s. He also remembers the more than 40 years it took for the town to get that road repaved."It was so bad," he said. "I mean, just tearing cars up. And we went to the town to complain. They still didn't do nothing."
"Finally, along with this lawsuit, came them also fixing this road up after 40 years," Butler said.
Since a lawsuit led to the election of the town's first two Black council members last year, the road — which is situated in a historically Black area in town — has been repaved.
On Saturday, with the newly paved Brooklyn Avenue in view, Federalsburg Mayor Kim Abner and the Federalsburg Town Council unveiled a new sign that commemorates the town's historic election and the new election system that made it possible.
The sign recognizes the individuals and groups who helped make it possible for Black Councilwomen Darlene Pitt Hammond and Brandy James to be elected to the Town Council in September 2023.
A MARKER OF PROGRESSAfter the unveiling, Hammond looked at the sign, tears forming in her eyes.
"It's a lot," she said, taking a pause, "to think that this small little town was able to stand for the rights of all people, not some people."
Hammond, who was a plaintiff in the lawsuit against the town, said the progress that has been made in the town is "heartwarming" and "breathtaking."
"It's a dream come true for me and for others that (came) before me, that we have established that everybody should be represented no matter what the color of your skin is," she said.
Although Black residents now make up nearly half of the town's population, the town had never had a minority representative on the council in its 200-year history. In June 2023 — through charter amendments, legislation and federal court rulings — the town's at-large election system was changed to a two-district system to ensure more representation of Federalsburg's Black residents.
In April, a $260,000 settlement was reached in the lawsuit filed against the town by the Caroline County branch of the NAACP, the Caucus of African American Leaders and Federalsburg residents regarding its discriminatory election system.
The settlement included a sweeping array of measures aimed at providing reconciliation after the town's previous election system was determined to have prevented Black residents from electing their chosen representatives. This includes the town apologizing to those who brought on the lawsuit, affixing a plaque to its town hall building, proclaiming Sept. 26 as Voting Rights Day and erecting the historical marker in the town's Black community.
Hammond said this sign unveiling and the first annual Voting Rights Day celebration, which was held in September, point to "a new era" in Federalsburg.
"It is a new era where everybody has a voice and everybody will be heard," she said.
After years of Butler speaking out about the need for Brooklyn Avenue to be repaved, Hammond said the new council was able to get the project done in about a year.
Before the sign was unveiled, Mayor Kim Abner said she and the council are excited about the direction that Federalsburg is going in.
"We have great things to come," she said. "We are making great progress in the town, and we are super excited that you're all here to celebrate."
Butler said he is hopeful more positive changes are coming with the current council in place.
"It's coming," he said. "We know Rome wasn't built in a day, so it's coming."
Sherone Lewis, a Federalsburg native and first vice president for the Caroline County branch of the NAACP who was a plaintiff on the lawsuit, called it surreal to be celebrating the changes that have been made.
"But I must say, the struggle continues," she said. "We still have a lot of work to do for diversity, equity and inclusion. I know those are buzz words these days. But I do believe that because I want this for my children, my grandchildren."
Willie Woods, president of the Caroline County branch of the NAACP, said the new sign is something that will be seen and read for generations.
"I hate to talk about it from this standpoint, but in the future, we will be passed on and there will be other generations," she said. "And this signage will remind them of the stance that was taken and of the progress that Federalsburg has embraced as we are moving forward."

title: Trump’s return has these conservative Latinos excited
author: ROBERT STEWART Capital News Service
content:
Trump’s return has these conservative Latinos excited

 November 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ROBERT STEWART Capital News Service | Section: News 
 
 817
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ROCKVILLE — Juan Leo Salazar is on a mission to awaken a dormant political power in Maryland — the state's conservative-leaning Latinos.He has compiled a list of 28,000 names he believes he can galvanize for conservative causes. He says his organization of Maryland Latino Republicans has roughly 300 paying members.
He and many of his conservative friends had been working and keeping their heads down, he said. Now they're not afraid of sharing their views, he said, despite possible criticism and even retaliation.
"Now that Trump is in," Salazar said, "nobody's afraid."
Exit poll data on Latino voters had some analysts' heads spinning. Nationwide, 46% of this group voted for Donald Trump in the general election.
But that turnout for Trump was not surprising for some Latino Republicans like Salazar. He and others had watched the ways people in their networks were responding to the Biden-Harris administration and saw the writing on the wall.
Salazar, who came to the area in the late 60s, has many thoughts on how Trump will benefit folks in Maryland.
To start, he praised Trump's promise to cut taxes on tips and overtime as a win for the working-class Latino community.
"Now with the tips, no tax on tips. That is wonderful," he said, "you should see how the Latino community, Hispanics, are so happy about (that)."
He also thinks the Republican victory can help improve cultural issues conservatives care about at the state level.
Connected with Latino Republicans across six counties in Maryland through his organization, Salazar has a good sense of how politically transformative the issue of parental input into school curricula is. He believes it unifies many minority immigrant groups in the state. This, he said, could change the state's political map.
"If those (other) minority groups can get organized … with chapters in different counties," he said, "I'm sure we can turn this state at least orange."
But to strengthen the Republican hand in a state overwhelmingly run by Democrats, you need friends.
Alirio Martinez is one of Salazar's friends in that mission.
Martinez, 50, lives in Easton with his wife Ann and their six cats. Outside of his entrepreneurial work — the two have an online business — Martinez enjoys connecting with fellow partisans.
The two men met this October outside of an early-voting polling precinct in eastern Montgomery County. Martinez was in the area and wanted to see if his buddy was canvassing. Salazar happened to have a table set up there, where he was doing outreach to the Latino community.
Martinez said there are a number of reasons why he's hopeful that Trump's return to Washington could help Latinos in the state.
"I tell people it's about what's going on, they're hurting people's pockets big time," Martinez said. "They're seeing the price of the eggs, the milk … the gas."
Martinez, who went as a Republican delegate to the Republican National Convention in 2016, said he can remember the time under Trump when his favorite sandwich cost him $5 and when gas prices were more affordable. Things changed under Biden, he believes. "Everything," he said, "started going up."
International politics also plays a role. The two presidential candidates took different stances on the president of El Salvador, Nayib Bukele. Where Trump embraced the so-called "world's coolest dictator," Harris expressed concerns about a decline in the country's democratic institutions.
Martinez said that many Salvadorans, who comprise the largest foreign-born population in Maryland, were disgruntled with what they perceived as Harris attacking a national hero. He said Bukele has done an amazing job of fighting crime in El Salvador.
Then, there's the elephant in the room.
Prior to the elections, immigrant rights groups warned that Trump's return to power would spell devastation for immigrant communities. But both Martinez and Salazar pointed to a greater number of deportations under President Obama than under Trump, in Trump's defense.
"When he won in 2016, they were saying the same thing, exactly," Martinez said.
He also said people should remember that Trump extended Temporary Protected Status to Salvadorans in 2019. Martinez, who perceives Democrats as more lenient towards illegal immigration, believes Harris was worse for immigrants in the state. Trump extended Temporary Protected Status after revoking it in 2018.
"There are bad and good people," Martinez said.
He added that many Latinos in the state support tougher immigration. The vast majority who come to the U.S., he believes, are good and hardworking people. It's the small percentage of undocumented individuals doing bad things in the country, he said, that makes Americans perceive all Latinos as criminals.
Salazar believes Trump would not undergo mass indiscriminate deportations.
"He's not going to do this," said Salazar, "because if that happens, we will be here to say, 'Hey, that's not right.'"
Both men plan on attending Trump's upcoming inauguration on Jan. 20. They both hope to meet the administration and lobby for what they believe is important for Latinos in the state, and they are embracing optimism.
"For the Latino community," said Salazar, "there are a lot of good things that are happening."

title: Protest to progress: Righting centuries of wrongs in Federalsburg
author: Staff Writer
content:
Protest to progress: Righting centuries of wrongs in Federalsburg

 December 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editorials 
 
 740
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Federalsburg last week took another step toward righting two centuries of ignoring its Black residents.The town unveiled a plaque commemorating the town's progress driven by a lawsuit requiring an overhaul of the election system that systemically prevented the election of Black council members for 200 years.
The court settlement announced in April was heralded as a landmark victory for Black voting rights.
The sign was one part of the settlement, which included an apology from the town.
"The Town of Federalsburg formally acknowledges responsibility and expresses its deep regret for actions and inactions contributing to racial discrimination and exclusion of Black residents, including its use of an election system that prevented any Black person from holding a position on the Town Council over 200 years," read the town's apology. "As officials of the Town, we accept moral accountability for the harms these actions inflicted upon Black residents, their families, and ancestors before them."
The town's apology concluded: "Through this expression of regret to those who endured race-based hardship and injustice, we seek to turn the page on this shameful history, and to begin a process of reconciliation among all of the Town's residents."
That apology is framed and displayed at Town Hall.
In addition, the settlement included:
Commissioning the plaque "From Protest to Progress: Events that Changed the Face of Federalsburg", celebrating Black voters' historic voting rights victory.Installing a photo display at Town Hall, in collaboration with the historical society and the plaintiffs in the lawsuit featuring Black community contributions to Federalsburg.Restoring the name Brooklyn Avenue to the portion of the avenue in the Black district that had been renamed Gerardi Boulevard.Issuing a proclamation naming Sept. 26 of each year as Voting Rights Day in recognition of Black voters' historic win on that day in 2023, the town's bicentennial year.Establishing a Town Unity Committee of elected officials and residents from each district to focus on community engagement in future elections and matters related to the promotion, engagement and enhancement of the town's diverse community.Establishing an annual multicultural celebration.
The lawsuit was filed as Federalsburg celebrated its bicentennial. It challenged Federalsburg's election practices, including its longstanding use of at-large and staggered elections, as violations of the Voting Rights Act.
The suit said Federalsburg maintained a "white stranglehold on municipal power" with its long-standing use "of a racially dilutive at-large, staggered term election system, rather than a racially fair system that would afford Black Federalsburg voters an equal opportunity to elect candidates of their choice."
In 2023, under a judge's supervision to create a plan that did not violate the Voting Rights Act, town leaders changed the election from at-large representation into a two-district system. The plan called for two of the four town council members to represent the predominantly Black part of town.
The election was held in September 2023, resulting in the election of the town's first two Black council members. Darlene Hammond received the highest number of ballots, earning 70 votes and a five-year term on the town council. Brandy James received 52 votes, earning a three-year term on the council.
After the plaque was unveiled last week, Hammond had tears in her eyes.
"It's a lot," she said, taking a pause, "to think that this small little town was able to stand for the rights of all people, not some people."
Hammond, who was a plaintiff in the lawsuit against the town, said the progress that has been made in the town is "heartwarming" and "breathtaking."
"It's a dream come true for me and for others that (came) before me, that we have established that everybody should be represented no matter what the color of your skin is," she said.
Sherone Lewis, a Federalsburg native and first vice president for the Caroline County branch of the NAACP who was a plaintiff in the lawsuit, called it surreal to be celebrating the changes that have been made.
"But I must say, the struggle continues," she said. "We still have a lot of work to do for diversity, equity and inclusion. I know those are buzz words these days. But I do believe that, because I want this for my children, my grandchildren."
Federalsburg has come a long way in the past year. The struggle continues, but the plaque unveiling was an occasion to celebrate progress.
"This day forever marks a turning point in Federalsburg, beginning a new chapter that celebrates Federalsburg's diverse community," the last line of the plaque reads.
Other Eastern Shore communities would be wise to see that their election results are reflective of their communities.

title: Bringing Latino Christmas traditions to Oxford
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Bringing Latino Christmas traditions to Oxford

 December 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 347
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD — The Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center hosted a Posada Navideña, a Mexican Christmas tradition of community and song, on Friday evening at the Oxford Community Center. The event provided new experiences to Eastern Shore natives and a piece of home to those missing their native countries during the holidays.Posada Navideña involves people, often children, gathering outside and going door-to-door singing Spanish holiday songs in order to reenact the Christian story of Mary and Joseph seeking shelter for the birth of Jesus.
In certain areas in Mexico, people will provide the singers with treats while they listen to the songs. The singers will sing around the neighborhood before going to one house that has food and warm treats awaiting them.
Victoria Gomez Lozano, deputy director of the Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center, said this was the first time the center has hosted a Posada and hopes to continue the tradition in upcoming years.
"I think the reason, as with any other activities that we are organizing here, is just so our clients can have a little piece of their countries," Gomez Lozano said. "Some of the traditions that we would like to keep and maintain, so maybe they can also feel at home."
Gomez Lozano said the event received a lot of support from Oxford neighbors who eagerly awaited the crowd of singers to reach their homes.
Throughout the Posada, people of all ages enjoyed the event and especially enjoyed the various treats including tamales, champurrado (a chocolate-based thick drink made with corn flour), chuchitos (Guatemalan tamales), apple Christmas salad, fruit salad, cookies, coffee and apple cider.
The evening provided attendees the opportunity to give back. Gomez Lozano said a table at the event held handmade ornaments that could be purchased through a donation.
The donations will benefit the center's after-school program. People also could sponsor a child of the program for a year. Sponsorships will give the donor an ornament, a thank you card from the child sponsored and a tour of the after-school program.
Gomez Lozano said ornaments still are available. Those interested can call the Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center for more information.

title: Nause-Waiwash's 1st female chief fights for identity, equality and preservation
author: Andrea Durán Capital News Service
content:
Nause-Waiwash's 1st female chief fights for identity, equality and preservation

 December 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Andrea Durán Capital News Service | Section: News 
 
 1402
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — A little over five feet tall, the chief of the Nause-Waiwash walked quickly. Despite a limp from a recent total knee replacement, she zipped up and down the stairs at the Dorchester County Visitor Center.The chief beamed as the overhead lights caught in her silver dreamcatcher earrings and white-streaked hair. Her blue-gray eyes darted over the various exhibits displaying pieces of her culture and history: a photograph of her uncle fishing, a miniature Nause-Waiwash longhouse and a taxidermied white muskrat.
The Nause-Waiwash tribe is one of the seven Native American tribes that are represented on the Maryland Commission of Indian Affairs, although the tribe is not state-recognized. The tribe, whose origins and traditions were once nearly lost but now are being revitalized, does statewide educational outreach to, as their chief says, "tell their story in their own words."
Chief Donna Wolf Mother Abbott is the first woman chief of a Maryland tribe in known recorded history.
Abbott has now been "Chief Donna" for 10 years. However, when she was first approached to run, she had serious doubts about whether she even wanted to become chief.
"But then I got thinking again, it's not about me," she said. "If I didn't step up and take on the responsibility I felt like that, all that would have just disappeared, and again, we would have lost our history one more time."
As chief, Abbott is in charge of planning the tribe's annual festival, overseeing educational outreach and acting as a liaison between the tribe and conservancy groups.
Deborah Barber, director of land conservation at the Nature Conservancy's Maryland chapter, has worked with Abbott on a handful of projects and said she admired Abbott's willingness to work with others within and outside of the native community.
Barber said a conversation with Abbott made her realize that what she was doing with her own children, being intentional about the values she is instilling in them, Abbott is doing with her own family and the whole tribe.
"She's doing it times 150," Barber said in an interview with Capital News Service.
It wasn't until Abbott was in her 30s and already a mother that she became fascinated with researching and passionate about preserving her culture.
"Growing up, I knew I was Native American, but it wasn't something that we shouted from the rooftops," she said. "It was just who we are."
Abbott said it was her cousin who approached her and told her she needed to join the tribe, but when Abbott resisted, her cousin told her, "It's not about you."
"It's about preserving what we have and learning and teaching and then teaching it for our next generation," Abbott said.
Since then, she has been dedicated to learning about her culture and educating others.
"I myself, I want to learn it all," she said. "Just not enough hours in the day."
However, as she became more involved in the native community, she also encountered stereotyping from both native and non-native people because she passes for white.
"'How much Indian are you?' How much do you want me to be? How much do I have to be? Does it make a difference?" Abbott said. "Not just the Nause-Waiwash—but not all tribes are tall, thin, with black hair and high cheekbones, riding bareback."
However, Abbott said that when she does encounter stereotyping or unfamiliarity with her culture, she turns to optimistic grace.
"I really try to blame it on the lack of knowledge," she said. "I'm like, 'These people don't know any better, so let's teach them.' So, I try not to take it personal. But I go through the 'okay, I'm mad now.' … and then I get over it."
Beyond tackling the prominent misconception that there were no more Indigenous people in the region, Abbott faced a multitude of challenges to increasing tribe membership. One of them is sexism from within and outside of the native community.
"…Here we are (in) 2024, and there's still so much gender discrimination and thoughts out there about, 'Oh, you have to be a warrior to be a chief,' And I'm like, 'Says who? No, you're practicing Western history,'" Abbott said.
Abbott said that some had used her gender against her and shamed her for not being as firm as the previous chief.
"I have been told I'm a pushover. I am a people-pleaser. And 'Who's ever heard of a woman chief? Who's ever heard of a chief or an Indian with blue eyes?'" she said.
Jerry "Gentle Bear" Hughes is 34 years old and serves as the Nause-Waiwash Band of Indians' vice chair and social media administrator. He is also Abbott's son, and he said it was his mother becoming chief that persuaded him to become involved with the tribe in his 20s.
Although Abbott's leadership might be controversial to some, Hughes said it's led the tribe to new opportunities.
"Oh, she's been an inspiration to everyone involved," Hughes said. "We've seen a lot of people who had stepped away because people had rubbed them the wrong way or made them angry or said something out of line. We've seen a lot of those people come back. We've had a lot of olive branches extended to us since she's been elected."
Prospective chiefs in the Nause-Waiwash tribe are nominated by the tribe's council to run, and the tribe's women vote for them. In 1988, the Nause-Waiwash Band of Indians was formed to preserve the Nause-Waiwash culture. A council of elders was created, and the tribe's women elected Fitzhugh as the chief.
Twenty-six years later, Chief Fitzhugh died, and in November 2014, Abbott was elected as his successor.
She has had doubts about making the right decisions for the tribe and questioned her own leadership.
"I have actually considered stepping down, and my son has said, 'If you step down, then who's gonna do it?'" she said. "But if I step down and nobody does it, then I feel I'm going to feel responsible for letting everything go and being a part of what caused us to lose our history again. And I don't know that I would be happy with myself if I did that."
The Nause-Waiwash people have always been in Dorchester County, which is known for its lush wetlands, diverse wildlife and crabbing and fishing on Maryland's Eastern Shore. They are descendants of the Nanticoke and Choptank tribes of modern-day eastern Maryland and Delaware. Unlike other Native American tribes, the Nause-Waiwash escaped persecution and death by hiding in plain sight for centuries and sometimes marrying Europeans.
"When I was in school, there were three paragraphs about the Trail of Tears that didn't apply to us," Abbott said.
However, even within the Nause-Waiwash community and Abbott's own family, people's connections to their Indigenous heritage can be complicated.
"My own sister does not identify as Native American," she said. "It just is not important to her. However, I do. Same mother, same father."
When someone wants to join the tribe, Abbott and other members must do a lot of genealogical research to verify connections to the tribe.
One major challenge for the tribe is getting younger people more involved.
Another is that younger tribal members are moving away from the area because of rising sea levels.
"It is just my opinion, but in the next hundred years, the Eastern Shore is probably not even going to be here based on what I see on our trapping grounds," she said. "That part of the county probably won't be here in the next 50 years."
Dorchester County is one of the regions in the country with the fastest sea-level rises, according to research by the Virginia Institute of Marine Science. In 2020, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration released a study that said, for example, sea levels for the Chesapeake Bay increased twice that of the global average over the 20th century.
For Abbott, who said she feels she's only scratched the surface of her people's history on her ancestral lands, the environmental changes feel especially tragic.
"I think that's going to be a part of our history that we're going to lose, that we can't get back because a lot of our ancestral land will be gone," she said. "There are probably hundreds of cemeteries that have washed away. We are never to get those back."
But Abbott stays optimistic about the future of her tribe.
"I think the culture can survive because the history in the culture, in their traditions, are the ones who practice it," she said. "And I think if we all pull together, then yes, absolutely, it'll survive whether we have our ancestral land or not."

title: During the holidays, LGBTQ community remembers the importance of chosen family
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
During the holidays, LGBTQ community remembers the importance of chosen family

 December 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Christmas 
 
 631
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — For many members of the LGBTQ+ community, who sometimes are outcast from their biological families, spending time with loved ones looks different during the holidays.Many members of the community rely on their chosen family for support and kindness.
Chosen family allows members of the LGBTQ+ to find community, support, kindness and love. For many, chosen families are there in all aspects of their lives, including during the holiday season.
Tina Grace Jones, co-founder and treasurer of the Delmarva Pride Center, said chosen family is particularly important to members of the LGBTQ+ community, especially since biological families sometimes cast people out due to their sexual orientation or gender identity.
"Chosen family really is about being there when somebody needs you and knowing that they'll be there for you no matter what the circumstances are," Jones said. "It's not based on blood or this lineage that you can trace, but it's based on love."
Lauren Fierman, a member of the board of directors at Delmarva Pride Center, said even for those who are still connected with their biological families, chosen family can allow for people to be truly themselves.
"Your chosen family is there for you that everyone brings something to the table, whether it's like a physical resource, an emotional shoulder to cry on," Fierman said. "Your chosen family is there for you because they choose to. That's in the name."
For Jones, the impact chosen family can have in an LGBTQ+ person's life is incredibly important. Chosen family can help members of the LGBTQ+ community stay safe due to the community's high rate mental health struggles and suicidal inclinations.
"It's not because there's something wrong with us, but it's because we don't have those connections," Jones said. "We don't always have those connections that we need. And the one thing that the studies have shown again and again is the one thing that does the most good in reducing suicide rates among LGBTQ people is having one affirming person in your life.
"That's that chosen family."
Jones said chosen family will be there for you and support you in all ways. She recalls a time when one of her friends faced a medical emergency, and she was the first one to be called. Through contacting proper medical intervention, Jones was there to support and possibly saved her friend's life.
For Fierman, chosen family can also help people explore gender expression. Fierman recalled a time when one of their close friends, who was not assigned female at birth, asked Fierman to teach them basic makeup application skills. Together, they were able to explore different aspects of femininity in a safe and welcoming space.
Jones said the moments where your chosen family shows up for you can be more than essential.
Jones recollects a time when she and her wife were foster parents for a gender nonbinary child who was not welcomed by any of their birth parents.
"Unfortunately, this child took their own life in our home two years ago because they couldn't just deal with the pain of not having been accepted by their birth parents," Jones said. "That's probably the most difficult thing I've ever dealt with in my life, but the outpouring of love and support that we got from, not only blood family, but especially from the chosen family, was so amazing and so comforting."
Though Jones understands it can be difficult for people to take initial steps toward community, she encourages all people, regardless of gender identity and sexual orientation, to find community at the Delmarva Pride Center
"Everybody needs hope, and everybody needs a place where they can say, 'You know what, it's okay. It's OK to be who you are.' And so that's why we do what we do with our love of pride," Jones said. "We can't solve everything but one little step at a time."

title: Families salute Maryland women of 'Six Triple Eight'
author: ROBERT STEWART Capital News Service
content:
Families salute Maryland women of 'Six Triple Eight'

 January 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ROBERT STEWART Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 713
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CATONSVILLE — Nineteen women from Maryland served during World War II in the 6888th Battalion, the predominantly black postal unit now the subject of the blockbuster film "The Six Triple Eight."After decades of hearing their stories only as family lore, if they heard them at all, the families of these Marylanders are watching those stories come alive — and enjoying the long-awaited recognition for their service.
"I have wanted my mother and my aunt to be honored and to be appreciated for a long time," said Karen Taylor, "and now because of the Tyler Perry movie the world knows what they accomplished."
Although not main characters in Perry's movie, Taylor's mother and aunt were both members of the postal unit featured in the film.
The Six Triple Eight, officially the 6888th Central Postal Directory Battalion, deployed to Europe for roughly a year during World War II. Some 855 women came from across the U.S. to process mail in the European theater of war.
They were a twice-segregated unit, as women served separately from men at the time, and women of color served separately from white women.
The film release prior to Christmas has reanimated discussion of the unit, bringing their accomplishments into public consciousness. For descendants and family members, it's a culmination of a multi-year effort to bring awareness to their family's military service.
Taylor, a 78-year-old retired dental hygienist, points to her living room wall lined with pictures of family members in her Catonsville apartment. Several items, including pictures, a U.S. flag, a certificate and a movie poster indicate a connection to the 6888th.
"These women were fighting for us," Taylor said, "Even if someone tells you you can't do something, you don't let it go at that. You keep on going and prove that you can."
Taylor says that's how her mother raised her.
Taylor's mother, Vivian Elzie Taylor, was one of 19 women who enlisted in Maryland and deployed with the 6888th. After serving in Europe and meeting and marrying her husband, Elyseo J. Taylor, in Paris, she settled in Salisbury, Maryland.
She and her husband, a tanker in the first Black tank battalion, eventually divorced. Elzie Taylor went to teach art at the all-Black Salisbury High School in Maryland's then-segregated school system.
From a segregated army to a segregated school system, Elzie Taylor's mid-century career was emblematic of the challenges Black women faced in Maryland and around the country.
She passed a lesson on to her daughter about persevering in the face of obstacles.
"My mom pushed me," Taylor said. "She made me."
After her mom died, Taylor began exploring the military oral history her mother had shared with her. It wasn't just her mother who served. Taylor's aunt, Marian Elzie Wilson, enlisted in Pennsylvania and also deployed with the 6888th.
The more she learned, she said, the more she understood the groundbreaking territory the group charted.
And she wasn't the only one.
Vashti Murphy Matthews, from Baltimore's multi-generational publishing family of AFRO American Newspaper, also served overseas with the 6888th.
She was a taciturn woman who — despite a drill sergeant-like leadership style — never spoke about her time in the army, according to her daughter, Betty Schuler.
"Had it not been for me finding some pictures, we would never have known that she served at all," said Schuler. "Not one word did she speak."
Schuler and her cousin first learned about the 6888th when a monument was being erected in honor of the unit. Researchers and fundraisers were reaching out to descendants and media organizations, which led them to Schuler and her cousin, Frances Murphy Draper, CEO and publisher of the family business.
The Buffalo Soldier Educational and Historical Committee created a monument for the 6888th in Fort Leavenworth, Kansas, outside of Kansas City, in 2018.
A few years later, Congress passed legislation awarding the unit the Congressional Gold Medal. Maryland Gov. Wes Moore even designated March 9 as a day honoring the 6888th in Maryland.
But it wasn't until the movie that the unit really caught people's attention. Draper compares the Six Triple Eight to other overlooked stories about people of color.
"I think it also speaks to the 'argument' about the need to really teach African American history," said Draper. "There's a whole history of people, and the more we understand about people … the more we understand that we have more in common than we have different."

title: Easton town hall meeting delves into expectations for LGBTQ+ community in new administration
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Easton town hall meeting delves into expectations for LGBTQ+ community in new administration

 January 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 521
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — In the final days before President-elect Donald Trump is sworn into office, Maryland's LGBTQ+ community is preparing for what could lie ahead."With the upcoming change in administration, the United States is poised to experience significant rollbacks in federal protections for LGBTQIA+ people, with transgender people squarely in the crosshairs," Delmarva Pride Center Board Chair Tina Jones said during a town hall event Wednesday evening.
Jones said that although state laws in Maryland provide more protections to LGBTQ+ people compared to many other states, protections in Maryland vary based on where people live, attend school and seek healthcare.
The town hall, which was held at the Waterfowl Building in downtown Easton, brought together a panel of experts to share their expectations for the next four years as well as their thoughts on what the state can do to ensure and expand protections for Maryland's LGBTQ+ community. Along with the Delmarva Pride Center, the event was hosted by DoCo Pride and the Maryland Legislative LGBTQ+ Caucus.
The four-person panel — which included Del. Kris Fair (D-Frederick), Fair's Chief of Staff Camila Reynolds-Dominguez, FreeState Justice Executive Director Phillip Westry and Maryland Office of the Attorney General Civil Rights Division Chief Jonathan Smith — answered questions related to schools and workplace, health care and family law.
Caleb Holland, an attorney and the chair of DoCo Pride, who moderated the town hall, said the goal of the event is "to prepare, not scare."
On the topic of education, Smith said he expects the Trump administration will try to push through executive orders around funding schools that are based on sports issues, bathrooms or the ability to deadname or misgender students. But Smith said there are "very significant responses" states can make.
"There's been a body of law that's developed that says the United States government cannot, through its funding powers, coerce states to take policy decisions that are not for the function of funding," he said.
Westry said organizing and getting active in politics, like school boards, is a good way to get involved.
Although part of Wednesday night's conversation focused on bracing for what could happen in the country, the panelists also talked about what gives them hope.
Fair, who is the chair of the Maryland Legislative LGBTQ+ Caucus, recalled the 2018 midterm elections. He said the country elected more women, more queer people and more people of color than ever before.
"In 2018, we figured out that in order to protect our rights, we need to do everything we can to put as many people who look like us into positions of power," he said. "What I am hopeful for is that 2026 looks just like that."
Reynolds-Dominguez, who was previously a policy advocate and legal impact coordinator at FreeState Justice, said that in the last couple of years, the state has taken an "aggressive stance" on doing everything possible to anticipate rollbacks. She said Maryland is "situated to weather this storm" and that should be used as a catalyst for doing long-term work.
"The core of all of this is shifting people's hearts and minds," she said. "And if we're not doing that work, we're spending our time in the wrong place."
