title: MLK's 'beloved community' has inspired social justice work for decades - what did he mean?
author: Jason Oliver Evans The Conservation
content:
MLK's 'beloved community' has inspired social justice work for decades - what did he mean?

 January 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jason Oliver Evans The Conservation | Section: Opinion 
 
 1054
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Since 1983, when President Ronald Reagan signed Martin Luther King Jr. Day into law, many Americans have observed the federal holiday to commemorate the life and legacy of the civil rights leader, Baptist minister and theologian.MLK Day volunteers typically perform community service that continues King's fight to end racial discrimination and economic injustice — to build the "beloved community," as he often said.
King does not fully explain the phrase's meaning in his published writings, speeches and sermons. Scholars Rufus Burrow Jr. and Lewis V. Baldwin, however, argue that the beloved community is King's principal ethical goal, guiding the struggle against what he called the "three evils of American society": racism, economic exploitation and militarism.
As a Baptist minister and theologian myself, I believe it is important to understand the origins of the concept of the beloved community, how King understood it and how he worked to make it a reality.
Older originsAlthough King popularized the beloved community, the phrase has roots in the thought of 19th-century American religious philosopher Josiah Royce.
In 1913, toward the end of his long career, Royce published "The Problem of Christianity." The book compiles lectures on the Christian religion, including the idea of the church and its mission, and coined the term beloved community. Based on his readings of the biblical gospels, as well as the writings of the apostle Paul, Royce argued that the beloved community was one where individuals are transformed by God's love.
In turn, members express that love as loyalty toward each other — for example, the devoted love a member of the church would have toward the church as a whole.
While Royce often identified the beloved community with the church, he extends the concept beyond the walls of Christianity. In any type of community, Royce argued, from clans to nations, there are individuals who express love and devotion not only to their own community, but who foster a sense of the community that includes all humankind.
According to Royce, the ideal or beloved community is a "universal community" — one to which all human beings belong or will eventually belong at the end of time.
'Beloved' diversityTwentieth-century pastor, philosopher, mystic, theologian and civil rights leader Howard Thurman retrieved Royce's idea of the beloved community and applied it to his life and work, most notably in his 1971 book "The Search for Common Ground."
Thurman first used the term in an unpublished and undated article: Desegregation, Integration, and the Beloved Community. Here, he argued that the beloved community cannot be achieved by sheer will or commanded by force. Rather, it begins with transformation in each person's "human spirit." The seeds of the beloved community extend outward into society as each person assumes the responsibility of bringing it to pass.
Thurman envisioned the beloved community as one that exemplifies harmony — harmony enriched by members' diversity. It is a community wherein people from all racial, national, religious and ethnic backgrounds are respected, and where their human dignity is affirmed. Thurman was convinced that beloved community was achievable because of the dedication he saw from activists during the struggle for racial integration.
During his lifetime, Thurman sought to build this beloved community through his activism for racial justice. For example, he co-founded the Church for the Fellowship of All Peoples, an interracial and interfaith community in San Francisco, which he co-pastored from 1943 to 1953.
Thurman's writings and activism deeply influenced King. Burrow argued that it is not entirely clear when and where King first learned the concept of beloved community. Yet King emphasized its importance in much of his writing and political action.
Love and actionIn simplest terms, King defined the beloved community as a community transformed by love. Like Royce, he drew his understanding of love from the Bible's New Testament. In the original Greek, the Gospels use the word "agape," which suggests God's self-giving, unconditional love for humanity — and, by extension, human beings' self-giving, unconditional love for each other.
According to Baldwin, however, King's understanding of the beloved community is better understood against the backdrop of the Black church tradition. Raised in the Ebenezer Baptist Church of Atlanta, King learned lessons on the meaning of love from his parents, Rev. Martin Luther King Sr. — Ebenezer's pastor, who was also a leader in the local chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People — and Alberta Christine Williams King.
One of the distinctions in King's thought is that he believed the beloved community could be achieved through nonviolent direct action, such as sit-ins, marches and boycotts. In part, he was inspired by Thurman, who had embraced the nonviolence at the heart of Mahatma Gandhi's resistance against the British in India. For King, nonviolence was the only viable means for achieving the United States of America's redemption from the sin of racial segregation and white supremacy.
For King, therefore, the beloved community was not merely a utopian vision of the future. He envisioned it as an obtainable ethical goal that all human beings must work collectively toward achieving.
"Only a refusal to hate or kill can put an end to the chain of violence in the world and lead us toward a community where men can live together without fear," King wrote in 1966. "Our goal is to create a beloved community and this will require a qualitative change in our souls as well as a quantitative change in our lives."
Searching for the beloved community todayKing's idea of the beloved community has not only influenced people affiliated with the Christian tradition but also people from other faiths and none.
For instance, scholars Elizabeth A. Johnson, bell hooks and Joy James have reflected upon the meaning of the beloved community amid ongoing challenges such as global climate change, sexism, racism and other forms of structural violence.
People around the world continue to draw insight and inspiration from King's thought, especially from his insistence that love is "the most durable power" to change the world for the better. Questions remain about whether his beloved community can be realized, or how. But I believe it is important to understand King's ethical concept and its continuing influence on movements that seek an end to injustice.
Jason Oliver Evans is a research associate and lecturer at the University of Virginia

title: Icy weather does not keep Caroline County from honoring Martin Luther King
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Icy weather does not keep Caroline County from honoring Martin Luther King

 January 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 379
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Snowy and icy conditions did not stop a crowd of locals showing up to Lockerman Middle School for the 13th annual Martin Luther King Jr. Day ceremony.Although the march was cancelled due to inclement weather, locals packed the school's cafeteria for a program that honored the civil rights hero's legacy.
"We're just so happy and proud that all the community has come together," event organizer Wanda Molock said. "We get a lot of community involvement, the schools, the churches and individuals. So we're so thrilled that it's going to keep on going because we all have a dream."
Some individuals were not able to attend due to the weather, but the organizers quickly improvised to keep the program going as scheduled.
The Lockerman Middle School chorus and band offered multiple selections, which attendees enjoyed.
Caroline County Commissioner Frank Bartz spoke on behalf of the Caroline County Commissioners, explaining the importance of King's legacy.
"While we honor Dr. King's life, we also acknowledge that the work he began continues in Caroline County," Bartz said. "We are trying to build a community, and inclusivity is more than just a word, it's a commitment ensuring that every person, regardless of background, is treated with dignity and respect."
Caroline County Public Schools Superintendent Derrick Simmons spoke on behalf of the district, explaining the importance of what King did and how Caroline County brings that mentality into its schools.
"I believe education is one of the most powerful tools in achieving Dr King's dream," Simmons said. "Every day in our schools, we strive to create environments where diversity is celebrated, all voices are heard, and discrimination has no place."
A mother and daughter duo from Metropolitan United Methodist Church offered poetry reciting of "Reverend Martin Luther King" written by Dr. Maya Angelou from mother Nikeisha Ogletree and a dance selection from daughter Laila Ogletree.
Closing out the program, Sammy Scott from New Beginnings United Methodist Church Division of Maryland recited King's "I have a dream" speech.
The most amazing part of the 13th annual Martin Luther King Jr. Day program for Molock was the participation of the local youth.
"Oh, it does my heart well," Molock said. "I'm a former educator, so to see the kids here and not home in bed, but getting out that student involvement is just so special."

title: Cambridge resident remembers involvement in 1965 march from Selma to Montgomery
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Cambridge resident remembers involvement in 1965 march from Selma to Montgomery

 January 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 520
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Cambridge resident Roy Davis remembers approaching Edmund Pettus Bridge for the first time during the march from Selma to Montgomery, Alabama in 1965. He was 14 years old."As we were coming up to the bridge, you could hear horses, dogs, screams," he recalled.
Once Davis reached the center of the bridge, he could see what he had been hearing: horses, dogs and people getting beaten with billy clubs and sprayed with tear gas.
"I was scared," Davis, a Selma, Alabama native, said.
During a Martin Luther King Jr. Day commemoration event at Christ Episcopal Church in Cambridge on Monday, Davis shared his recollection of the famous Alabama marches, which took marchers three times before they were able to cross the bridge.
Davis said they marched about 15 or 16 miles each day until they arrived in Montgomery.
"It wasn't bad on me," he said about the distance. "I was 14 years old. I could run and walk all day."
His mother didn't know about Davis' involvement in the first march, but she was proud when she found out. "She was calling my relatives in Chicago, New York and everything," he said.
MARCHING ONDavis remembers being on the playground during recess after he had gotten back to Selma from the march.
"And kids were coming to me (saying), 'Roy, you're on Newsweek Magazine,'" he said.
Davis didn't believe them. But sure enough, on the cover of the April 5, 1965 edition of Newsweek, Davis is seen marching with two other young men on the road to Montgomery.
Almost 60 years later, Davis continues to champion issues important to him. These days, that issue is homelessness in Dorchester County.
"These people have no business being homeless," he said. "Can't get nothing to eat. ... And that's what we are doing these days. Helping them try and get housing."
After the event, attendee Lametha Elbert said Davis' experience in the march and as a kid in Alabama in the 1960s struck her. She talked about the importance of people sharing their experiences.
Dorchester County Democratic Central Committee Chair Sarah Gavian said the event had "universal appeal," bringing people together.
"It comes on a day that's very important for people, certainly for Democrats, to be turning their energies forward constructively and figuring out how to be more community (service-oriented) and engage better." Across the bridge in Washington, D.C., Republican President Donald Trump had been sworn in a few hours earlier.
Along with Davis' story, the Martin Luther King Jr. Day event — hosted by the Dorchester County Democratic Central Committee — included a variety of speeches and songs. First United Methodist Church of Hyattsville Rev. Yvonne Wallace Penn and Cambridge Mayor Lajan Cephas' fiancé Joe Johnson-Bey both spoke. Vocalist Maris Wicker sang "This Little Light of Mine" and "Balm in Gilead." Marie Anderson closed out the evening singing "If I Could Help Somebody."
Johnson-Bey spoke for Cephas, who couldn't be at the event. He shared the importance of loving each other through everything.
Wallace Penn said that King lived love.
"He said, 'I have decided to stick to love' because I don't have time to waste to hate anybody. But I have time to love you," Wallace Penn said.

title: Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center fights against misinformation
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center fights against misinformation

 January 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 618
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — In an effort to fight misinformation surrounding the changing landscape of immigration laws, the Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center is working to inform and prepare the Eastern Shore community at risk of deportation.A wave of executive orders has been signed by President Donald Trump since he assumed office last week. Several of these focus on immigration and mass deportation throughout the country.
The orders include, but are not limited to, closing off access to the CBP One App and asylum protections at the U.S. border; sending more troops to assist with border barriers and removal flights; and opening the door for immigration authorities to arrest immigrants in schools, churches and hospitals.
According to Matthew Peters, executive director of the center, since the announcement of the executive orders, the center has received an influx of phone calls from worried community members.
"A lot of people are calling, very concerned about all the things they see in their social media and all the things they're hearing from the media about the executive orders," Peters said. "So people are just (trying to) understand what consequences they may or may not have. What do (the orders) mean? And that's obviously going to take time for everyone to kind of absorb a lot of those executive orders and see what they mean in the real world."
The Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center is working to distribute Know Your Rights guides, implement additional immigration services and offer classes for citizenship.
Victoria Gomez Lozano, deputy director of the Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center, said red cards are being shared at the center, providing information to help people assert their rights and defend themselves in situations with officials such as immigration agents and police officers.
Gomez Lozano said she hopes the red cards can provide needed information for people who find themselves in situations where their families or themselves are in need of immediate assistance but are unable to quickly get it.
The center has released a Know Your Rights guide for everyone who is in need of the information. This guide addresses the rights that all people, regardless of immigration status and criminal history, have to protect themselves.
The guide addresses what people need to know and what to do when encountering immigration agents, police or FBI in different places; how to read a warrant; preparing emergency planning checklists; and what to do if a loved one calls from an immigration detention center or police station.
Additionally, the center has announced Ingrid Diaz Lopez as a newly promoted immigration specialist. Diaz Lopez has recently been awarded recognition and accreditation by the Executive Office for Immigration Review.
Diaz Lopez said she will be working alongside Peters, taking on immigration applications and assisting the community.
Diaz Lopez has been doing extensive work for high-risk communities on the Eastern Shore, including coordinating free citizenship classes, preparing immigration forms and applications and overall demonstrating a deep commitment to the well-being of those she serves.
The responsibility of truth is not one that is taken lightly by the team at the center, and Diaz Lopez said it is important to see the humanity of the Hispanic immigrant community that has been targeted for mass deportation.
As an immigrant herself, Diaz Lopez can attest to the importance of hard work and dedication in shaping her journey and sees that work effort and dedication in the community she works to protect.
"It's important to recognize that welcoming immigrants aligns with the core values of opportunity and compassion that we hold dear," Diaz Lopez said. "I urge you to be mindful of your words and actions, as we are all human beings, and we all have feelings. Remember, either you or your ancestors were once immigrants, and consider how you would have wanted them to be treated."

title: Delmarva Pride Center brings new world with Dungeons and Dragons
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Delmarva Pride Center brings new world with Dungeons and Dragons

 February 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 824
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — In the tavern of a formerly demolished village, a group of brave adventurers is approached by well-dressed, albeit frail-looking, elders who offer a reward of 700 gold to whoever is brave enough to investigate the lizard folks lair in order to gather information on their military weapons.Lauren Fierman, a board member of the Delmarva Pride Center and host of the center's Dungeons and Dragons program, moves around the conference room of the Unitarian Universalist Fellowship in Easton.
With every sentence, Fierman provides history, landscape and heart to the world the group of players has carefully developed.
Delmarva Pride Center hosts an open-for-all Dungeons and Dragons, a fantasy tabletop role-playing game, on the fourth Saturday of the month.
What started as a small game event has turned into a growing community, providing a safe environment during a heightened political climate for members of the LGBQT+ community and allies to explore gender identity, sexuality and imagination.
Fierman, who acts as dungeon master (game organizer and participant in charge of creating details and challenges for the game), said the game understands and respects the personal boundaries of its players.
From allowing players to choose the character's pronouns to deciding whether or not they will act out in regional accents, the comfortability of players is key to a successful game.
In Fierman's experience, Dungeons and Dragons provided the first space for them to use different pronouns.
"I'm playing with gender, (and) I'm playing with sexuality in my characters, and it's just such a wonderful avenue to explore different identities and sexualities," Fierman said. "As a fluid person myself, it was very healthy for me to be in a very safe space with people that I trust to express those parts of me through this game."
Allie Silver, one of the local group's players, said historically Dungeons and Dragons has had a white, straight, male focus. But in recent years, the game has been claimed by LGBTQ+ people who have found the fantasy and community aspect comforting, especially if they feel isolated.
"Just creating that space of safety for yourself and for the people at your table is so important because it can become such a beautiful thing," Silver said. "And it's OK if it's not transcendent. If you just play a silly game and kill a bunch of goblins, that's fun.
"But just the joy of friendship at the table of community collaboration is what makes this game so good. Especially now more than ever, community is what we need."
Though character building is an important aspect of the game, other players said the game provides an opportunity for them to create LGBTQ+ representation that is frequently left out in the media.
Zack Parreco, a player, said often LGBTQ+ characters' stories use "queerness" as something that is othering and aimed at larger audiences to gawk at. In Dungeons and Dragons, LGBTQ+ people can build characters and stories where they can control what is important and what is normal.
"There is no pressure for queerness to be a performance for others. It is allowed to just exist," Parreco said. "Maybe we make it big or maybe it's just a normal trait in the world. Either way, we get to fully control our queerness and its expression."
Outside of the game world, players are able to take aspects of their fictional characters into their real lives. Some bring with them new pronouns, and others, like Silver, bring back more courage.
Silver shared that when she started playing, she was "an anxious little mouse," and, when she was comfortable, she began playing a bold character whose main trait was being able to stand up for everybody.
"It was a really fun character, and in the process it gave me permission to find my own courage in my real life and now, in my professional life," Silver said. "I'm an adviser for a Pride group. I volunteer in a bunch of different spaces, and I work to help people and I think that's something eight years ago I would have been terrified to do."
According to Fierman, this space is particularly important due to the rise in policies rolling back LGBTQ+ protections since President Donald Trump's inauguration. These policies include executive orders prohibiting gender-affirming health care for those under 19 and designating that the country recognizes only two sexes.
Fierman said now more than ever community and joy needs to be prioritized. This game provides a space to escape from the pressures of the outside and create a physical, mental and emotional space for anyone that needs to get away.
"The goal of a lot of these anti-LGBTQ policies and misinformation is to take away our joy. They want us to go away, and I think combating hate with love and combating hate with joy is the most powerful thing you can do because that's what's going to keep us going. That's what kept our community fighting back for generations."
Delmarva Pride Center hosts monthly events including Gender Expression Movement, Elder and Intergeneration Social and Parents and Allies Groups.

title: Delmarva Pride Center to vote on having chapters across the Shore
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Delmarva Pride Center to vote on having chapters across the Shore

 February 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 633
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On Sunday, the Delmarva Pride Center Board of Directors will vote on a significant change to its bylaws.If the amendment passes, LGBTQ+ groups and organizations like DoCo Pride will have the ability to join the Delmarva Pride Center as a chapter of the organization. Each chapter would also get two seats on the pride center's Board of Directors.
Delmarva Pride Center Board Chair Tina Jones said the center has found that for organizations in small, rural areas, keeping up with the administrative side of things can be difficult. She said the center would help take care of the administrative tasks for organizations that become members so the organizations could focus on providing services.
"Each community here on the Shore is different," Jones said. "Talbot County's very different than Dorchester, than Queen Anne's, than Kent. They know their communities. It allows them to build programs or events that will help better serve their different communities. That's the idea."
Jones said amendments to the bylaws have been drafted. She expects the board will vote to pass them Sunday.
If the amendments to the bylaws are approved, DoCo Pride, an organization located in Dorchester County, will become a chapter of the center.
DoCo Pride Chair Caleb Holland said it all started when DoCo Pride reached out to the Delmarva Pride Center about the need for administrative supports. He said that conversation evolved into the idea of coming together and pooling resources.
Holland said that as a chapter of the pride center, DoCo Pride would keep its name.
"Basically, the individual chapters will take the lead on programming, events, things that are specific to that geographical area," he said, "but with the support of the larger Delmarva Pride Center infrastructure."
Although DoCo Pride isn't currently a chapter of the pride center, Holland has already gotten a taste for what this collaboration could bring. He said the pride center helped DoCo Pride advertise for a pride walk in December.
"And because Delmarva Pride helped us advertise that, we had people coming down from Kent," Holland said.
Holland said DoCo Pride knows what kinds of events and programming will be successful in Dorchester County and in Cambridge.
"But that doesn't mean that it wouldn't also be interesting for somebody that's in Kent or Talbot," he said.
With the Delmarva Pride Center's help and advertising, local events could reach a larger audience across the Eastern Shore.
Jones said this has basically been the Delmarva Pride Center's vision from the beginning.
"We just didn't have it quite set up right," she said. "We want to make sure that we're a resource for anybody LGBTQ in the area."
Laurel Atkiss, who founded DoCo Pride in 2021, said she is excited about the possibility of the organization becoming a chapter of the Delmarva Pride Center.
"I think that working with an organization that has already gotten their feet under them, has done a few events, has already kind of gone toe to toe with city councils and things, I think there's a lot of wisdom and guidance there that we can benefit from," she said. "And I think that's very exciting to have them available to us."
Holland said one of the reasons he moved to Cambridge in 2023 was because he saw "so many" pride flags around the city when he visited.
"And so it's really neat for me to now kind of spearhead this effort and bring that kind of visibility that was important for me," he said. "Now I can do that for hopefully other people."
Jones said that when they started the Delmarva Pride Center in 2021, there weren't many resources and places to go for area's the LGBTQ+ community.
"And so we've just got to make sure that we can come together and have a place where we can just be ourselves," she said. "It's nothing more than that. We just want to be ourselves."

title: MLK breakfast inspires action and resilience
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
MLK breakfast inspires action and resilience

 February 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 741
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — "Pivot, don't panic."This powerful message echoed through Washington College's Gibson Arts Theater as Devon Beck, keynote speaker for the annual Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Breakfast and Observance, urged attendees to remain steadfast in their pursuit of justice. The event, originally delayed by snow, brought together community members committed to honoring King's legacy of resilience and activism.
Sponsored by Minary's Dream Alliance, the Chester Valley Minister's Association, and Washington College's Starr Center for the Study of the American Experience, the Feb. 1 event was well attended, with around 150 people gathering in solidarity against racism and injustice.
Following breakfast at Hodson Dining Hall, the program featured music, poetry, and an inspiring address by Beck, owner of Beck Excellence and a diversity, equity, and inclusion facilitator. He emphasized the importance of perseverance, telling the audience, "Pivot, don't panic."
Co-Executive Directors of Minary's Dream Alliance, Doncella Wilson and Paul Tue III, highlighted the event's theme: "Mission Possible: Protecting Freedom, Justice, and Democracy in the Spirit of Nonviolence365." Wilson and Tue, drawing inspiration from the King Center in Atlanta, Georgia, encouraged attendees not to lose hope even in challenging times.
Tue, a football coach, used a sports analogy to illustrate the need for action. While his role is typically on defense, he urged the audience to go on offense against policies that threaten rights and freedoms at both local and federal levels.
Beck expanded on Tue's sentiments, acknowledging the weight of unkept promises and progress under siege. Quoting King, he reminded listeners that "injustice anywhere is a threat everywhere." He urged people to resist panic and instead pivot toward collective action, reinforcing that freedom is not merely an individual right but a shared responsibility.
The program began with Amiya Potts of New Life Community Methodist Church leading the audience in "Lift Every Voice and Sing," a hymn written by NAACP leader James Weldon Johnson in 1900. Washington College President Mike Sosulski welcomed attendees and paid tribute to the late Rev. Jethroe Moore II, a civil rights leader dedicated to youth advocacy. Sosulski called on the audience to reflect on the sacrifices made for freedom in 1860, 1960, and to envision what it must look like in 2060.
LaMonte Cooke, warden of Queen Anne's County's Department of Corrections and recipient of the Maryland Association of Counties' Service Award, read a proclamation on behalf of the Kent County Commissioners, officially declaring Jan. 20, 2025, as Martin Luther King Jr. Day.
The Chester River Voices, led by Assistant Director Stephanie LaMotte, performed the traditional African American spiritual "Soon-a-will Be Done," followed by Clare Harner's poem "Do Not Stand at My Grave and Weep." Washington College students also showcased their talents: Zhanglin You delivered a moving piano performance, while Ayanna-Jalen Harris captivated the audience with her rendition of Rihanna's "Lift Me Up."
A highlight of the event was the presentation of the Commissioner William W. Pickrum Service Award to Tilise Brown, a dedicated advocate for Kent County youth. Brown, the school counseling secretary at Kent County High School, also serves as the coordinator for the Achieving Academic Equity and Excellence for Black Boys Initiative, a former Kent County Spartans Cheer Commissioner, and the planner of the senior awards ceremony.
Kent County High School Principal Kris Hemstetter, who presented the award, praised Brown's transformative impact over the past seven years. "She is a powerful force for good, a mentor, guide, and relentless advocate for students," Hemstetter said.
Brown, moved by the honor, expressed gratitude to her mother, grandmother, daughter, and husband for their support. She reflected on her journey, recalling how an injury derailed her dream of cheering for the Baltimore Ravens. However, she found fulfillment in mentoring and leading young people in her community, demonstrating resilience in the face of setbacks.
"I will be forever grateful to be in this community," Brown said, closing with a King quote urging leaders to prioritize justice over wealth.
The celebration continued with a performance by the MLK Steppers, a group of youth girls who executed intricate cheer routines, including a step-up shoulder stand set to Beyoncé's "Crazy in Love."They were trained by Brown, LaToya Johnson, Nichole Blake and Taliyah Russell.
Next, a historically Black fraternity Omega Psi Phi, specifically the Psi Nu Nu Chapter, followed with a presentation of their Achievement Week honorees.
Before concluding, Tue rallied the audience to remain engaged. "Now is the time to stay in tune with local politics, galvanize, organize, strategize, and then execute," he said. "Let's not cower—let's be courageous, and we will get through it."

title: Water’s Edge Museum celebrates 4 years, kicks off Black History Month
author: Konner Metz
content:
Water’s Edge Museum celebrates 4 years, kicks off Black History Month

 February 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 502
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD — Surrounded by historic paintings, photos and maps, nearly 100 people packed the tight confines of the Water's Edge Museum Saturday to honor and celebrate Black history on the Eastern Shore.Talbot County's first African American museum celebrated its fourth anniversary in Oxford Saturday afternoon, along with kicking off Black History Month. The galleries around the museum tell the stories of Maryland's founding Black families.
Elinor Thompson, a member of the Maryland Commission on African American History and Culture, spoke in front of the large crowd. She emphasized the importance of passing down and preserving history.
"I'm so glad that we, as a community, this community, can come together and share some of this rich history that we can pass onto the next generation," said Thompson, a Kent Island native.
Kay Brown, co-director of Water's Edge Museum, thanked those who came out, including local leaders and community members. The crowd was welcomed by musician Leroy Potter and his group at the Maryland Spirituals Initiative.
During the anniversary celebration, the museum's team provided tours of the galleries, which dive into Oxford's Black history as well as that of the Eastern Shore. Brown said bringing the younger generations into the museum is a key goal moving forward.
"We need the seed planted," Brown said. "And we are enthusiastic with our team, and I cannot do this without my team."
During the event, Brown asked the Moaney family to stand, honoring the late Tissier Moaney, who died last month. She is described as a founding backbone of the museum's collection.
Jeffrey Moaney is a genealogical advisor for the museum and Tissier Moaney's grandson. He said his grandmother was friends with Water's Edge Museum Founder Barbara Paca for the last 15 years.
The two amassed a collection of work and history before the museum ever existed.
"It is my grandmother who helped make that connection between the historians of our family like myself and a couple of others to bring this collection to life," Jeffrey Moaney said. "And as an exhibition, as well as a book."
While giving a short presentation, Thompson asked attendees to sit down with their families to protect and explore family histories.
"We need to have generational sustainability for the next generation," Thompson said. "We need to put our gifts and talents back into our community. We need to start with our businesses and things like that."
Thompson asked parents to encourage their children to learn cursive writing, as most papers and documents she preserves are written in cursive. "We want to put those things back into our communities, back into our children," she said.
As Black History Month began Saturday, Brown said it's the perfect time for the community to "show off and show out" by commemorating its roots, just like the Water's Edge Museum has been doing for four years
"You all can make your own memories, make your own museum, in your own churches," Brown said. "We need to start pulling out our photos of grandparents, uncles and aunts, and preserve those photos. Our kids need to see what things look like."

title: Black History Month name change for Maryland county does not move forward
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com
content:
Black History Month name change for Maryland county does not move forward

 February 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 430
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Black History Month will remain Black History Month in Charles County.Commissioner Ralph E. Patterson II, a Democrat, last June sought to rename Black History Month — a recognition that was passed by Congress in 1986.
"The reason is, looking back at all the wonderful months we have where they celebrate all different heritages, February is the only month that has "history" in the name," Patterson said at the June 25, 2024, meeting of the commissioners.
He sought to rename the month to "African American Heritage Month," at least locally.
"Black History Month never got the same recognition that the other months have received," Patterson said at the time. "We have Asian American, Pacific Islander Heritage Month, Native American Heritage Month, Arab American Heritage Month, so on and so forth."
Now, the results of months of surveying are in, and a good number of Charles County residents were not on board with the name change.
A majority of the respondents to surveys were in the 45 to 54 age group and the 55 to 64 age group, which each contained just over 28% of participants.
Low engagement was received from residents ages 34 and under. Just over 2% of participants were in the 25 to 34 age group and just under 3% of participants were in the 18 to 24 age group.
Five meetings were conducted in person about the topic, with at least one in each county district.
In a summary presented Tuesday by Renesha Miles, the chief equity officer for the county, several key findings were summarized.
The majority of participants did not support the proposed name change, concerns were raised about how and why the name change was brought up and many participants felt that "Black History Month" is a more inclusive term, capturing the contributions and experiences of Black people from various backgrounds, including those from the Caribbean, Latin America and other regions outside of Africa.
Concerns echoed Commissioner Amanda Stewart's (D) comments when the topic first arose.
Stewart said last year, "Some folks identify as Black, some folks take offense when someone calls them African American. ... I respect everyone's position. I'm not offended if someone calls me Black, I'm not offended if someone calls me African American. I've heard people say, 'I'm not from Africa, so I'm not African American.'"
Some participants in favor of the change referenced the importance of recognizing history, heritage and present accomplishments related to African American culture.
"I know at this point, I'm not willing to move forward on this," Patterson said.
The commissioners settled with a consensus that the name change was not something to move forward with; no vote was conducted.

title: Talbot County diversity training, statement stir dialogue
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot County diversity training, statement stir dialogue

 February 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Life 
 
 657
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A resolution to repeal Talbot County's diversity statement elicited strong reactions from the community over the weekend.While the Talbot County Council had its Tuesday meeting canceled due to impending snow, the resolution requested by Council Member Dave Stepp caught the eyes of many residents and organizations when it appeared on the meeting agenda.
Tina Jones, chair of the Demarva Pride Center, said the organization's board discussed it Sunday. Jones said the center opposes a potential repeal of the diversity statement.
"One of the things that our government is supposed to be is representative of all people, and that includes people in marginalized communities," Jones said.
The resolution's title on the agenda states that it would repeal two 2020 resolutions "regarding diversity training and development of a Talbot County diversity statement, respectively."
The first 2020 resolution implemented an annual report of diversity training opportunities offered to staff. The second facilitated the creation of Talbot County's diversity statement, which is now found in its employee handbook.
The statement defines diversity, equity and inclusion, explains its purpose and details the county's approach to ensuring diversity. It also outlines how employees can report discrimination.
Stepp, who joined the council in 2022, confirmed to The Star Democrat that he is bringing forward the new resolution.
"I certainly think there's a lot of folks that are out there that are trying to make this something that it isn't," Stepp said in an interview. "It's all financial in nature."
In a letter written to residents Tuesday, Stepp stated the resolution's purpose is to keep Talbot County "in good standing with the federal agencies providing funds" to the county. He said it's not an attack against the county's diversity and inclusion.
Stepp's letter makes mention of President Donald Trump's Jan. 20 executive order to end all diversity, equity and inclusion policies and programs in the federal government.
"What this proposed resolution will do is protect the Talbot County taxpayer from potentially not receiving the millions of dollars Talbot County already receives annually from the Federal Government," Stepp wrote.
Former Talbot County Council President Corey Pack brought forth the initial resolutions in the summer of 2020. In an interview Tuesday, he said the diversity statement was meant to "memorialize" what the council was already doing regarding diversity, equity and inclusion in the workforce.
Pack hopes any attempt to repeal fails and said he's disappointed the council may be looking to remove the statement.
"Put your money where your mouth is," Pack said. "If this is what you are about as a governmental body, what's wrong with putting that in writing? If you are a governmental body that believes in diversity, that believes in inclusion, that believes in equality, what's the fear?"
County Council Vice President Pete Lesher was on the council when the two resolutions were passed in the summer of 2020. He said he hasn't noticed anything that would lead him to "try to attempt to remove them."
"I've gone back and read over the language of the diversity statement, and I can't imagine what in there anybody would find objectionable," Lesher said in an interview.
Lesher added that he's worried removing the diversity statement could hurt the recruitment and retention of county government staff.
"I don't know that somebody would come here on the basis of whether or not we have these statements," he said, "but the publicity of actually proactively removing such a statement might send a signal that some people aren't welcome here."
Before Tuesday's meeting was canceled, groups such as the Delmarva Pride Center and Talbot County Democratic Forum encouraged members to attend the meeting and speak against the proposal.
"Our community voices matter. Together we can defeat this transparent challenge to the Eastern Shore value of treating others with dignity and respect at all times," wrote Michele Dappert, forum president, in a newsletter Saturday. "The community must speak out to ensure this progress is not erased."
The proposed resolution is expected to be on the agenda for the Talbot County Council's next meeting on Tuesday, Feb. 25.

title: Cambridge Woman's Club hosts presentation about obtaining citizenship
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Cambridge Woman's Club hosts presentation about obtaining citizenship

 February 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 492
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Seeing herself as a voice for Federalsburg's Haitian community, Gelard Merilus Loulou attended the Cambridge Woman's Club Friday to gather helpful information that she can take back to Federalsburg.Friday afternoon, the club hosted Lindsay Waite, a retired attorney who currently volunteers at the Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center in Easton to help those who are applying for United States citizenship prepare.
Merilus Loulou said Federalsburg's Haitian community is "in crisis," with many fearful about what could happen in the county in the coming months when it comes to immigration.
With a new administration in the White House, there has been a push to crack down on illegal immigration, which has caused concern among migrants in the United States.
During her presentation, Waite spoke about the process for naturalization in the U.S. She explained that to gain citizenship, a person must file a Form N-400 application for naturalization, have their biometrics taken, pass a background check, pass the citizenship test and complete an interview with U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services. If the person is approved after these steps, they will need to take the Oath of Allegiance at a naturalization ceremony.
Waite said she believes the process costs about $800 to complete.
At the Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center, Waite and other volunteers help prepare those with green cards who want to obtain citizenship. She said volunteers help go over the Form N-400 application, review questions that could be on the test and practice reading and writing.
Waite said the citizenship test includes an English portion and also asks questions about democracy, the constitution, history and geography.
Offering some of the more difficult questions to the audience at the event, Waite said the people she works with come in for about 10 weeks to review questions and practice English.
"They learn a lot more than I think my nephew, who went to high school and college, could probably know," she said, causing people in the audience to laugh.
Claudia White-Cooke and Joyce Dowling, who attended Waite's presentation, said after hearing some of the questions on the test, they weren't sure if they'd be able to pass it. White-Cooke said the process to become a citizen seems complicated and the people who apply are really committed.
When one person at the event asked if the new presidential administration has affected the naturalization process at all, Waite — who said she is not an expert on what's happening at the national level — said she did notice a change in priority for legal entry into the U.S. from Venezuela.
"To a limit, a certain number of people from Venezuela were being given entry legally and now that's stopped," she said.
Waite said she believes the naturalization process in the U.S. will continue, however. She said people still want to be American citizens.
"And I and others will do what we can to help," she said.
Those who are interested in volunteering with the Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center or want to learn more can call 877-772-9832 or visit chesmrc.org.

title: Fearing ICE raids, Delmarva immigrants mostly stay home
author: PAUL KIEFER Capital News Service
content:
Fearing ICE raids, Delmarva immigrants mostly stay home

 February 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: PAUL KIEFER Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 1304
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GEORGETOWN, Delaware — Race Street, usually the busy commercial core of a Central American neighborhood, was deserted on a clear weekday evening.A man named Delmar sat in an otherwise empty restaurant, sipping a hot drink from a styrofoam cup. Unlike many of his neighbors, he told a visitor, he's not reacting prematurely to the possibility of immigration raids.
He's remaining hopeful, he said, but he's also prepared.
"El plan A es esperarse," he said. "El plan B es prepararse."
The region's key industries, Delmar added, should see the empty businesses on Race Street as a sign of oncoming trouble. Without undocumented immigrants like him, the Delmarva Peninsula's construction, agriculture and hospitality employers could face a critical labor shortage.
"What's going to happen to the workforce?" he asked in Spanish. "They need the value that immigrants provide."
Not all immigrants in Georgetown without legal status are as relaxed as Delmar.
As rumors of pending raids circulate through rural communities on the Delmarva Peninsula, places like Race Street have grown eerily quiet. The mere possibility that the Trump administration might follow through on its mass deportation plans is enough to have a chilling effect in rural towns where many immigrants feel especially visible.
Capital News Service is not using the last names of undocumented immigrants or those in the asylum process at their request, to protect their identities.
Drawn initially by the region's poultry industry and other agricultural work, thousands of immigrants from Latin America and the Caribbean settled in small towns and cities on the peninsula over the past five decades.
The peninsula remains a destination for new migrants. Since 2020, Wicomico County has received more new immigrants with cases in federal immigration court — including asylum seekers — per capita than any other county in Maryland, according to an immigration court case database maintained by the Department of Justice.
The same data indicates that both Wicomico County and Accomack County on Virginia's eastern shore received more post-2020 immigrants per capita than Los Angeles County.
Children and grandchildren of those immigrants now make up a large share of the student body at North Georgetown Elementary, which serves children from the neighborhood surrounding Race Street.
Jennifer Nein, a multi-language learning coordinator who works at the school, said her students are on edge.
"I've noticed a few kids who are a little bit quieter than they normally are," she said. "When I say, 'Are you alright,' they come right out and tell you, 'I'm just really scared. I'm scared that I'm going to go home and my parents are going to be gone.'"
Another student recounted panicking at the sound of someone knocking on the door of their home, Nein said, only to discover that the visitor was a family member.
Nein noted that while her school has yet to see attendance drop substantially, some families are planning for the worst-case scenario, including arranging powers of attorney and identifying family members or neighbors who could take their children in if they are deported.
Margarita, an immigrant from Mexico who works at a restaurant on Race Street, said she's watched families in her orbit prepare to take their U.S.-born children with them if they are forced to leave the country.
"Those who were born here and have immigrant parents — their parents are looking for ways to obtain passports and send their children to Guatemala," she said in Spanish.
Lina, a Guatemalan immigrant in Selbyville, a town twenty miles south of Georgetown on the Delaware-Maryland border, told CNS that she plans to take her two children with her if U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement ramps up its enforcement efforts on the peninsula.
"For me, it would be ideal to first see if they really do start arresting people around here," she said in Spanish. "Then I would leave with my daughters."
At least a few of her acquaintances, she added, decided to preemptively cut their losses and return to their home countries.
From behind the counter of a restaurant in Selbyville, Maria, an immigrant from Mexico, said that the same anxieties are straining businesses that rely on immigrant customers.
Since President Trump's inauguration last month, Maria said that the restaurant has seen few dine-in orders as worried regulars try to minimize the time they spend in public spaces. Some take-out customers, she added, insist that she check the parking lot for signs of immigration enforcement before they come to pick up their meals.
"When sales go down, work goes down," Maria said. While the restaurant usually requires two servers per shift, she worked a weekday lunch hour alone in late January. At that rate, she said, some businesses in small towns like Selbyville may not survive.
Those precautions aren't unique to undocumented immigrants.
"There are citizens here," said Jean-Frandy Philogene, the outreach and field coordinator with the Maryland office of a farmworker assistance nonprofit Comité de Apoyo a los Trabajadores Agrícolas, or CATA. "But even though they are [citizens], they are scared — some of them — because they don't know exactly how they're going to do the deportations."
Philogene said he's met naturalized citizens in the Salisbury area who, despite carrying proof of their citizenship, are still cutting back their non-essential visits to workplaces and businesses.
So far, he added, only a handful of the immigrant workers in his orbit have decided to avoid their workplaces.
But the Rev. Roosevelt Toussaint, president of the Haitian Development Center of Delmarva, thinks that may not last.
His organization serves thousands of Salisbury-area Haitian immigrants who entered the country after the Biden administration launched a "humanitarian parole" for immigrants from four countries, including Haiti, in January 2023. That program allowed parolees to live and work in the United States for two years.
The Biden administration later opted not to renew the legal status of immigrants who arrived through the program, and Trump formally ended the program by executive order on his first day in office. While those immigrants generally still have legal status, Toussaint said it's unclear whether the Trump administration will offer an alternative path for them to remain in the country.
"There's a fear among the business owners," he said, that Haitian workers might disappear if they are left in legal limbo. "So they are looking for options — what options are there for those employees to seek [legal status]?"
Tom Super, the senior vice president of communications for the National Chicken Council, told CNS that his industry has yet to see workforce impacts.
But Leila Borrero Krouse, an organizer in CATA's Maryland office, said it's unclear whether the migrant farmworkers who come to the peninsula in the summer to pick watermelons, tomatoes and other produce, will return this year.
Whispers about upcoming workplace raids have already begun to spread in Georgetown.
Lt. Joel Diaz, the city's deputy police chief, said his department received a flurry of calls about alleged ICE arrests at restaurants and other businesses last month, none of which proved accurate.
Early last week, however, ICE agents appeared in Georgetown to detain a fugitive, giving the police department advance notice of their arrival.
Diaz said the operation wasn't the first of its kind in Georgetown, but his department is now trying to dispel misinformation and calm the town's nerves.
"That initial blast is what makes folks uneasy," he said.
Immigration raids are nothing new on the Delmarva Peninsula. In 1996, federal immigration agents arrested more than 100 workers at two poultry processing plants on Maryland's Eastern Shore.
That era's raids prompted some Haitians to depart for Canada, Toussaint said, as did Trump's first term in office.
"Every time there's a change in the federal government, there's always a stir for people to move," he said.
Celsa, an immigrant from Mexico who came to Georgetown in the early 2000s, told CNS that while more recent arrivals might be alarmed by the Trump administration's rhetoric on immigration, she doesn't believe the next four years in Georgetown will be meaningfully different than the last two decades.
"Todo el tiempo ha sido lo mismo," she said. It's always been like this.

title: What does removing DEI statement say?
author: Staff Writer
content:
What does removing DEI statement say?

 February 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 370
 Words

 We understand that there is a move afoot to remove the diversity, equity and inclusion statement from the Talbot County Employee Handbook. We further understand that this may be done in a way that flies below the radar, without input — perhaps to push a political agenda without public scrutiny.First, we must say that we are strong supporters of the underlying concept of providing, enhancing and maintaining a diverse, equitable and inclusive community. We live our lives accordingly, and hope that each of you do, as well.
If the council were to remove the DEI statement from the county handbook, are you saying that you, the council and by extension, Talbot County and its citizens, do not agree with providing a supportive and equitable workplace? Are you saying that not all county employees are valued, but that some are and some aren't? Which are not, and why?
Are you saying that you reject a workplace that values respect, understanding and acceptance of all employees or just some? What could possibly have changed to make Talbot County less accepting, understanding and committed to fostering a safe and equitable workplace for all of our valuable county employees? This can only be the result of the current political climate that has demonized the concept of DEI far beyond what it actually is and the wonderful spirit with which the prior Talbot Council unanimously approved this statement.
Please do not let politics pollute and degrade the admirable traits contained in the statement, and let's continue to honor and respect all of our fellow citizens equally. We urge you to keep Talbot County great by keeping the diversity, equity and inclusion statement not only in the employee handbook, but in our hearts, minds and actions as a community.
Which of these things, specifically, are you no longer committed to, and why?
The county is committed to: (1) maintaining an inclusive, productive, supportive, open, innovative and equitable workplace environment in which every individual is valued for his or her unique characteristics; (2) fostering respect, understanding and acceptance of differences; and (3) enabling employees to reach their full potential, thus enhancing the relationships among ourselves and optimizing the quality of services to our residents and our fellow employees.

title: Fountain case sparked animosity between papers
author: JOSEPH KOPER
content:
Fountain case sparked animosity between papers

 February 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JOSEPH KOPER | Section: Columns 
 
 1200
 Words 

 Read News Document

 During the two-plus years of the contentious Isaiah Fountain case (1919-1921), Easton and Talbot County were rocked with many controversies and side stories that derived from the the original case. In April 1919, Isaiah Fountain — an African American — was accused of raping a local white girl. Fountain's case generated hundreds of news articles relating to his case resulting from: his two trials and convictions, multiple lynching attempts, two escapes and manhunts, armed infantry troops surrounding the Talbot County courthouse, questionable court decisions and his controversial execution.The general sentiment in conservative Talbot County was that Fountain was guilty of raping the white girl. Of course, during the Jim Crow era, any allegations of sexual or even suspicious social contact between a Black man and a white female were taken extremely seriously by the white population. During this period there were many locals who felt the need to to resort to the "Lynch Law." Similar sentiments were echoed — or even promoted — by the Easton Star-Democrat. Contrary viewpoints were quickly and passionately disputed by the paper. As with most local editors of the era, though, the Star-Democrat's Samuel E. Shannahan was determined to present Easton and Talbot County in the best light possible.
According to Norman Harrington's book, "Easton Album," Shannahan was the longtime editor of the Easton Star-Democrat. Harrington described Shannahan as: "chauvinistic, elevating the interests of Talbot County above all else." Shannahan was the ultimate local "booster" for Talbot County and didn't stand for any criticism about his home county.
Certainly, he didn't accept the implications of Lynch Law, Jim Crow, mob violence and racism that the events of Fountain case cast over Easton and Talbot County. He was determined to uphold the honor and reputation of his hometown, regardless of what "outside" publications printed.
The Baltimore newspapers (Sun, Evening Sun, News and Afro-American) viewed the Fountain case with a somewhat more balanced journalistic eye. They generally reported evidence that suggested that Isaiah Fountain was innocent of the rape charges.
The reporting of the "big city" newspapers infuriated editor Harrington, who took issue with just about everything the the Baltimore papers printed. When the Baltimore papers reported that a 2,000-person mob attempted to lynch Isaiah Fountain, the Easton weekly minimized the lynching attempt and blamed the "excitement," on people from other counties or troublemakers from Delaware.
Shannahan was furious that the Baltimore press would dare impugn the dignity of local citizens by reporting opposing accounts of events. A Star-Democrat editorial labeled the "big city" newsmen as "a mob of cub reporters" and called their reporting "not only unfair but disgusting." In another article the Star-Democrat used bold type to complain: "Of all the things to be resented, next to the crime itself, the absolute contempt for the truth, the utter barefaced lies published by the press of Baltimore city, is most to be condemned."
In short, there was very little that the Baltimore and Easton papers agreed upon regarding the Fountain case. This visceral journalistic animosity even extended beyond the matters of the Fountain case. For example — in an attempt to mend journalistic fences — the Baltimore News sent a reporter to Easton to write a sort of travelogue about the town. The News published the article on Sunday, Feb. 1, 1920, and the Star-Democrat reprinted the story a week later.
Surprisingly, the local press expressed dissatisfaction with the article and ignored its very positive depictions of Easton. A person reading the story today, would think that it was crafted by a public relations firm hired by the Easton Chamber of Commerce. Still the article's praise for Easton didn't matter to the local weekly. The paper continued its journalistic feud with the Baltimore News by it's headline for the story it reprinted on Feb. 7, 1920: "Says Easton is slow/Baltimore news man does not flatter Talbot's county seat in review in Sunday's issue/Says we pride ourselves on quality instead of quantity — sees us as serene and satisfied'
The Star-Democrat prefaced the News article with this statement: "Some of the story is good, some untrue, and none of it as good as Easton is entitled to." Today, a reader of the article would probably agree that Easton was as desirable a place to visit and live then as it is now.
The only comments that I could discern as being even remotely negative involved the "high cost of living" (i.e., the "two-bit" bus ride from the railroad station) and this statement: "... Easton, Talbot's lovely county seat, grows with that slowness that is akin to sureness. ..."
The article is chock full of complements, calling Easton: "Serene and satisfied" and "lovely." The article praises "the well-paved thoroughfares," "charming homes" and "ancient and worthy trees." The Baltimore News reporter wrote with awe about visiting The Old Friends Meeting House and described his visit to the nearby Wye House and its "wonderful old garden." He called the Wye House "one of the most beautiful and historical estates on the Eastern Shore."
Reading the Baltimore News review about Easton over a century later, I confess that I don't understand the Star-Democrat's stubborn viewpoint about the article being "untrue" or unkind to Easton. The apparently offending comment about Easton's "slowness that is akin to sureness", strikes me as a very positive comment.
The complaint about the "high cost of living" and the "two bits" it cost for transportation from the train station are hardly condemnations, but merely observations that many of us might make today about the economy. The Baltimore News reporter gushed with praise for Easton, describing it as: "this attractive town" "Easton gives constant pleasure to the artistic eye" and "well-groomed, well-bred, and unobtrusive."
The writer also portrayed the town as "lovely", and "the most pleasing of the larger cities of the Eastern Shore." The News reporter then described Easton as: "the Queen City of the glorious Eastern Shore of Maryland" and "richly endowed by nature as a manufacturing center and place of residence." The reporter praised the "well-paved" streets, "splendid sidewalks" and the sewerage system "of the most advanced type." The article even cited the town's "efficient lighting plant," and its plan to purchase a modern motor fire engine."
After reading the Star-Democrat's hyper-critical and fussy comments about the Baltimore News article, one must ask: "What's wrong about this gushing review of Easton?" The News article about Easton sure makes it seem like the kind of place one would like to visit or live. I think most readers would agree that the lovely town of Easton is still much the same as described in the newspaper article from over a century ago — except for the century-old vitriol shown for the "big city papers" and the comment about having to spend "two bits to ride in the omnibus."
With his stanch anti-Fountain editorial viewpoint and disdain for "big city" newspapers, Editor Samuel Shannahan remained fiercely devoted to his hometown and the Easton Star-Democrat. Under his editorship, in 1937 the Maryland Press Association named the Easton Star-Democrat as the best weekly newspaper in Maryland. Ever the newsman, Shannahan died on December 7, 1942, while working at his editor's desk — some 22 years after he declared the Isaiah Fountain case to be "... one of the most noted in the State's annals."

title: State, county leaders join Frederick Douglass descendants to unveil new plaque
author: Konner Metz
content:
State, county leaders join Frederick Douglass descendants to unveil new plaque

 February 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 482
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Exactly 130 years after Frederick Douglass' death, the Talbot County-born abolitionist and civil rights leader was honored for his lasting impact on freedom, equality and education.Descendants, county leaders and state transportation officials gathered to unveil a historical marker honoring Douglass at the Talbot County Courthouse Thursday morning. They were joined by Lt. Gov. Aruna Miller.
Miller spoke at the unveiling, noting that Douglass' calls for justice still demand answers to date. She pointed out the crucial role he played in advancing education for Black Americans during a time when it was not widely accepted.
"Frederick Douglass dared to see beyond the chains that bound him," Miller said. "He knew that true liberation was not just freedom of the body, but freedom of the mind."
The marker, one of nearly 800 official historical signs created by the Maryland Department of Transportation, will be placed at Tappers Corner Road and Route 303, just northeast of Cordova and near Douglass' birthplace.
Julie Schablitsky, cultural resources chief for the Maryland Department of Transportation, said after working with Douglass family descendants and community members, an addition was made to the text on the historical marker: Anna Murray.
Murray, Douglass' first wife, was "strong" and "loyal," Schablitsky said. Many speakers Thursday maintained that Murray's fight for equality and justice was just as important as Douglass'.
Schhablitsky noted Murray was crucial in Douglass' escape from slavery, sewing the sailor suit he used to disguise himself while fleeing north.
Kenneth Morris Jr., Douglass' great-great-great-grandson, called Murray an "equal partner" to her husband.
"It was Anna who made his escape possible," Morris said. "Her strength, sacrifice and unwavering support ensured that his journey to freedom was not just his alone, but part of a greater fight for justice that continues today. I'm just as proud of her as I am of him."
"Her story reminded me that during difficult and challenging times, we must rely on each other and sometimes risk our own safety for the ones we love," Scablitsky said.
Other local and state officials spoke during the event, including Department of Transportation Secretary Paul Wiedefeld, Talbot County Council President Chuck Callahan and Easton Mayor Megan Cook.
Edward "Boots" Robinson, president of the Frederick Douglass Honor Society, and Tarence Bailey, Douglass' five-time great nephew, provided words as well.
"No place is more important to mark his footsteps than where Frederick Douglass experienced his first taste of freedom while living with his grandparents, enjoying those few spiritful, joyful years," Robinson said.
Bailey said that when he was growing up in Easton, many of his elders didn't openly discuss the history of slavery in the area. Descendants of Harriet Tubman weren't allowed to talk about Tubman outside their houses, Bailey said.
The roadside marker will give the younger generations a chance to learn about that history and the local legacy of Douglass, Bailey said.
"We didn't have this," Bailey said. "So to be able to give it to the next generation is really special."

title: Talbot County’s United States Colored Troops fought with valor and honor
author: PAUL W. CALLAHAN Talbot County Historical Society
content:
Talbot County’s United States Colored Troops fought with valor and honor

 February 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: PAUL W. CALLAHAN Talbot County Historical Society | Section: Local News 
 
 566
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Though President Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation, issued on Jan. 1, 1863, did not free the enslaved people in Maryland, it allowed African Americans throughout the nation to serve in the Union Army as part of the United States Colored Troops. This gave Black Americans the opportunity to fight not only for their nation, but also for their freedom and citizenship — and fight they did.Frederick Douglass, a native son of Talbot County and a leading African American abolitionist, writer, orator and newspaper publisher, placed steady pressure on the Lincoln administration to include African Americans in the Union Army. Douglass met with the president, used his influence to the fullest, and has received great credit towards the creation and support of the United States Colored Troops.
During the Civil War, nearly 180,000 African Americans served in the Union Army, with almost 80,000 recruited from states that remained in the Union. Of this number, 8,718 were from Maryland. Talbot County led all Maryland counties in total enlistments.
By the start of the war, African Americans in Talbot County were nearly equally divided, with half enslaved and half free. Many enslaved individuals from Talbot earned their freedom by enlisting in the United States Colored Troops.
The Civil War saw the first draft in U.S. history to enroll men for battle. There were four draft rounds during the war, but Talbot County was only subjected to the first. The enlistment of Talbot's African Americans counted toward the county's quota of men required for the Union Army. Because so many Black men enlisted, no white men from Talbot were drafted after the first round.
Many senior Union commanders voiced skepticism about how African Americans would perform in battle and questioned their willingness to fight. Many formerly enslaved men had little experience with firearms and could neither read nor write, as they were often prohibited from learning. Time and time again, Black soldiers proved their mettle in combat, exhibiting great valor, courage and a ferocious fighting spirit.
Men from Talbot County served in every United States Colored Troops regiment formed in Maryland and in the United States Navy. They participated in major battles in Virginia, North Carolina and South Carolina in 1864 and 1865, including the battles to capture Petersburg and Richmond.
Talbot County soldiers were also involved in the final battles leading to the defeat of General Robert E. Lee's army and were present when Lee surrendered at Appomattox Courthouse.
This May, the Talbot Historical Society, located in downtown Easton, will present an exhibit titled "With Valor and Honor — Talbot County's United States Colored Troops During the Civil War."
This exhibit will feature numerous images and artifacts that tell the story of the courage, honor and valor displayed by these men.
"They served their nation at a time when many Black people in the Union states were still enslaved, and those who were free had no rights of citizenship," the Historical Society said in a press release. "Our staff has been working diligently to research this history and, most importantly, to identify the names of the men who served. To date, we have uncovered the names of over 550 men from Talbot County who served in the Union's United States Colored Troops — and we are still discovering more."
During this exhibit, the Talbot Historical Society will have these men's military records available so those who are interested, including these men's descendants, can have direct access to this rich history.

title: Talbot council tables vote on diversity statement as residents push back
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot council tables vote on diversity statement as residents push back

 February 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: News 
 
 553
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot County Council chambers filled to the brim for Tuesday's meeting, with many of the more than 100 attendees there to oppose a potential removal of the county's diversity statement.On the meeting's agenda was a resolution to remove the statement from the employee handbook. Proposed by Council Member Dave Stepp, the resolution would repeal two 2020 resolutions — one that developed the diversity statement and another that implemented an annual report of diversity training offered to staff.
Stepp's resolution was tabled and will be on the council's March 11 meeting agenda. However, its chances to pass appear slim, as a majority of the council — Council Vice President Pete Lesher and Council Members Keasha Haythe and Lynn Mielke — indicated their opposition to the resolution Tuesday.
Mielke said she was "surprised" by the resolution and doesn't believe there are reasons to remove the diversity statement.
"It's just a statement of who we are, what we recognize," Mielke said, receiving loud applause from the public. "I see no reason to withdraw this."
Stepp stated his requested resolution would keep Talbot County in good standing with the federal government and agencies that fund the county. He made mention of President Donald Trump's Jan. 20 executive order to end all diversity, equity and inclusion policies and programs in the federal government.
Stepp said he spoke to county employees and all of them supported the statement's removal.
"All of our county employees that I spoke with were kind. They're hard working and fully supportive of repealing these policies," he said. "I heard from a grand total of zero county employees that requested to keep these DEI policies in place."
During a lengthy public comment section, nearly all residents who spoke regarding Stepp's resolution did so unfavorably. That resident opposition was voiced in the chambers throughout the meeting and earlier in the day, too.
More than an hour before the meeting's onset, many gathered outside the courthouse holding signs opposing a potential repeal.
Gloria McVeigh said removing the county's diversity statement would be a setback.
"We really need our leadership at every level of government to stand for the principles that make us America," McVeigh said. "And diversity, equity and inclusion, that's what that is. Everybody is part of this country, everybody has something to contribute."
Mary Pellicano held a sign reading "DEI = DEMOCRACY" and expressed worry for if the county acts in an "anticipatory" manner to comply with executive orders.
"When people just capitulate before things are tested, that's the demise of our democracy," Pellicano said. "So I really feel like people need to speak up, come out, show up, state their concerns and understand what this means for our country and democracy."
Easton resident Steve Parks, who attended Tuesday's meeting with his wife, Elizabeth, said the entire discussion surrounding DEI feels political. He pushed back against the idea that diversity initiatives are simply apart of a "woke" movement.
"What it means is to be awake to injustice in the world," Parks said. "What's wrong with that?"
McVeigh said if the council weakens its commitment to diversity, the wrong message is sent to the people of Talbot County.
"We're actually looking at the safety of employees who can be labeled DEI hires and their families," McVeigh said. "We can't pretend that that's not what's at stake here. So I am pleading to them to do the right thing."
