title: Rooted Wisdom partners with Bloomberg for guided history walk at Adkins Arboretum
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Rooted Wisdom partners with Bloomberg for guided history walk at Adkins Arboretum

 February 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 694
 Words 

 Read News Document

 RIDGELY — Adkins Arboretum and Beech Works are have been collaborating on the Rooted Wisdom Podcast for months. Now, they are working together on a similar project, but with a twist — Rooted Wisdom Walks.Rooted Wisdom Walks consists of audio walking guides for three trails at the arboretum. For listeners of the podcast, the voice sharing history along the 45-minute to hourlong walks will sound familiar.
Rooted Wisdom Walks historian Anthony Cohen guides the listeners through the trails.
According to Rooted Wisdoms producers, Adkins Arboretum best shows natures' role in the Underground Railroad through its diverse landscape.
"Adkins is one of the few places where you can go and see examples from these narratives of the landscape in one place," George Burroughs, one of Rooted Wisdom Walks producers, said.
"It leverages Adkins as a place to come and try to understand and put yourself in the footsteps of a freedom seeker by observing what they might have observed."
Rooted Wisdom Walks offers a digital guide from Beech Works with technology supplied by the Bloomberg Philanthropies Connects app for mobile devices.
"We were looking for an app ... and what would work best for it," Burroughs said. "There is not WiFi on a 400-acre forest. That's another issue. So we came across Bloomberg Philanthropies, and they developed this app, this platform for it, and it's downloadable."
Another big component of choosing the Bloomberg app is the ability to add pictures and videos to the audio, producers said.
"The key to with the Bloomberg Connects digital guide is that it's a multimedia platform. Like, we can put video in there," Burroughs said. "We didn't do it for this one, but we put photographs that were taken by us and Adkins staff to help listeners identify what's being discussed."
Cohen travels with listens and stops at certain points in the trail to give a little background on what the listener is seeing at the park. But the recordings also give the listener some points of independence with the walk as well.
"There are times where there's something that matches that they're talking about specifically," Lauren Giordano, one of Rooted Wisdom Walks' producers, said. "So visitors are prompted to walk to that space and then listen to the conversation there, and then the next stop there.
"They're walking and listening to the next segment of the conversation. So there are times where it's really kind of self-guided, but there's also a choice from the participant, where you can take more time at a spot for reflection."
Cohen believes that time gives listeners a chance to reflect on different wayfinding tactics that were used during the Underground Railroad.
"The probably far too simply put story of the Underground Railroad, or part of it, is the story of wayfinding," Cohen said. "How do you get from point A to point Z and what propelled you along that journey?"
Adkins Arboretum helps tracks attendance via their map box and general attendance at the park each year.
Ginna Tiernan, executive director at Adkins, expects the arboretum will see an uptick in visitors with the new guided walks.
"We have a visitor center here. We have a map box outside that they could use," said Ginna Tiernan, executive director at Adkins. "Of course we have a big, beautiful sign as well. Bloomberg did a fantastic job in allowing the producers to find just the right sign makers, and Lauren Giordano (producer) did all the graphics, fabulous icons that show you the way, what trail to take."
With Rooted Wisdom Walks, listeners don't have to be at the park to experience the audio. They can also just listen at home.
The producers credit Cohen's creativity and knowledge of history to making to audio captivating.
"You have people that know the history, and it's very hard to find people that can help you experience it a bit and get you connected to it," Burroughs said. "But what Tony does so well is the connective tissue in between that someone needs to be conduit and facilitate, and that's what Tony does best.
"That's the experiential history part, we haven't been on anything else around any other subject, where someone performs the work that Tony does, and they and provides that unique perspective that he does."

title: Amid a split council and public outcry, vote on Talbot County DEI statement lingers
author: Konner Metz
content:
Amid a split council and public outcry, vote on Talbot County DEI statement lingers

 February 27, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 856
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A resolution to repeal Talbot County's diversity statement was left unsettled following a heated and impassioned Talbot County Council meeting Tuesday.Council Member Dave Stepp, the resolution's sponsor, received criticism from many of the more than 100 residents who attended the meeting. Despite the pushback, he's not changing his tune on the measure.
"I'm the one who sponsored it, and I'm sticking to it," Stepp said in an interview after the meeting.
His proposed resolution — tabled until the council's March 11 meeting — would repeal two 2020 resolutions. The first developed the county's diversity statement, while the other implemented an annual report of diversity training offered to staff.
Keasha Haythe, the council's only non-white member, said in an interview that she was disappointed the resolution wasn't voted down Tuesday.
"I feel like I'm diversity, equity and inclusion," Haythe said. "Being the African American female on the council, I just feel like we can certainly get past this and continue to support the employees and the community."
The resolution's chances to pass appear slim, as Haythe, Council Vice President Pete Lesher and council member Lynn Mielke all indicated their opposition.
"Repealing this statement, which contains nothing that could be construed as objectionable, could have a negative impact on those efforts to retract and retain the best and most qualified workforce we can have in this county," Lesher said at the meeting.
While offering his reasoning to repeal the diversity statement, Stepp made mention of President Donald Trump's Jan. 20 executive order to end all diversity, equity and inclusion policies and programs in the federal government.
He said removing the statement will protect Talbot County's federal funding. Mielke disagreed, adding that Trump's executive order hasn't gone through the legal process yet. Some provisions of the measure have been blocked by a federal court.
Stepp said Talbot County's diversity, equity and inclusion initiatives are failing. He noted that the percentage of Black and African American employees in the county government has dropped from 17.5% in 2020 to 15.8% this year.
"It's time we, as Talbot County, the employer, stop letting a politicized DEI product get in the way of true and real unity that is displayed daily in all of Talbot County," Stepp said.
VOTE DELAYEDAfter initial discussion on the resolution, Haythe asked that the council table a vote until the council heard public comment and allowed the legal process to play out regarding Trump's executive order.
Haythe, Stepp and Council President Chuck Callahan voted in favor of tabling, while Lesher and Mielke opposed.
Throughout the meeting, some residents called for the vote to not be delayed to a future meeting. County Attorney Patrick Thomas told the council that since the resolution was tabled, it could not be voted on Tuesday unless at least four council members voted to suspend normal procedures and revisit the resolution.
Following public comment, Haythe moved for procedures to be suspended in hopes of holding the vote. Lesher and Mielke joined her, but Stepp and Callahan voted no, meaning the required supermajority wasn't secured.
Some residents in the chamber voiced displeasure with Stepp and Callahan, shouting, "shame." One person said, "we will be back." Callahan said the resolution will reappear at a March 11 meeting.
In an interview, Haythe said her intention when first tabling the resolution was to hear public comment and then vote. She said there was "a little bit of miscommunication in regards to bringing it back up and being able to vote and get it done with tonight."
"I think the public wanted to certainly have it done tonight," Haythe said. "But March 11, and we'll get it done. We'll get it done."
PUBLIC OUTCRYMembers of the public filled the council chambers during Tuesday's meeting, overflowing into the hallway and outdoor courtyard. Many held signs opposing DEI rollbacks.
Resident Gloria McVeigh stood in the back corner of the council's meeting room holding a sign that read "SUPPORT DIVERSITY." At one point, Callahan asked her to put the sign down.
"That's not the way (clerk Susan Moran) explained it to me," McVeigh said. "She said as long as we're not blocking anybody's view."
"The protocol is what I'm telling you. No signs," Callahan said. He then said she could stand outside the meeting room door and display the sign through the window.
"That's not the protocol," McVeigh said, shortly before Callahan acquiesced.
During public comment, nearly all who spoke pushed back against Stepp's proposed resolution. Resident Maegan White expressed feelings of fear.
"As a queer woman who lives on the Eastern Shore and lives in this community, I'm scared," White said. " … What I'm being greeted with is disrespect, rejection, exclusion."
Talbot County NAACP President Richard Potter spoke to the importance of diversity, equity and inclusion, adding that "if anything, we need to put more teeth to this statement."
"The significance of DEI lies in the ability to drive innovation, enhance decision making and improve organizational performance by bringing together diverse voices and experiences," Potter said.
Tina Jones, chair of the Delmarva Pride Center, provided comment on her own behalf. Jones, a transgender woman, said lives are at stake.
"When you say DEI doesn't matter, it says to other folks, it's fair game on these people now," Jones said. "And it's time to stop it."

title: Immigrants are essential and deserve our respect
author: RICK HUGHES
content:
Immigrants are essential and deserve our respect

 March 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: RICK HUGHES | Section: Columns 
 
 590
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In this highly divisive time, it's safe to say that every American agrees that there should be immigration laws. However, opinions mainly differ in what the end goals are and how they're to be accomplished: deporting the undocumented, providing pathways to legal status, amnesty, Dreamers, birth-right citizenship and so on.The Trump administration appears to be painting all non-US citizens (immigrants with Green Cards, Temporary Protective Status, asylees and the undocumented) with the same broad brush by often referring to them as if they were all insane, criminals, gang members or rapists and here to cause trouble. That is not the case, and it is most certainly politically, if not racially, motivated.
The U.S. economy and our comfortable way of life depends on immigration and these hard-working people and their money. Those entering the country with a non-immigrant visa are under extremely strict guidelines and working conditions and are entirely dependent on the business sponsoring the visa. They can only enter the country under the terms of the visa agreement and must depart the moment the visa ends.
There is no limit on seasonal H2A agricultural visas because we critically rely on the workers. We need these people to have food on our tables. The H2B non-agricultural temporary worker visa program met its annual statutory limit by Jan. 7, and Homeland Security nearly doubled the cap from 66,000 to more the 130,000 just to meet the need for people to do the jobs that couldn't be filled by "ready, able and qualified American workers." On the Eastern Shore, large numbers of people are needed to "pick crabs" and without them an entire industry would be at grave risk.
My fear is that the ultra-MAGA rhetoric that blasts from the White House on a near daily basis is dehumanizing all non-US citizens and creating an us-versus-them paradigm that will desensitize the public to inhumane treatment of these people. Yes, some undocumented people live here, most are contributing members of our society, and many have spouses and children who are, in fact, U.S. citizens.
They pay taxes and rent and shop in local stores and are in every way a member of our society except for a piece of paper. These undocumented immigrants need a commonsense path to citizenship. They are here to realize the American dream of life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness. Many had to flee their homeland under threat of violence and death. They are here and contributing more than they are taking.
At the very least, in this supposedly law-abiding country, every person should be granted the opportunity for legal representation and shouldn't be subjected to the threat of arrest, having their families ripped apart, being whisked away to unknown and perhaps foreign detention centers with no warning and deported without formal charges, opportunity for due process or even evidence. The America that I respect and honor protects the poor, the rich, the citizen and non-citizen.
Since so many reduce everything to dollars and cents, you also should know that according to the comptroller of Maryland's State of the Economy Series: Immigration and the Economy, released in April 2024, "The American Immigration Council estimates that in 2021 Maryland's combined population of immigrants paid $13.3 billion in federal, state, and local taxes and had total spending power of $33.1 billion."
And this doesn't include the huge financial contributions of workers with non-immigrant visas. These people are our neighbors, our friends and coworkers, and we need them. They deserve our respect and appreciation for doing hard work, doing it well and often being overlooked and unappreciated.

title: Harriet Tubman Museum responds to NPS website changes
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Harriet Tubman Museum responds to NPS website changes

 April 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 372
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Following the removal and restoration of Harriet Tubman content from the National Park Service's webpage about the Underground Railroad, the Harriet Tubman Museum and Educational Center in Cambridge has vowed it will not change or reframe anything about Tubman at its center."Under no circumstances will we modify, reframe or change any facet of her life or history as the greatest conductor of the Underground Railroad," the center's Director of Events and Programs Linda Harris said in a statement.
Harris said the Harriet Tubman Museum and Educational Center "proudly" promotes Tubman's legacy.
"Her courage, valor, determination and faith exemplify the very essence and pursuit for living free and contributing to the healing and wellness of this country," Harris said.
In February, the National Park Service webpage titled "What is the Underground Railroad?" was altered. According to the Associated Press, changes to the webpage included the removal of a photo of Tubman from the top of the page and text edits that removed references to slavery and changed descriptions.
The changes to the site came amid the efforts to remove diversity, equity and inclusion policies in the federal government.
Last week, it was announced that changes to the webpage had been reversed.
According to the Associated Press, a National Park Service spokesperson said the changes were made without approval. The spokesperson said the agency celebrates Tubman.
In her statement, Harris said she is "saddened" to know the current administration "is making a concerted effort to rewrite and erase history."
Harriet Tubman, an abolitionist and social activist who was born into and escaped from slavery in Dorchester County in the 19th century, became well known for her work on the Underground Railroad, a network of routes and safe houses that helped slaves escape to their freedom. At the Harriet Tubman Museum and Educational Center in Cambridge, visitors can learn about the legacies of Tubman and other influential African Americans from the Eastern Shore.
Harris said that along with Tubman's legacy, the center will never forget Frederick Douglass, William Still and others who "documented and informed the nation of the atrocities of slavery."
"Tributes shall be given to freedom seekers, abolitionists and the many who endured and fought to end slavery in America!" Harris said. "We are evermore emboldened to tell their stories."

title: An age in America comes to an end
author: BILL PEAK Talbot County Free Library
content:
An age in America comes to an end

 May 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BILL PEAK Talbot County Free Library | Section: Columns 
 
 890
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The small town of Oroville, California, drifted into the 20th century as a shadow of its former self.Back in 1848, when gold was discovered in the area, prospectors had poured into the place. But by 1900 the vein had long since petered out, and the town had become little more than an agricultural backwater.
Meanwhile, the modern world marched on. In Los Angeles, California's first movie theater opened for business in 1902. The next year, the Wright brothers made the first heavier-than air flight at Kitty Hawk. And in 1908, Henry Ford brought the automobile within reach of everyday Americans when he introduced the reliable, relatively inexpensive Model T.
Still, news of these wonders would have arrived in Oroville as little more than rumors of a wider, more sophisticated world.
Then, on Aug. 29, 1911, a teenaged layabout named Floyd Hefner strode into the corral of the local slaughterhouse, intending to hitch up a team of horses, and found a nearly naked man leaning unsteadily against a fence-post. The last living member of a Native American tribe had come in from the cold.
Perhaps not surprisingly for the time and place, guns were drawn, dogs were held at bay, and someone used the telephone in the slaughterhouse to call the law. By the time the sheriff arrived, a butcher's cloak had been thrown over the shoulders of the man, who spoke no language anyone understood. The sheriff handcuffed the man, drove him into town in a wagon (the first time in his life he'd ever ridden in a wheeled vehicle), and locked him up in the county jail.
It wasn't long before newspapers throughout the state were reporting the discovery of America's "last wild Indian." Learning of the news, Alfred Kroeber, a renowned professor of anthropology at the University of California, Berkeley, sent a colleague, Thomas Waterman, up to Oroville.
Meeting with the prisoner in his cell, Waterman thought he might be speaking a language related to the Yana tongue. Waterman knew a little Yana, and when he tried it out on the prisoner, the man's face lit up.
For the first time since the only other members of his Yahi band had died, he had heard another human being speak a word or two he understood.
Waterman was able to ask the man his name. Using a combination of gestures and simple Yahi, the man explained that in his culture it was taboo to speak his name aloud to someone else until another member of his tribe had formally introduced him. As this was now impossible, Waterman ended up simply calling him "Man" in the Yahi tongue.
And so it is that this Native American man comes down to us in history under the false name of "Ishi." We will never know what his real name was.
Waterman's fellow professor at Berkeley, Alfred Kroeber, was a remarkable man. He had earned his doctorate in 1901 from Columbia University, studying under Franz Boaz, the father of modern anthropology. Kroeber took Ishi in and gave him a place to live in the university's museum, where Ishi worked as a janitor. This allowed Kroeber and the other anthropologists in his department to study Ishi closely over the remaining five years of his life.
You might expect that much of what Kroeber and Waterman learned from Ishi would have been horrifying. This was a man who, from boyhood, watched his tribe and immediate family whittled down by ceaseless slaughter. Norman Kingsley, an eager participant in one of the last massacres, later recounted that, in the middle of his attack, he exchanged his .56 caliber Spencer rifle for a .38 caliber pistol, because the rifle "tore them up so bad," especially the babies.
But after his introduction into modernizing California, accounts say Ishi didn't speak of the horrors he'd witnessed, nor did he give in to melancholy or despair. He adapted with grace to his new life and embraced many of the changes happening in the world around him.
I learned of Ishi from Alfred Kroeber's wife and fellow anthropologist Theodora Kracaw Kroeber, who, in 1961, wrote "Ishi in Two Worlds," now considered a classic of modern anthropology. I first read the book 40 years ago, and rereading it recently, I found myself placing Theodora Kroeber in the same league as Claude Lévi-Strauss. Without ever leaving any of her anthropological principles behind, she consistently writes clear, compelling prose.
It isn't easy reading the first part of Kroeber's book, watching as Ishi and the remaining members of his band are forced to withdraw further and further from the whites encroaching upon their world; until, finally, they retreat into that world's last untouched cañon, and, ultimately, its last bushy slopes.
But Kroeber's description of the way Ishi handles the world he is then brought into, the way he maintains his Yahi dignity in the face of that world's awesome power (while never losing his ability to see through its sometimes absurd idiosyncrasies) is somehow reassuring. It gave me hope for humanity at large.
I reread "Ishi in Two Worlds" thanks to an Inter-Library Loan, but a copy of the book has now been placed in our collection at the Talbot County Free Library. You'll find it in the Easton library on the Biography shelves under the call letters ISHI. If you're in St. Michaels, you can place a reserve on the book and it will be sent down there for you.

title: Plaque honors hundreds of Black Civil War soldiers from Queen Anne's County
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Plaque honors hundreds of Black Civil War soldiers from Queen Anne's County

 May 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 510
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A new memorial plaque at the Kennard African American Cultural Heritage Center in Centreville recognizes approximately 435 Black soldiers from Queen Anne's County who fought for the Union Army during the Civil War, filling a gap in local history and honoring their profound impact on the community. Local veterans and residents gathered April 28 to dedicate the monument to these long-overlooked heroes.The soldiers served in the United States Colored Troops, which consisted of free and enslaved African Americans who fought for the Union during the Civil War. Queen Anne's County has identified about 435 men from across the county who served in these units, according to local historian Chris Pupke.
Maryland contributed more than 8,000 men to the United States Colored Troops, and by the end of the war, Black soldiers represented about 10% of the Union force, he said.
Queen Anne's County soldiers predominantly served in the 19th, 39th and 7th regiments, and participated in battles and sieges instrumental to turning the tide of the war and shaping the history of the divided nation, he said.
"These men, these heroes, fought, bled and died for this country and we are grateful," Pupke said.
Following the war, these men started schools, built churches, searched for loved ones sold into slavery, and helped create the community known today, he said.
"Too often today their stories remain missing from our history books, from our community conversations, and from family histories," Pupke said.
While more work is necessary to continually recognize the tremendous sacrifices made for freedom, "today we celebrate these heroes, their bravery and sacrifices, accomplishments and contributions to our community," he said.
An initiative more than a year in the making, members of the Centreville Veterans Information Committee as well as local artists, masons, community members and county commissioners helped bring the project to fruition.
Kennard African American Cultural Heritage Center Executive Director Tara Coursey noted it was incredible to recognize the legacies of county Civil War soldiers.
Kennard stands as the repository of African American history in the county, so it is only fitting the plaque found a home there, she said.
Performing a dedication prayer, Deacon Frank Hessen of St. Christopher's said, "With courage born of hope they marched from this very soil answering the call to defend the dignity of all people and forge a nation united in liberty. Their sacrifice, steadfastness, and unwavering resolve inspire us still, reminding us of the cost of freedom and the power of unity in the face of adversity."
Committee member Robert Simms teared up at the performance of taps dedicating the plaque. As a Vietnam-era veteran, Simms understood the loss of friends to war as well as a lack of recognition upon returning home.
Noting the plaque's meaningfulness to him and others, "It's been a pleasure to be part of this group," Simms said.
The Centreville Veterans Information Committee looks forward to the eventual installation of a 6-foot statue to further honor Queen Anne's County United States Colored Troops.
The committee's Veterans Coffee House welcomes veterans supporting veterans community and conversations every Monday at the American Legion Jeff Davis Post 18 at 11 a.m.

title: Tubman's service did not end with the Underground Railroad
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Tubman's service did not end with the Underground Railroad

 May 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: News 
 
 564
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DORCHESTER COUNTY — Harriet Tubman escaped slavery and became a conductor of the Underground Railroad, leading around 13 missions to free over 70 enslaved individuals around Maryland before the Civil War, but her work didn't stop there.During the war, Tubman was a nurse, Union spy, scout and cook, which prompted the Maryland National Guard to posthumously commission her as a one star general at the American Legion Dorchester Post 91 in Cambridge last year.
Tubman began her service in 1862, when she aided sick and injured Black Union soldiers and newly freed slaves in South Carolina. "And she did it with a massive bounty on her head," said National Underground Railroad Network to Freedom member Bob Nelson.
She managed to evade capture all while operating as an agent for the Union Army.
"Getting into the byways, where she traveled with the enslaved people that she held free, you really get a sense of how rough it was, how remote it was, how terrifying it was at night. And thus the incredible bravery of these people," said Nelson. "And again, in Harriet's case, the bravery to go back into that over and over again. And then go to South Carolina and help with the war."
Two years into the war, under the command of Union Colonel James Montgomery, Tubman became the first female to lead an armed military operation, one that many have called her most extraordinary accomplishment. During the Combahee River Raid, Tubman, Montgomery and 150 Black Union soldiers rescued more than 750 slaves.
The success of the raid is owed to Tubman's intelligence gathering. Tubman learned from those she helped free where the Confederacy hid torpedoes along the river and the proper routes to rescue people.
Alongside freeing over 750 enslaved individuals, Union troops came on shore as slaves boarded the military vessels to destroy influential estates along the river. By the time Confederate forces learned what was happening, most of the damage was done.
Honoring Tubman
To honor Tubman and those she fought alongside this Memorial Day, founder of the Menare Foundation Tony Cohen suggests learning more about her story.
"There is a new book called 'Combee,' which is one of the Pulitzer Prize Winners, and it's about her service to the Union Army in South Carolina," Cohen said.
Cohen is intimately familiar with Tubman's story, having followed in her footsteps in 1996.
"I walked from Montgomery County, Maryland to Canada along the route of the Underground Railroad. And so I walked 10 to 25 miles a day for about seven weeks. I stopped in all the towns along the way asking people what they knew about the Underground Railroad, sought out documentation and historical societies, and museums. I spoke with descendants of those folks who made the journey and those who helped them along the way. And I even stayed in people's houses every night, some of them being stops on the Underground Railroad," Cohen said.
Cohen is planning on commemorating the 30-year anniversary of his journey by doing it again. He wants to bring the story of the Underground Railroad to a new generation while bring attention to our National Parks on the nations 125th anniversary.
"She experienced some of the most harrowing aspects of the slavery system, but her legacy is about pushing through and transcending those situations to bring about change. And I think that's the legacy that folks on the Eastern Shore can be very proud of," said Cohen.

title: Turning back the clock? Five years after George Floyd’s death, race in America faces Trump-driven changes and crossroads
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media
content:
Turning back the clock? Five years after George Floyd’s death, race in America faces Trump-driven changes and crossroads

 May 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media | Section: National 
 
 1397
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In the aftermath of the killing of George Floyd in May 2020, Irving Joyner and Rob Carpenter saw some signs of change when it came to race relations in America.Police agencies were pressed for more transparency and greater ability to charge officers accused of wrongdoing. Major employers, federal agencies, universities and progressive communities launched diversity and inclusion initiatives.
Five years after Floyd's death and ensuing protests and unrest, Joyner, a law professor at North Carolina Central University, is less optimistic.
"Now the opposite is occurring," Joyner said. "There is a retrenchment."
He points to efforts by the Trump administration and other conservatives to dismantle diversity, equity and inclusion programs and affirmative action hiring requirements, the directions of policies related to immigration and refugees and rollbacks of legal oversight sought by the Biden administration with the Minneapolis and Louisville police departments after the killings of Floyd and Breonna Taylor in 2020.
"The playbook seems to be pretty clear. There is an effort to undermine all the racial progress," Joyner said, contending DEI programs criticized by conservatives aim to be pathways to seeing the benefits of a pluralistic society.
"We see the parallels and the perils," Joyner said of the current landscape and America's history with race.
'PROTECTING COMMUNiTIES' Since returning to power in January, President Donald Trump has shut down DEI programs (including in the U.S. military) and affirmative action hiring requirements for federal agencies and contractors.
Trump argues for a "merit-based society" and conservatives say DEI and affirmative action policies disadvantage white people and continue to classify people along racial lines.
The U.S. Justice Department on May 21 said that it is dismissing federal lawsuits and proposed consent decrees with police in Minneapolis and Louisville in response to the Floyd and Taylor incidents.
"Overbroad police consent decrees divest local control of policing from communities where it belongs, turning that power over to unelected and unaccountable bureaucrats, often with an anti-police agenda," said Assistant U.S. Attorney General Harmeet Dhillon of the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division.
Dhillon said the moves aim to end the Biden administration's "failed experiment of handcuffing local leaders and police departments."
A White House spokesperson said Trump is focused on safety and prosperity "for all Americans" and empowering law enforcement.
"President Trump is tirelessly enacting policies to ensure America's safety, prosperity, and success for all Americans. Through his Make America Safe Again agenda, the Trump Administration is committed to stopping crime, upholding justice, protecting communities, and empowering federal, state, and local law enforcement," said White House spokesperson Harrison Fields.
The White House said the president is not considering a pardon of Derek Chauvin, the Minneapolis police officer convicted of killing Floyd in May 2020.
Trump has pressed the District of Columbia to remove Black Lives Matter street murals near the White House and wants to restore names of military bases that bore the names of Confederate generals.
Joyner and Carpenter, an author and communications professor at the University of California, Los Angeles, feel undercurrents to Trump's rhetoric and agendas.
They see cultural and racial undertones to Trump's hard lines on immigration (including his efforts to end birthright citizenship), his nostalgia for a "Golden Age" of America and his administration's cuts to foreign aid and refugee programs for developing countries while launching a new one for white Afrikaner farmers from South Africa.
"Trump is perceived as turning back the clock," Carpenter said.
'HUMAN NATURE'S SCRIPT'Carpenter sees societal swings after Floyd's death went viral on social media, highlighting police misconduct and America's complicated history of racial and social inequities.
"I do think there has been some progress," Carpenter said, noting some of the efforts related to policing.
But Carpenter said plenty of challenges remain citing research showing 75% of white people do not have friends of color and 66% of Black people don't have any white friends.
Carpenter said African Americans still face obstacles and discrimination with jobs, noting a 2024 study that found job applicants with 'white-sounding' names were 50% more likely to get callbacks from employers than 'Black-sounding' names.
"It's an ongoing trauma. It's still a daily experience," Carpenter said of America's racial challenges.
But he also said the experiences of race in America and the current pushback to diversity and affirmative action programs have global and historical parallels.
"It's all throughout history where a majority population tends to favor themselves and dismiss the complaints of minorities," Carpenter said.
He said when minority rights are focused on, majority populations tend to feel they are being aggrieved.
"It's nothing new under the sun," Carpenter said. "They are just following the human nature script."
ECHO CHAMBERSOthers on the frontlines of the social landscape see a mixed bag with the current state of race in America.
Erica Williams, executive director of A Red Circle, a St. Louis-based racial equity group, welcomed post-Floyd police changes such as body cameras and civilian review boards, but said the community distrust of law enforcement persists.
She said the economic impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic "deepened every pre-existing divide — especially in food access, education and health care."
Her group has launched community food programs to help with post-pandemic inflation with U.S. prices up 25% since the pandemic.
"We grew more produce, hired youth interns, launched workshops and distributed thousands of pounds of fresh food to families," she said.
Adanté Pointer, a California-based civil rights attorney, sees ups and downs with policing since 2020.
"We are seeing officers prosecuted more frequently than before," he said. "However, police shootings and killings have gone up."
Last year, police killings of civilians totaled 1,365 persons, the highest on record, according to Mapping Police Violence.
There were 1,159 police-involved deaths in 2020.
White people made up 42.7% of the 2024 deaths while accounting for 59% of the total population. Black people accounted for one-quarter of fatal police incidents while making up 13% of the population.
Pointer said the dominance of social media in contemporary discourse offers an opportunity to learn more about others and their paths. But it also mirrors societal biases and beliefs and technology algorithms allow users to stay in their ideological and social lanes.
"It becomes an echo chamber," he said.
GOODBYE DEI?Donald Nieman, a history professor at Binghamton University in New York, sees racial pendulums throughout American history.
He said there has been progress in narrowing racial income, education and employment gaps but worries about Trump "appealing to white grievance."
Neiman said. "It also assumes that Black people have used racism as a weapon to win special privileges at the expense of whites .. It is dangerous: It diverts attention from the real racial disparities in our society and from developing policies to address them."
The U.S. poverty rate stands at 11% with 18% of African-Americans, 17% of Hispanic Americans, 19% of immigrants and 8% of white Americans living in poverty, according to U.S. Census data and FederalSafetyNet.com.
Some of the companies and organizations that embraced DEI efforts after Floyd's death have jettisoned those efforts amid pushback from Trump and conservatives.
Others have faulted DEI programs as patronizing and self-serving.
"DEI is embraced by the business community when they think it will enhance their bottom lines," Pointer said. "They are more than willing to walk away when it's not popular."
Several large U.S. businesses, brands and technology firms have sought warm relations with Trump since he returned to power, attending and bankrolling his inauguration and attending other White House events.
Muneer Panjwani, CEO of Engage for Good (which connects businesses and nonprofits) said DEI programs have driven "meaningful progress."
"Companies have become significantly more aware of systemic racism and structural barriers faced by marginalized communities, taking actionable steps toward equity," he said.
But Panjwani acknowledges Trump has leveraged feelings of alienation among some white people. He also said equity conversations have sometimes been framed too narrowly, overlooking class, gender and other factors.
Carpenter said white working-class Americans, who have seen stagnant wages and high inflation, have felt unheard in contemporary discourses.
All that comes amid post-pandemic financial strains and concentrations of wealth.
"Economic inequality has reached alarming levels, with the richest 1% holding over 31% of the nation's wealth while nearly half of Americans still struggle with unexpected financial burdens," Panjwani said.
Williams said her Missouri-based stays focused on its local work, including a community farm that grows its own food and is looking to offer its own grocery store and food production kitchen.
"We've seen an escalation of rhetoric and policymaking that undermines inclusive education, equity initiatives and even basic access programs. In that environment, I stay focused on building what my community needs," she said
Carpenter agrees that it takes popular and grassroots changes in mindsets to move the needle.
"Politicians never lead," he said.

title: Trump rebrands 'Don't Ask, Don't Tell' policy
author: TONY WOODS
content:
Trump rebrands 'Don't Ask, Don't Tell' policy

 June 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TONY WOODS | Section: Columns 
 
 730
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In 2008, I was kicked out of the military because of my sexual orientation under "Don't Ask, Don't Tell." More than a decade after the military overturned that policy, the Trump administration is playing politics and bringing discrimination back to our armed forces. But this time, instead of purging troops for who they love, it punishes them for who they are.Today, brave transgender service members serve in uniform, many of whom have deployed, commanded troops, and put their lives on the line for this country. They serve at twice the rate of the general population, choosing military service at an extraordinary level of commitment.
The new order banning transgender personnel is written in broad strokes, just as the original Don't Ask, Don't Tell policy was. That meant nearly anyone could get caught in the dragnet — service members who had never spoken a word about their identity, those outed by others, even those falsely accused. The effects of this policy are even more sweeping as it mandates proactively kicking out any trans service member who has sought basic evidence-based, medically-necessary care just like any other service member.
The justifications for this policy echo the baseless justifications once used to discriminate against Black Americans, women, and gay people. While opposing the integration of Black troops into the military, then-Army Chief of Staff General Dwight D. Eisenhower warned that "the army is not a sociological laboratory" and that such "experiments" would harm morale and discipline.
In 1941, Sen. David Walsh argued that allowing women in the Navy "would tend to break up American homes and would be a step backward in the progress of civilization."
More than half a century later, in defense of Don't Ask, Don't Tell, Sen. Chuck Hagel insisted that "the U.S. armed forces aren't some social experiment." And as recently as 2015, former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee used nearly identical rhetoric to oppose women in combat roles, saying, "The military is not a social experiment. The purpose of the military is to kill people and break things."
This kind of thinking was wrong then, and it's wrong now.
The reason my grandfather, a Black man, was able to serve in an integrated military was because we retired those old, backward ideas. The reason my mother was able to serve in the armed forces was because people rejected the notion that women didn't belong in uniform. And the reason I am able to serve today is because "Don't Ask, Don't Tell" was finally tossed onto the ash heap of history.
But sometimes, bad ideas don't die. They get repackaged and rebranded. That's what we're seeing now.
Under this new policy, even service members who have fully transitioned and are operationally fit will be discharged. Military academies will be forced to expel trans cadets and midshipmen. Recruiters will turn away talented individuals who want nothing more than to serve their country. It is a deliberate purge, one that echoes the discrimination that kept LGBTQ+ Americans out of the military for decades.
The U.S. military is already struggling to meet its recruitment goals, missing its target for the Army by 11,000 in 2023 and barely reaching its recruiting goals for 2024 after dramatically lowering them. Why would we turn away trained, capable warfighters — people in whom American taxpayers have already invested millions in training — at a time when we need them most?
History will look back on this decision as a shameful moment, just as it now does on previous efforts to bar women, Black Americans and LGBTQ+ individuals from serving openly. And as before, this policy will not last. It will be challenged, it will be overturned, and one day, we will wonder how it was ever considered acceptable to turn away Americans willing to serve.
But the cost in the meantime will be real. Careers will be destroyed. Lives will be upended. Our national security weakened. And America's promise — that anyone who steps forward to serve will be judged by their ability, not their identity — will be broken.
To those who have worn the uniform, this moment is not just about policy. It is about principle. Service members swear an oath to defend the Constitution against all enemies, foreign and domestic. That oath does not ask for gender identity. It does not make exceptions. It simply demands the courage to stand up when the nation calls.
The question now is whether our leaders will do the same.

title: Caroline County celebrates pride
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Caroline County celebrates pride

 June 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Caroline 
 
 435
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Chappel Roan's "Pink Pony Club" was blasting and rainbow flags were flying Saturday afternoon at the fifth annual Caroline County Pride Festival in Denton.Booths, food trucks and family friendly activities like face-painting and a bounce house lined Market Street for over 500 participants to enjoy. Booths varied from the Caroline County Democratic Club, Fairy Awesome Secrets by Loralie and Kaiser K9 to the Chesapeake Voyagers Inc. Wellness and Recovery Center.
Caroline Pride founder and CEO Angel Perez started creating the organization during the pandemic and hosted the first festival in 2021. "And the year after, as an outcome of the first festival, we opened the Caroline Pride organization," he said.
For Perez, events like these are particularly important during the current political climate. "Having events like this one and celebrating pride month is another way to put the message out there regardless of what other people say, 'We are there for you. We hear you. We see you, and we don't want you to go anywhere,'" he said.
The Caroline Pride nonprofit works to support LGBTQ+ members of the community by hosting youth programs, coffee talks, pride socials and other events year-round.
Miss Trans Maryland, Davina Reign Escade, was one of the first to speak at the event in downtown Denton Saturday. She said it was difficult growing up in a body she didn't feel was hers and that it was especially tough because she didn't have a supportive community.
"I am proud to be here as a citizen of this town at one point, and I'm proud to be here to be a voice for our community because we all know what's going on in the world," she said. "We're fighting. We're fighting to be visible, we're fighting to stay here, we're fighting to be loved. We're fighting to just exist," Escade said.
The event's keynote speaker was recent North Caroline High School graduate Connor Christopher, who expressed gratitude towards his family and friends for making his coming out process easy. Christopher acknowledged this is not the case for a lot of individuals.
"Many queer people have been kicked out of their homes, disowned by their families, shunned by their loved ones, harmed or even killed because of their identity," he said. "I have the honor and privilege to be standing on this stage before you today at a festival where we are free to celebrate who we are and what it took to get us here."
Christopher recognized the Stonewall Riots of 1969, and gave the audience a mission to continue to fight for the LGBTQ+ community.
"Unfortunately, we are still far from done with our fight," he said.

title: Easton celebrates 4th annual Delmarva Pride Festival
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton celebrates 4th annual Delmarva Pride Festival

 June 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 416
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Delmarva Pride Festival brought hundreds to Easton on Saturday, and with the large crowd came a sense of unity.The festival especially picked up around noon, when hundreds of "No Kings" protesters walking down East Dover Street turned onto South Harrison Street to join the Pride celebration.
Tina Jones, co-founder of the Delmarva Pride Center, said it was the perfect combination of two events looking for acceptance and inclusion.
"They just align," said Tina Jones, co-founder of the Delmarva Pride Center. "I think it's so symbolic when they do come together and merge like that."
Saturday's Pride Festival included drag performances, live music and food vendors. Tents set up by local businesses and nonprofits packed Harrison Street during the five-hour event.
Easton Mayor Megan Cook spoke to the crowd from the performance stage, commending the sense of community festivalgoers brought to Easton.
"Pride is more than just a festival," Cook said. "It's a powerful reminder of the strength it takes to live authentically and the importance of creating a town where everyone feels safe, valued and supported.
"I've been proud to stand with you over the years, and I'm especially glad to be here today with my son. It means a lot to me, both as a community leader and as a parent of a son in the LGTBQ+ community, that we live in a place that embraces diversity, celebrates people for who they are and leads with love."
Jair Devereaux, a first time festivalgoer, said he was impressed with the vendors and musical performers. Devereaux came from the protests earlier that day.
While he said the festival was great, he said there are still challenges the LGBTQ+ community faces in a rural area like the Eastern Shore.
"I don't think that people know that they have a home here," Devereaux said. "It's like having a food desert."
The Pride Festival has faced controversy and pushback in its four years, namely from the Easton Town Council. A public assembly permit for the 2024 event narrowly passed by a 3-2 vote, and in the months after, multiple council members spoke opposing the Pride festivities.
But this year, the council approved the festival's permit 4-0.
"I think a lot of things have happened," Jones said. "Of course some council members have changed. But also, I think more importantly, conversations have been happening."
"Look, we don't all agree on every topic," Jones added. "But there are more things that we agree on than we disagree on. ... Let's get to know people. And this (festival) is a great way."

title: New exhibit documents and honors Talbot County's U.S. Colored Troops
author: Konner Metz
content:
New exhibit documents and honors Talbot County's U.S. Colored Troops

 June 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 712
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A new exhibit is documenting the often untold stories of hundreds of African American men from Talbot County who fought for their freedom in the Civil War.And while the project put on by the Talbot Historical Society aims to tell the history of free and enslaved Black men in the Civil War, it doesn't stop there. Extensive research dating back months has helped uncover the names and details of more than 500 Black soldiers from Talbot County.
Before the exhibit's soft opening to the public Tuesday, retired Salisbury University professor and historian Clara Small delivered a moving lecture to a packed room in the Talbot County Free Library.
"This exhibit will help to put flesh on those names," Small said. "The goal is that it's not just a name anymore, but a human being. One of your ancestors."
The exhibit — "Talbot County's United States Colored Troops: A Story of Valor and Honor" — is located on South Washington Street in downtown Easton. The list of names hangs on one end of the exhibit, though that catalog is continuously being updated as historians learn more about the local soldiers.
During the Civil War, as Small noted, the border state of Maryland did not meet its quota for Union Army soldiers. Many white soldiers avoided fighting through fees or purchasing substitutes, she said.
"The solution was to use free Blacks and slaves because they provided an unlimited reservoir of manpower," Small said, noting how many Marylanders and slaveholders rejected the idea of using Black troops, fearing a loss of labor.
Abolitionist and Talbot County native Frederick Douglass advocated for the inclusion of Black soldiers in the Union Army. His work, along with Abraham Lincoln's authorization for the recruitment of slaves, made the United States Colored Troops possible.
Small noted around 180,000 Black men served in the Union Army, with more than 8,000 from Maryland and around 600 or 700 from Talbot County.
Research conducted by the Talbot Historical Society and partnering groups sheds light on the many free and enslaved Black men from Talbot County who answered the call but never received the same recognition white soldiers were granted.
Historical Society member Paul Callahan said it took hours of research, collaboration with local organizations like Easton's American Legion Post 77 and consultation with Small to prepare the list of names.
"I saw so many family names, friends that I grew up with in Oxford," Callahan said. " ... I don't even think they knew that their ancestors were American heroes who fought in the war so valiantly."
The exhibit has records and an electronic database where people can learn specifics about the soldiers: birthplace, date of death, height, eye color, regiment, rank and more. Callahan says it's a tool to empower Talbot County residents to learn more about history and their ancestries.
Historians relied on the online military record database Fold3, as well as records in the library's Maryland Room and from local families or veteran groups.
"It was very tedious," Callahan said.
Some of the artifacts and items on display in the exhibit come from a Civil War reenactment group in Philadelphia. Project leaders also consulted descendants of the 18 U.S. Colored Troops who founded the Unionville community after the war.
During her lecture, Small said the research makes the Civil War more "personable" for local residents. She emphasized that Black families will be better able to trace their heritage.
"There should be very few people in this county that are not connected to some of these men in some way, whether it is by marriage, as cousins or as cousins of cousins," Small said.
The renowned professor highlighted the unfair and discriminatory treatment Black soldiers received even after the Union's victory in the war. She encouraged attendees to tell the accounts of the free and enslaved Black soldiers, stories that aren't told nearly enough.
"That is a legacy that is often forgotten, neglected or is purposely left out of our history books," Small said. "It is way past the time to correct those myths, perceptions and erroneous beliefs."
"This is just the tip of the iceberg," Small added. "We have a lot of work to do."
The Talbot County United States Colored Troops exhibit is located at the Talbot Historical Society at 25 S Washington St. It is open Wednesdays through Saturdays from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m.

title: Moore unveils investment into marginalized communities during event on Pine Street
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Moore unveils investment into marginalized communities during event on Pine Street

 June 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: News 
 
 653
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Gov. Wes Moore made a historic announcement at the historic Civil Rights meeting ground of Bethel AME Church in Cambridge on Juneteenth.Moore announced the allocation of $400 million to address discriminatory practices like redlining, mass incarceration and urban renewal in over 400 "Just Communities."
Making the announcement at the Pine Street church on the holiday designated to commemorate the ending of slavery in the United States was no coincidence.
"This was the Black Wall Street operating in America," said the Rev. Devan Martin Thursday of Pine Street as he acknowledged the historic significance of the day, place and announcement. Martin energized the people sitting in pews, reminding them of those who have come here before.
"It's not an accident that we've come here on Juneteenth to not only stand on our own two feet, but to stand on the shoulders of our ancestors," he said. "The Harriet Tubmans and Fredrick Douglasses who walked literally enslaved people through these grounds."
Cambridge's past
During a time of civil unrest in Cambridge in the 1960s, Bethel AME served as a headquarters for the Civil Rights Movement, according to Dorchester County's tourism department. Many rallies and meetings were held at the church.
In the early 1960s, unemployment skyrocketed, exposing the Cambridge's severe racial divide. Although segregation was ruled unconstitutional in 1954, Cambridge maintained separate schools and recreational areas in the Second Ward for 10 more years.
Protests endured for weeks in the summer of 1963 after promises of desegregation were backpedaled. Gov. J. Millard Tawes imposed martial law and deployed the Maryland National Guard to Cambridge, where it remained for 25 days. Martial law would remain in effect for a year.
In July of '67, H. Rap Brown, an emerging Black militant and chairman of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, gave a speech in the town. On the corner of Pine and Ceder streets, Brown said, "If this town don't come around, this town should be burned down."
On July 24, 1967, Pine Street went up in flames. The origin of fire remains unclear, though there has been a lot of speculation and finger pointing over the decades. Cambridge's Second Ward is still recovering from the fire, the segregation and the discrimination that followed.
Moore's announcement
A key theme among speakers at the Juneteenth event was that now is the time to rectify systemic and economic injustices affecting the community.
Martin said this will not be a pull-yourselves-up-by-your-bootstraps approach. Instead, a path forward will be provided offering hope beyond self resilience, he said.
At Bethel AME., Moore announced over 400 "Just Communities" in Maryland, including Cambridge. The communities, 419 of Maryland's 1,463 census tracts, were determined by the state's Department of Housing and Community Development to be historically underserved.
According to Moore, $400 million has been designated to address exclusionary policie in these communities. The "Just Community" designations will go into effect July 1.
"Today, Gov. Moore and Sec. (Jake) Day embodied how Maryland is setting a national standard for disrupting systemic inequities and ushering inclusive paths towards healing in and with communities from all zip codes," said Maryland Commission on African American History and Culture Vice Chair Jaelon Moaney, who is from Cambridge, in a press release Thursday.
During his visit to Cambridge, Moore also announced an executive clemency order adding nearly 7,000 cases to his historic June 2024 mass pardon of 175,000 cannabis-related convictions. The 6,938 additional pardons, which are for simple cannabis possession convictions, are "the result of continued partnership with the Maryland Judiciary to review cases since the first order was signed last June," Moore's office said in a press release.
"I also want to be very clear, we are not going to celebrate the benefits of (cannabis) legalization if we do not deal with the consequences of criminalization," Moore said to those gathered at Bethel AME. Thursday.
Moore said both initiatives announced Thursday aim to address the long-term impacts of discrimination like that experienced by Cambridge's Pine Street community.
"Liberation is good, but we demand freedom," Moore said.

title: Families flock to Delmarva Pride Festival
author: BROOKE ENSMINGER
content:
Families flock to Delmarva Pride Festival

 June 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BROOKE ENSMINGER | Section: News 
 
 582
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The fourth annual Delmarva Pride Festival brought together both young and old last weekend. Notable among the festivalgoers were families with young children.In recent years, the Pride Festival has faced defunding threats from several Easton Town Council members, who have argued that certain aspects of the event could be harmful to children. However, the festival organizers have made an effort to make the event family-friendly and appropriate for young children.
Kyle O'Donnell, the treasurer and co-founder of the Delmarva Pride Center, said the Center strives to create a welcoming environment for everyone.
"We thought that by default, Pride on the Shore should be family-friendly," O'Donnell said. "And to us, that meant asking the musical performers and bands to review their songs and we ask them to please not sing any songs or do any dance routines with curse words in them."
Many parents take their children each year, saying the event provides an opportunity to instill inclusivity from an early age.
Erin Shimko, of Easton, attended the festival with her husband and two children. She said she brings her children to help normalize self-expression and authenticity.
"We live nearby, so we've been going to this ever since we moved here," Schimko said. "So, it's just part of their life, and they don't question it."
Some attendees, like April Schmidt, drove an hour from Annapolis to attend the Pride Festival in Easton, where her children's grandparents live nearby in Preston. She was joined by her wife, their two children and the children's grandparents. Schmidt has a 2-year-old son and a 5-month-old daughter.
"I think it's really special for them to see other families that are similar to ours, but also just to celebrate Pride month in general, so they get a feel for accepting all," Schmidt said.
Many parents said they appreciated the positivity at the festival, with attendees smiling and enjoying themselves. Local Easton resident Angie Lavezzo walked around the festival with her two children and said she enjoyed the welcoming atmosphere.
"You're getting hugs from strangers, and everybody's so kind to each other," Lavezzo said. "It's just such a powerful statement of love."
Similar to many parents at the festival, Lavezzo brought her children to the event to show them people being "who they are to their core" and to teach them to accept everyone.
Some parents expressed gratitude for having a Pride Festival and a space to promote inclusivity in such a small town.
Blakely Barlev attended the festival for the first time with her daughter. A former New York resident, Barlev now lives in Easton and said it is important for children growing up in small towns to go to events like these since they aren't as frequently exposed to other communities.
"I lived in New York City for a while, so I'm used to seeing that all the time, but they don't," Barlev said. "So, I love bringing them to places like this, and I think it inspires them to be quirky and weird and be themselves."
Some parents offered suggestions on how the festival could become more engaging for children. Jaclyne Schettini, of Cambridge, said she remembered the festival having face painting in the past and would like to see it again. This year's festival had a temporary tattoo station instead.
Schmidt said she had been to other festivals with designated kids' areas and thinks that could be a good addition to the Delmarva Pride Festival going forward. But each parent interviewed said they would return for next year's festival to continue showing their children the importance of inclusivity.

title: DEI is about giving everybody an opportunity
author: STEPHEN RIDEOUT
content:
DEI is about giving everybody an opportunity

 June 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STEPHEN RIDEOUT | Section: Columns 
 
 600
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I am reading "How We Learn to Be Brave" by Bishop Mariann Edgar Budde, the Episcopal bishop of Washington.In her book, she writes about Thurgood Marshall and the challenges that he faced during his life.
"When he was denied admission to the University of Maryland School of Law on the basis of race, he reluctantly applied to Howard University School of Law, which he considered a far less reputable institution," she writes.
That interested me because I was aware that when he became a lawyer, he and the NAACP successfully sued the University of Maryland Law School in the case of Murray v. Pearson for denying Black students admission because of their race. It also interested me because of conversations I had with two men who had similar experiences.
One was a retired judge, who told me that he had gone to Howard and graduated as valedictorian. Thurgood Marshall asked him to apply to the University of Virginia Law School thinking that they would deny him admission, despite his qualifications, so that he could be Marshall's plaintiff in a lawsuit against the university.
When he applied to UVA, he was not denied admission. Rather, he was approached by a wealthy benefactor of the university with the offer to pay for his law education at any other law school that would accept him. The retired judge accepted the offer, went to law school in New York, and had to tell Mr. Marshall that he would not be the plaintiff in that lawsuit.
Gregory Swanson became the successful plaintiff in that lawsuit against the rector and Visitors of the University of Virginia brought by the NAACP with Thurgood Marshall being one of the lawyers where Mr. Swanson was granted admission to the law school.
Several years after my discussion with the retired judge, I had a chance meeting with Rep. Alcee Hastings from Florida. I sat near him on a plane trip and told him the story of the experience the retired judge had as a student. Interestingly, Congressman Hastings told me that it was not an isolated event, as the same thing had happened to him and had also happened to African Americans who had applied to medical schools in the South.
Schools and alumni offered to pay their way to a graduate school in the north to avoid the litigation that might come from the denial of admission to the school to which they applied. While some may have been denied admittance, others were offered some benefit to go elsewhere such as the payment of their tuition at a law school or medical school elsewhere in the U.S.
When I hear complaints about diversity, equity and inclusion, I never hear the full story of the background or reasoning for these complaints. I see the DEI effort not as promoting unqualified people to a position but rather giving all people the opportunity to be considered for a position who might otherwise be excluded from being considered. Giving everyone the opportunity to compete and learn from the experience, whether hired, admitted or not, seems to me to benefit everyone.
Colleges and universities have done something similar for many years for the children of alumni of their institutions where the child might not be considered the most qualified candidate but is admitted. How is that not favoritism based on connections rather than on skills and past accomplishments? In Cambridge during my time in city government, the search for qualified city employees included anyone interested and always tried to find people who were a good fit for our community who had the potential to become great and long-term workers for the city.

title: Harriet Tubman's history is home: new historic marker unveiled in Dorchester County
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Harriet Tubman's history is home: new historic marker unveiled in Dorchester County

 June 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 534
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHURCH CREEK — On Monday morning, a new historic marker honoring Harriet Tubman's birthplace was unveiled. It is set to be placed on Maryland Route 16.The marker is the result of work by Chief Archaeologist for the Maryland Department of Transportation Julie Schablitsky, whose team seeks to help people to better understand Tubman's early life through her home and her descendants.
Schablitsky and her team began searching for signs of Tubman's early life in Dorchester County in late 2020. Through discoveries made during that time, the archeologists were able to tell a larger story of Tubman's young life.
Tubman's childhood was unearthed through the beams and bricks of her father Ben Ross' cabin. The team discovered a chest of drawers with an iron for pressing clothes inside, a variety of white ceramic dishes from England with designs similar to West African textiles painted on them, buttons and a tobacco pipe with an eagle motif.
"Perhaps this was a subtle, yet symbolic, public display of resistance, strength and even future aspirations for freedom," Schablitsky said about the eagle on the pipe.
The discovery of Ross' cabin, which is presumed to be Tubman's birthplace, has not only allowed for historic insights, but has allowed for Tubman's descendants to know her on a more personal level.
Tonet Cuffee, a fourth generation great niece of Tubman's, visited the site of Ross' cabin with Schablitsky's team. "Harriet Tubman was born here in a rut of pain and injustice, but it was here that she learned faith, resilience, courage and compassion," Cuffee said.
According to Schablitsky, Tubman spent much of her time in the area until being moved to Bucktown with her mother, eight siblings and enslaver, Edward Brodess. When Tubman became a teenager, she moved back to the Ross cabin in the wooded wetlands along Harrisville Road and the Blackwater River and began working with her father in logging, cutting and hauling timber.
The discoveries made by Schablitsky's team allow people to "see the places she may have walked, the structures she may have known and the world it was that she was born into," Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said.
Dorchester County Council Vice President Mike Detmer made a point to remember Tubman's humanity at Monday's event. "It's easy for us to celebrate and to honor her now, knowing how her extremely cinematic story of heroism, and tenacity, and toughness and single-mindedness. We know now how it turned out," he said.
Though she lived through immense adversity, Tubman never gave up on her faith and freedom, her descendants said at the event.
Gov. Wes Moore spoke about Maryland's complex history as the "northernmost southern state." He said this complexity is perfectly personified in Maryland's state flag, which is a combination of flags from the Civil War's Union and the Confederate armies.
On Monday, Moore spoke of the many hats Tubman wore throughout her life, including during the Civil War. Last year, Tubman was posthumously recognized by Moore as a one-star Brigadier General in Maryland's National Guard for her service in the Civil War.
"I learned and realized Harriet Tubman is the original 'leave no man behind,'" Moore said.
The Harriet Tubman historical marker will be installed Monday near the Woolford Store along Route 16 east of Harrison Road.

title: Crackin my shell: Emotional detachment and war
author: SARENA NEYMAN
content:
Crackin my shell: Emotional detachment and war

 June 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SARENA NEYMAN | Section: Columns 
 
 827
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Every spring, someone in my town posts hand-drawn "turtle crossing" signs near the roads where turtles lay their eggs. I'd never actually seen one crossing and used to wonder why anyone bothered with these signs.But recently, I spotted a small painted turtle inching across the road, likely returning to the pond after burying her eggs. I considered moving her but worried I'd throw off her inner compass.
The next day, on a morning bike ride, I saw a massive snapper the size of a watermelon, slowly making her way across the asphalt. I got off my bike and paused the podcast I'd been listening to: Peter Beinart's interview of Israeli journalist Gideon Levy.
Levy said many Jews, both in Israel and the U.S., shut their hearts to Palestinian suffering. They skip the disturbing images of destruction and starvation, avoid the headlines, ignore the unbearable. His words brought to mind "The Zone of Interest," the Oscar-winning film about an Auschwitz commandant's family unmoved by the screams beyond their walls. What's chilling is how ordinary people adapted, how they built lives alongside atrocity by refusing to see the victims as fully human.
As I stood by the turtle, a car pulled up. The driver rolled down the window. "Should we move it?" she asked. We both admired the majestic prehistoric-looking creature, its jagged shell and ancient eyes, like a living dinosaur that had somehow lumbered out of the deep past. These animals have not changed in 90 million years.
"I don't think it's safe to move a snapper unless you've done it before," I said.
She nodded, rolled up her window and carefully drove around it.
I was pulling out my phone to take a photo when I saw another car approaching. I assumed they saw the huge turtle. I didn't wave or signal. Surely they'd slow down.
But then, in an awful instant, I realized they weren't slowing down at all. The impact was immediate. The snapper was thrown into the air. When she hit the ground, I heard a sound I will never forget: her shell exploding beneath the tire — a violent, cracking thunder that tore through my ears. The car never even slowed down.
It felt like something in me had cracked too.
I'm not someone who cries easily. I have a hard shell — quicker to think than to feel. Maybe it started in childhood. I was the one who had to wake my grandmother from her nightmares. No one else heard her cries at night, but my room was next to hers. I hated the job. A Nazi soldier had ripped her 4-year-old daughter from her arms. She never saw the little girl again.
Shaken by the turtle's death, I got back on my bike and resumed the podcast. Levy was describing a Palestinian friend in Gaza with only two days of insulin left. This is everyday life in Gaza, Levy says. We all know what happens when severe diabetics can't get their insulin, he adds.
The death of the turtle reminds me of how vulnerable the earth's creatures are and the cruelty of humans. I hear the high-pitched screech before a bomb explodes, the scream of a father pulling his daughter's body from the rubble, the cries of hungry children with ribs like bird cages.
It's strange what breaks through. It's rarely facts or numbers. Dozens of Israeli children were killed by Hamas on Oct. 7. Thousands upon thousands of Palestinian children have been killed since that date. Among much of the Jewish community I grew up in, one number evokes national mourning. The other is met with silence.
In a recent interview, Ezra Klein spoke with writer Kathryn Schulz about the challenge of staying emotionally awake.
"I spend days covering efforts to rip health care from people and torch the global economy," Klein said, "and then I'm supposed to go to a birthday party."
We can't live every second in full awareness, Schulz tells him. We'd collapse. But, she says, if we're lucky enough to feel suffering only indirectly, we must choose, again and again, not to look away. Even if we don't know how to intervene.
Throughout the day, I keep remembering the snapper's death. The arc her body made in the air. The shattering crunch. These turtles can live for up to 100 years. Who knew how many years were cut from her life? She had survived predators, pollution, drought. And then in an instant, she was smashed to pieces.
I am haunted by my inaction.
Why didn't I wave at the car? Why didn't I hold up my hand? I keep thinking about how preventable it all felt. How easily we destroy what we don't slow down to see. How easy it is to detach from it all.
Over time, the memory of this day will fade. But I want to remember that sound. That cracking. Because in its violence it connected me to the fragility of life, the tragedy of indifference, the ease with which one becomes numb — and how dangerous that can be.
