title: Native American communities underscore untold stories of American independence
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Native American communities underscore untold stories of American independence

 July 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 656
 Words 

 Read News Document

 VIENNA — July 4 is a day many Americans celebrate to honor the country's independence from Great Britain. For many Native Americans, the meaning behind the holiday is more complicated, and their story of Independence Day often goes overlooked.The narrative surrounding Fourth of July often highlights the triumphs of American independence while overlooking the injustices that accompanied it.
Native Americans existed on this continent long before white colonial settlers, and according to Director of Native American Studies at the University of South Carolina Lancaster, Stephen Criswell, The American Revolution likely would not have been accomplished without the help of the Indigenous population.
"It is less likely there would have been a successful revolution, we may have ended up as Canada or Australia," Criswell said on indigenous participation in the Revolutionary War. "That doesn't really get acknowledged," he said.
Donna "Wolf Mother" Abbott, chief of the Nause-Waiwash Band of Indians based in Dorchester County, said the story of July 4 is bigger than the colonists gaining independence from Great Britain.
She said it is important to tell the whole story.
"When the colonists came here, the Native Americans were already free, and the colonists had to experience our lifestyle, our culture and our traditions," Abbott said. "What they experienced and what they learned from us was a part of the story that's missing."
Criswell said while the Declaration of Independence called Native Americans "merciless Indian Savages," those who wrote it relied heavily on the indigenous peoples' knowledge of the land.
"You know, they called them savages but shortly after referred to them as the Five Civilized Tribes, so which is it?" Criswell asked. "Of course, this is the same document that says all men are created equal, except for those that don't own land, or aren't white or aren't male," Criswell said.
The wording of the Declaration of Independence underscored a pervasive attitude that dictated centuries of discriminatory policies toward Native American people, including forced displacement, land theft and suppression of identity.
Criswell said July 4 is a holiday that's not as hotly debated among Native American communities as other holidays, like Christopher Colombus Day. Usually, he said, the Fourth of July is an opportunity for family and friends to come together.
The Fourth of July has historically been an opportunity for Native American people to practice their own ceremonies, especially in the late 1800s, when Congress passed the Religious Crimes Code, banning all Native American ceremonies and dancing, according to Smithsonian Magazine.
For 50 years, Native Americans either held religious ceremonies in secret or didn't have them at all due to the extremely harsh punishments like imprisonment or withholding treaty rations. Indigenous ceremonies during this time were held on or near July 4 under the guise of American celebration. Because of this, many tribal gatherings today take place on or near the Fourth of July, according to the Indigenous Foundation.
While there is no formal Nause‑Waiwash event on July 4, Abbott said members of the tribe do celebrate the holiday. "It's a celebration where families get together and spend time together, and we are all about family and friendship," Abbott said about the holiday.
Abbott said a good way to honor Native Americans on the Fourth of July is to tell the whole story of American independence and to learn more about Indigenous history. "I find a good resource is the Maryland Archives," she said.
In 2023, The state of Maryland began the Indigenous Archive Project for the Eastern Shore of Maryland where seven members from different tribal communities record and keep their oral histories. This archive is publicly accessible.
Within the Maryland Archives, stories of Indigenous veterans of the Revolutionary War can be found.
The Nause-Waiwash Band of Indians will hold its 33rd annual festival on Sept. 13 of this year. "Each year we have tried to do something a little different and add something to it that's different so we don't fall into the rut of having the same thing every year, so we're proud of that," Abbott said.

title: Cambridge becomes a Just Community
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Cambridge becomes a Just Community

 July 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 634
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — On Juneteenth at Bethel AME Church on Pine Street, Gov. Wes Moore announced the Just Communities designation of 419 locations across Maryland, including parts of Cambridge. Moore said it was not a coincidence this announcement was made in a city where the Civil Rights Movement took center stage.The Moore-Miller administration established the Just Communities Designation in 2024 to address policies that have disenfranchised generations of families, such as redlining and exclusionary zoning.
"We wanted to hold it in one of the communities that rose to the top tier of places that had experienced the most harm and from which, the least improvement has occurred," said Secretary of Housing and Community Development Jake Day of the Juneteenth event.
The initiative is the result of work by The Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development Division of Just Communities. Day said he has worked closely with Division of Just Communities Assistant Secretary Cat Goughnour.
Day said the Just Communities Act not only acknowledges past harms but returns resources to those communities. As part of the initiative, Day said Cambridge residents will see community-nominated projects for revitalization, such as facilities, housing and economic developments.
"We want to make sure that we understand what the community wants and not show up with development when people aren't asking for it," he said.
According to Day, early indicators of success for the Just Communities Act would be more project activity in neighborhoods with visible scars, like the Pine Street corridor of Cambridge, formerly known as Black Wall Street.
This could include more home repairs for legacy homeowners, increased homeownership, new homes on vacant lots, new community buildings and more businesses. Long term outcomes include improved public health and reduced criminal justice involvement, Day said.
Cambridge Mayor Lajan Cephas said she feels this is a framework for justice. With Cambridge's history of slavery, Jim Crow, discriminatory policies and segregation among wards, Cephas is hopeful the Just Communities designation will begin to rectify past harms.
"It's being unwound," Cephas said. "It's just great to finally address, you know, the financial instabilities and other opportunities that were held back in communities just like Cambridge."
Cephas said along with the investments made in the community, the Just Communities initiative pushes grant requests to the front of the line.
"I say, Gov. Moore, it's like you gave us platform shoes," she said. "It's very difficult competing against these other municipalities. They have better grant writers, better budgets. You know, they have comprehensive plans that they've been working on for years, and we're just now getting caught up."
Cephas wants to make it clear that these initiatives will not solely benefit Black residents, but will benefit all residents who have been affected by discriminatory policies and live within the Just Communities designated area, which encompasses much of downtown Cambridge and surrounding neighborhoods.
The Just Communities Act has faced pushback from Maryland Republican lawmakers, who called the initiative an unproductive government handout and unfair to Maryland taxpayers, according to a statement issued to the Baltimore Sun.
In a statement to the Star Democrat Friday morning, Maryland Senate Minority Leader Stephen Hershey (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline) said, "Does anyone really believe pumping hundreds of millions into handpicked areas will build generational wealth?"
"This is wealth redistribution dressed up in equity language — it's socialism, plain and simple," the statement said.
But the initiative's proponents contend the Just Communities designations aim to ensure fairness among Maryland residents.
"It's the very picture of fairness as I was raised and taught to understand fairness," Day said. "Again, take something from somebody and you return it."
Cephas echoed Day's sentiments, pointing to the "unfair" practices that have held Cambridge back.
The community can check on updates for the Just Communities Designation at choosecambridge.com, where residents can sign up for public alerts via text or email.
This report has been updated to include comments from Sen. Stephen Hershey.

title: 'Still matters today': Community to read famous Frederick Douglass speech on Saturday
author: Konner Metz
content:
'Still matters today': Community to read famous Frederick Douglass speech on Saturday

 July 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 499
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On July 5, 1852, Frederick Douglass asked a burning question in front of hundreds of abolitionists in Rochester, New York: "What to the Slave is the Fourth of July?"The Talbot County native, often considered the most important abolitionist and civil rights leader of his time, delivered an address that described why enslaved African Americans weren't afforded the same freedoms and liberties that could allow them to celebrate the anniversary of the Declaration of Independence like the rest of the nation.
Douglass' famous speech is still popular 173 years later. On Saturday, the Easton-based Frederick Douglass Honor Society is hosting an annual community reading. Local officials, community leaders, residents and children are reading aloud portions of the address on the lawn of the Talbot County Courthouse starting at 10 a.m.
Vickie Wilson, the society's treasurer, says this year's calendar couldn't have worked out any better, with the event falling on the same day Douglass spoke to the Rochester Ladies Anti-Slavery Society.
"What's really exciting for us this year is that the first time Douglass read this speech was on July 5, 1852," Wilson said. "And now, it falls again on July 5."
The Frederick Douglass Honor Society has held the reading annually since 2018, though it was put on pause last year for a separate event. Wilson says this year's return is exciting due to the diversity of people — in age, race, occupation and more — participating in the reading. Fifty-nine people are expected to step up to the podium.
"We live in a diverse community," Wilson said. "It's going to show the love that we have for this community as well."
Douglass in his 1852 speech explained the significantly different perspective enslaved people had on the Fourth of July holiday.
"What, to the American slave, is your 4th of July? I answer; a day that reveals to him, more than all other days in the year, the gross injustice and cruelty to which he is the constant victim," Douglass said.
He continued: "To him, your celebration is a sham; your boasted liberty, an unholy license; your national greatness, swelling vanity; your sounds of rejoicing are empty and heartless; your denunciation of tyrants, brass fronted impudence; your shouts of liberty and equality, hollow mockery; your prayers and hymns, your sermons and thanksgivings, with all your religious parade and solemnity, are, to Him, mere bombast, fraud, deception, impiety, and hypocrisy — a thin veil to cover up crimes which would disgrace a nation of savages."
Wilson says the Talbot County tradition during the week of Independence Day is a moving one. She encourages people, no matter how they celebrate the holiday the rest of the week, to attend on Saturday.
She said the speech is a "lot to unpack," but extremely powerful. It still resonates with her today, and she believes it does for many Talbot County residents.
"It still matters today," Wilson said. "And I often think it matters more today in the climate that we're in right now. Everything here about this speech is still relevant."

title: Shame of being poor becomes empathy, motivation
author: ARLYCE MENZIES
content:
Shame of being poor becomes empathy, motivation

 July 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ARLYCE MENZIES | Section: News 
 
 898
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I grew up poor, that is, American poor.I fantasized about food at night–mashed potatoes, buttery dinner rolls, raspberry cheesecake. I would wake up and imagine a breakfast — strawberry waffles with whipped cream, cold orange juice — then, talk myself toward accepting what I knew was there — toast with peanut butter and usually, milk. My dad did not tolerate ungratefulness.
I couldn't pay school fees like the dreaded $10 workbook fee and was harangued by the dogged collectors as I repeated that I forgot it. I couldn't rent an instrument, so I didn't play one but singing lit my heart on fire. I couldn't join sports, couldn't buy uniforms or pay for trips. My gym teacher in seventh grade said I was great at running and hurdles, and she encouraged me to join the track team. I joined, but immediately sprained my big toe and quit. I think my teacher, the coach, knew I could have overcome this minor injury, but couldn't overcome going without the right shoes, walking two miles home from practices, having no money or rides or, in fact, confidence to run.
I got the free lunch at school. We had to walk up to the stage in the cafeteria to find our ticket — a white card with our name on it — before getting in line. Not only were we conspicuous, frantically searching for the ticket in front of everyone, but we were also the last to get the food our bagged-lunch friends couldn't recognize.
"What is that? Are you going to eat that?!"
When we had to bring a lunch for field days, my dad would pack something in a bread bag like an only-peanut-butter sandwich and a whole carrot with the white root hairs obscenely pressed against the clear plastic. Variations on this lunch included a boiled egg crayoned with "B" on the shell or a plain baked potato.
Packaged snacks weren't covered by food stamps or WIC — milk stuffs for Women Infants and Children. We had whole milk and bricks of government cheese food. We had unmarked cans and other food bank finds including, once, a sugary cereal we were excited about until we tasted that it had been contaminated by the powdered laundry soap it had sat with in the donation box.
We were turned away in shops because what we wanted couldn't be bought with this other-colored money or because they said they didn't have change for food stamps. Thankfully, my mom mostly knew where she could stock up and on what.
We rarely went to the doctor. We all have scars that show no one stitched them or set the bones straight — OK, only one broken finger set with a stick and tape. When my sister was really sick, the irritated doctor didn't want to take Medicaid. He only gave her Claritin. It turned out to be mono, and she was in bed for a week, then she got pneumonia. She recovered. Our remedies were to pray, drink water, put a cloth on your head or where you hurt, hot or cold, depending.
My mother-in-law says I'm an exception.
She says people on welfare are lazy, only busy pumping out babies and watching TV. She thinks it's easy to have no job, let the checks roll in, buy steaks and chocolate with your government winnings. She hasn't sat in the welfare office for three hours only to be yelled at, looked down upon and rejected for the second time because you couldn't get the papers right.
She hasn't had a disability or loved a person who is blind from a genetic disease like my dad was. She hasn't had a nervous breakdown, spent months in mental wards after suicide attempts like my mom has. She doesn't know anyone who grew up on or is on welfare, except for me.
In some ways, I am an exception. I grew up with both my married parents. My great-grandfathers were a doctor and a lawyer. The lawyer left us each $4,000 for college. There wasn't any question — we had to go to college. My dad went blind slowly. He memorized children's books so he could "read" to us without seeing the pages.
Although she didn't finish college, my mom loves poetry and had a full mahogany bookcase. She planted daffodils in the yard; we lived in our own house. My parents got a settlement after being in a dormitory fire. My mom's dad got a lawyer who won them enough to buy a house on an acre of grassy land with crab apple trees that bloomed pink in spring.
I am not an exception in that I am white. More than 62 percent of welfare recipients are white and about 46 percent are single mothers. Despite the term "white trash" my mother-in-law imagines this waste of money is for People of Color.
I am not an exception in that my parents are disabled. The majority of welfare recipients are children, the elderly, and people with disabilities.
I am not an exception in that I am hardworking and work to improve my life and the lives of others.
I am not an exception in that very young, I knew some strangers, teachers and people around me thought I was a useless weight, a tax burden, a bad decision, a mistake. I am not an exception in carrying this shame, trying to shape it, alchemize it into empathy, motivation, a commitment to justice.

title: Cephas family has 'rich heritage and roots' in Dorchester County
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Cephas family has 'rich heritage and roots' in Dorchester County

 July 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: News 
 
 976
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Cephas family's history is the history of Dorchester County.Ancestors fought in the Revolutionary War, worked in the fields as slaves on plantations and owned the largest Black-owned farm in the county following the Civil War. Today, Cephas family members hold key political positions in a number of Dorchester County towns and beyond.
For Brandy James, being part of the Cephas family means pride, resilience and honoring generations of strength, leadership and cultural identity in the Black community.
"The struggles of our ancestors were not in vain and have come to fruition," she said.
James, a Federalsburg council member, is the daughter of Hurlock Mayor Charles Cephas. James's cousins are Cambridge Mayor Lajan Cephas and Cambridge City Council President Sputty Cephas.
If one was not told before a city council meeting that Lajan used to change Sputty's diapers, you'd likely never know that they're siblings, but they're a dynamic duo in Cambridge's local government.
"I see it as my mission and my purpose to serve," Lajan said, but she didn't just mean as mayor. For the Cephases, politics can be a conduit to care for and serve the community, but it is not the main player.
"It doesn't have to be political to show that you care or that it's okay to help your neighbor. It's about the human aspect of it all. It's about being a good neighbor and considering your community as an extension of your family. That's how I see it," James said.
The Cephas Family History
Around 1817, Moses Cephas and his family were slaves at a property near the Fork Neck area — situated between Cambridge and Vienna — where Charles, the self-proclaimed acting patriarch, said the family had "deep roots."
That is until after the Civil War, when Moses and Josiah Cephas inherited a large farm near Vienna, becoming the proprietors of the largest Black-owned farm in Dorchester County. The Cephases sold produce, including corn and tomatoes, on Race Street in Cambridge and leased out part of the farm to white individuals, Charles said.
Lajan said along with farmers, there are watermen and sailors in the Cephas lineage.
Charles said that during slavery, some Cephas family members were captured by the renowned slave hunter Patty Cannon. Slave hunters like Cannon practiced in the illegal slave trade, also known as the Reverse Underground Railroad, where they found and captured escaped and freed slaves to return them back to slavery.
During this time, family members' names were changed from Cephas with an A to Cephus with a U to facilitate their transport across state lines back to the South.
Perhaps one of the most fascinating Cephas family members — which difficult to determine considering the incredible cast of characters — is Richard "Big Dick" Cephas.
A fictional version of his life where he fights in the Haitian revolution and falls in love with a young American woman is presented in Kenneth Roberts' best-selling novel "Lydia Bailey." But Charles said after speaking to several historians, he knows the real truth.
"He ran away from slavery and he went all the way to Boston, Massachusetts, and he ended up being in the British Army," he said. "He fought against America, he was captured and put in prison there, and they were able to trace it because he was such a disruptor that he caused a riot in the prison."
Being a disrupter is sometimes a necessary agent of change.
In 1962, Charles made history as one of the first Black people to graduate from the newly desegregated Cambridge High School. After serving on the town council for two decades, acting as president for one of those, he became the first Black mayor of the town of Hurlock in 2021 and was re-elected last year.
In 2023, James became the first Black lawmaker in Federalsburg's 200-year history. The following year, Lajan became the second Black female mayor of Cambridge and Sputty was re-elected onto the City Council and elected by his fellow council members as council president.
Cephas family values
For the Cephases, faith is at the center of all they do.
"You know, that's the foundation that we come from, and not only that, we take the last name of Cephas to a deeper meaning, more or less than the meaning that you see in the Bible," Lajan said. "I guess anyone who is a Christian or anyone that's read the Bible, Jesus had the moment where he referred to Peter as a Cephas, and that was essentially the foundation of how Christianity was established."
Charles has 14 children and 49 grandchildren — maybe a few more, maybe a few less. It's easy to lose count he said. At 75 years old, Charles said he's excited to watch the legacy he has helped build continue to prosper and grow.
For Lajan and Brandy, it is also important that Cephas is not synonymous with politics.
Both have children who pursued careers outside of politics. For both, it is important that their children carry the long-withstanding Cephas values into whatever they do.
"They feel the pressure to do what they're supposed to do so we can make God happy. That's their pressure," said Lajan about her sons. "You know, to govern themselves accordingly."
Lajan said she wants the people of Dorchester County to know that while the Cephases are deeply rooted, they are a small piece of the larger puzzle and beautiful fabric of all the other names in the county.
Some of the other names may even be Cephases.
Many formerly enslaved individuals either had their names changed or changed their names after obtaining freedom. Because of this, Charles said there are many Cephases out there that likely don't even know they are Cephases.
Charles said the descendants they've been able to trace can be located all over the U.S., including Alaska. Recently, they were able to trace Cephases in Japan. In the next few months, there will be a massive Cephas family reunion with descendants from all over the country and beyond.

title: Mid-Shore residents protest ICE arrest of Easton pastor
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Mid-Shore residents protest ICE arrest of Easton pastor

 July 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Local News 
 
 618
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot County Democratic Forum hosted a rally Friday evening to demand the return of Easton pastor Daniel Fuentes Espinal, who has been detained by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement since Monday. Over 150 people came out.Rally goers expressed fear, anger and concern that a pastor has been "ripped" from his congregation, three children and wife. Espinal, originally from Honduras, has been in Easton for 24 years.
Jim Bruce, a member of the Talbot County Democratic Forum communications committee, attributed the crowd size on the corner of Route 50 and Dover Street to the incredible media attention Espinal's case has received. Bruce said he normally knows a majority of the people who attend these events, but he saw new faces Friday night.
"There are some I don't recognize at all. So, I mean, I think the press is what did this," Bruce said.
Religious leaders and concerned citizens came out to show their support, including the Rev. Jessica Stehle of Easton Christ Church, who said she felt called to action to come support Espinal.
"It's hurting our hearts, and it's calling us to action," she said.
ICE said in a statement to The Star Democrat that Espinal overstayed a six-month visa by 24 years.
Espinal has no other criminal record and has been attempting to obtain citizenship legally for years, according to his daughter Clarissa Fuentes Diaz.
Espinal's arrest comes amid a push by the Trump administration to step up immigration enforcement. President Donald Trump has repeatedly stated he is out to get "the worst of the worst," promising a mass deportation that targeted criminals.
Many in attendance Friday pointed to Espinal's lack of criminal record.
"President Trump told the American public 'we're going to go for the worst of the worst,' and clearly they're not doing that," Bruce said.
"He needs impact, so he's picking people who've been here a long time, who are well known in the community," he said.
U.S. Customs and Immigration data from June 29 shows a recent shift from focusing mainly on those with criminal records to arresting those without a record. Out of 57,861 people detained by ICE, 41,495 had no criminal convictions.
Members of the Trump administration have said since the data's release that their priority remains deporting those who have committed crimes.
Those at the protest Friday raised signs that read "MELT ICE stop the kidnappings," "'WORST OF THE WORST?' Rev. Daniel = BEST of the BEST," and "YALL KNOW JESUS WAS BROWN RIGHT?"
Sydney Bradner Jacobs, chair of the Dorchester County Democratic Central Committee, said she and the rest of the committee canceled happy hour to be there.
"We decided to come out here and support and stand in solidarity with our friends in Talbot because it's not a happy hour when one of our own is deported without due process," Bradner said.
Espinal was initially taken to Salisbury, transferred to Baltimore and is now in an ICE detention center in Louisiana where he is waiting for his first hearing where his family hopes he will be released on bond.
A GoFundMe to support the pastor's mounting legal fees was created on Thursday and has already far surpassed its initial goal of $15,000. The new goal is set for $40,000 and the fund currently stands at $26,033 as of 8:30 p.m..
These fees, in other circumstances, can often be provided by local nonprofits.
The Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center keeps an emergency fund for situations like Espinal's that is typically kept at $10,000. President of the Talbot County Democratic Forum Michele Dappert said the funds have been significantly depleted due to the drastic increase in ICE-related arrests.
"We need help," Dappert said. "People should also donate to the MRC (multicultural resource center). If you have legal expertise, they could also use volunteers to serve as lawyers."

title: Hispanic pastor was targeted
author: Staff Writer
content:
Hispanic pastor was targeted

 July 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 320
 Words 

 Read News Document

 That ICE would arrest the Rev. Daniel Espinal was a foregone conclusion. To put it simply, he was targeted.ICE has been creating self-serving catches across the nation which both polish its badge and dispirit Hispanic communities. Doubtless, members of Pastor Espinal's church should be sure that ICE will be worshipping with them this Sunday, prayers in Spanish offered inside, whilst outside agents will be checking license plates, awaiting their drivers. There will be no coffee hour.
This has happened before in Easton.
In 1994, the then-INS raided an apartment complex, hauling off at least a dozen undocumented Hispanics. I represented many of their cases before the Asylum Office in Arlington, Virginia, and in the U.S. Immigration Court in Baltimore. As in those days I pastored a store front chapel in downtown Easton, I made it privately known to our Hispanics to enter by the alley door for the following Sunday's Spanish mass. Mass concluded, our strategy was to have those with green cards or who were citizens to socialize outside the front door. The INS agents, whom we expected, were baffled, even angry, to be greeted by our legals – while other worshippers squeezed into the sacristy, invisible through the chapel's front windows – all of them documented within the immigration system, yet vulnerable to agents eager only to collect vast numbers.
To victimize prominent members of a targeted community has been well learned by ICE. When Herman Goering established the Third Reich's Gestapo in 1933, their methods were to first target such prominent Jews as rabbis and cantors, congregation and community leaders, elected civic leaders and teachers, thus dispiriting and creating fear within the remaining Jewish families. Those secret state police, taught to sniff out their fears, sent Jews off to the Alligator Alcatraz's of their time. It's an old, old story. It has happened in every civilization in recorded history.
THE RT. REV. JOEL MARCUS JOHNSON
Retired Anglican Bishop of The Chesapeake
Easton

title: ICE arrest of pastor stops church services
author: Lily Tierney
content:
ICE arrest of pastor stops church services

 July 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Local News 
 
 634
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Church services at Iglesia del Nazareno Jesús Te Ama have ceased since the arrest of its pastor, Daniel Fuentes Espinal, on Monday, July 21.Espinal was getting ready to enjoy his McDonalds breakfast when he was pulled over by an unmarked car on state Route 322 near Moton Park around 8 a.m.
Not only has Espinal been taken from his wife and three children, but also his congregation of 80. The parishioners currently aren't meeting out of fear the same will happen to them.
"You know, the members of the congregation believe, and rightfully so, that if this could happen to somebody with Pastor Fuentes Espinal's stature and position within the community, then nobody's safe," said Len Foxwell, a close family friend of Espinal's.
The Rt. Rev. Joel Marcus Johnson, a bishop from Easton, said canceling services now is wise.
"It's wise on their part, I think because we know that ICE would be showing up," Johnson said.
Johnson knows this because he lived it in 1994 when U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Services — the precursor to ICE — showed up to one of his Spanish services at a storefront chapel in Easton.
Johnson, clergy and the congregation came up with a plan where the undocumented immigrants went out the back door and those with green cards or citizenship went out the front.
"It really, really angered INS," Johnson said.
Johnson said arresting high-ranking members of the church is a targeted approach that is not new.
"It's one of the tried and true methods for dispiriting or deflating the hearts of these communities," he said.
Matthew Peters, executive director of the Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center, said he is not aware of any recent ICE arrests in churches on the Mid-Shore, but due to uncertain policy changes, fear is widespread.
COMMUNITY RALLIESEspinal was detained by two U.S. Customs and Immigration Enforcement agents and taken to the Salisbury Field Office. He was quickly transferred to the Baltimore ICE detention center, where he remained for three nights. On Thursday, Espinal was transferred to an ICE detention center in Louisiana, where he will stay until his hearing, which has not been scheduled yet.
Espinal has been in the U.S. since 2001, has no criminal record and has been attempting to secure citizenship legally for years. He has been described as a pillar of the community. A GoFundMe created by Foxwell has raised over $44,000 to cover attorney's fees and other expenses.
ICE said in a statement to the Star Democrat that Espinal was arrested for overstaying his six-month visa.
"Daniel Omar Fuentes Espinal is an illegal alien from Honduras who was arrested by ICE on July 21, in Easton, Maryland," the statement said. "Fuentes entered the United States on a 6-month visa and never left in 24 years. It is a federal crime to overstay the authorized period of time granted under a visitors visa."
Community members, religious leaders and politicians have rallied behind Espinal, holding protests in both Easton and Baltimore since his arrest. On Friday, over 150 people showed up to support Espinal with a rally on U.S. Route 50 in Easton.
According to Foxwell, around 300 people showed up to a rally in Baltimore on Monday. He said he was nervous that people wouldn't turn out because they don't know Espinal, but that was not the case.
"I didn't know if we would be playing to an empty McKeldin Square, but the place was full," Foxwell said.
The rally began with a march from the square to the Fallon Courthouse, the site of the temporary ICE detention center where Espinal was held before being transferred to Louisiana.
Another rally for Pastor Espinal will be held in Easton Friday, Aug. 1, from 5:30 to 6:30 p.m. at the intersection of Dover Street and Route 50. The rally will be hosted by the Talbot County Democratic Forum and the Talbot County Democratic Central Committee.

title: This is not who we are ... a cruel people
author: LARRY PIFER
content:
This is not who we are ... a cruel people

 August 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LARRY PIFER | Section: Columns 
 
 670
 Words 

 Read News Document

 There is an inscription on the Statue of Liberty's base proudly proclaiming:"Give me your tired, your poor, Your huddled masses yearning to breathe free." That is what all of us believe and love about our country. My great-grandparents came from France and Germany, my wife's grandparents came from Ireland. I know when my great-grandmother was given a passport to come to New York and land at Ellis Island passing by the Statue of Liberty.
Unfortunately, that is not who we are today.
Trump has vilified illegal immigrants, and his administration is in such a frenzy to deport a million this year that lawful immigrants are caught up and deported as well. Their only crime is that they are immigrants.
The Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency claims that they are removing only people who have criminal records, "the worst of the worst," Trump claims, but this is clearly untrue. Lawful immigrants and unlawful immigrants with no criminal record have been arrested by ICE in California in the Dodger stadium parking lot, in Home Depot parking lots, while they work in fields gathering crops.
Luis Leon is an 82-year-old grandfather who was arrested by ICE at an immigration office in Pennsylvania at an appointment he had scheduled when he was trying to replace his green card because he lost his wallet. Mr Leon was given political asylum in 1987 after escaping Chile and torture by the Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet.
A green card holder is a lawful permanent resident of the United States. Mr Leon has no criminal record. Mr Leon was deported to Guatemala. with no notification to his family. He has since been found in a hospital in Guatemala.
Mahmoud Kahlil is a graduate student at Columbia University who was arrested in March 2025 and held in a Louisiana detention center until June. There are no criminal charges against him. He is a legal permanent resident. He is still under the threat of deportation.
The Constitution guarantees both citizens and non-citizens certain rights to due process, including challenging the lawfulness of their detention by the government. These are crucial safeguards against arbitrary detention and tyranny. The government cannot hold someone without a legal basis. None of the people described above and many others were afforded these rights.
Is this who we the United States citizens have become? Do we condone the cruelty exhibited by these acts?
There is another way in which we have become something different than who we thought we were. The Gross Domestic Product of the United States is around $28 trillion, about a quarter of all the world's wealth. We used to try to use that wealth to help those who were less fortunate in the world by providing food and aid through the United States Agency for International Development (USAID). Our president has recently defunded USAID, stopping us from using our enormous wealth to help others.
Here is just one example. As reported by CNN on July 17:
"The US plans to destroy nearly 500 metric tons of taxpayer-funded emergency food, the State Department confirmed. The nutrient-dense biscuits, which have been sitting in a Dubai warehouse for months, were supposed to help feed starving people around the world. The destruction of the critically needed food would not have happened prior to the Trump administration's destruction of the US Agency for International Development, a former USAID official said. Two rations of biscuits a day are enough to stop people from dying, they added. Now that the food is about to expire, it must be destroyed; that will cost American taxpayers another $100,000. "This is the definition of waste," the former official said."
This makes no sense and is not who we thought we were. How does it serve the president and the Republicans to withhold the money to feed people?? It is not like we cannot afford it. Again, the cruelty seems to be the reason.
I appeal to my fellow Americans let us try our best to not do these things, let us object strongly to doing these things and hold those who are doing them accountable.

title: Easton Town Council speaks out on increased ICE activity
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Easton Town Council speaks out on increased ICE activity

 August 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Local News 
 
 727
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Councilmember David Montgomery led the prayer at Monday's Easton Town Council Meeting, during which he asked for God to watch over Pastor Daniel Fuentes Espinal.This was the first of many mentions of Espinal, who has been detained by U.S. Customs and Immigration Enforcement since July 21.
"We pray especially for Daniel Fuentes Espinal. Watch over him during his trials, and return him to his family, if that is your will," Montgomery said.
Espinal came to Easton in 2001 on a six-month visa. He has been pastor of Iglesia del Nazareno Jesús Te Ama since 2015.
Espinal was detained by two ICE agents in Easton and taken to ICE's Salisbury Field Office on July 21, according to his daughter.
He was quickly transferred to the Baltimore ICE detention center, where he remained for three nights. That Thursday, Espinal was transferred to an ICE detention center in Louisiana, where he will stay until his hearing, which has not been scheduled yet.
The comments at Monday's meeting came amid increased ICE presence in the town.
"ICE was here today and made some arrests. I mean, it seems like they're here more often than ever," Councilmember the Rev. Elmer Davis said.
Michele Dappert, president of the Talbot County Democratic Forum, said the forum learned of what she believes could be dozens of immigration arrests early this week through both word-of-mouth and corroborating photos and videos. An exact number could not be provided.
The Rev. John Nash from Sts. Peter and Paul said one member of the church's Spanish-speaking congregation was "abducted" Tuesday.
"She was abducted some time this morning, and she's not permitted to call anyone, so nobody knows where she is," Nash said. "They're going after these poor innocent folks who are just trying to make a living."
Easton Police Capt. Greg Wright confirmed that the department was aware of ICE activity in the town on Monday, though the department was not involved in any arrests and could not provide specific details.
Easton resident Emily Stone, who spoke to the council Monday, wanted to know if the police department has a formal agreement with ICE and if the Town Council had taken any actions to get Espinal home.
"I, in particular, want to learn more about how the arrest of Rev. Espinal is being handled by the Town Council and if you have made any requests to our state representative, Andy Harris, to learn more about his well-being or his location," Stone said.
Wright responded, saying the police department has no interaction with ICE nor does it have a formal agreement. They usually are not notified about ICE operations or apprehensions in Easton because ICE is a federal program.
While the town has taken no formal actions on behalf of Espinal, every council member used a portion of their comment period Monday to speak about the effects of the recent ICE arrests on the community.
Councilmember Maureen Curry said she is "distraught" over the detention of Espinal as the daughter of an immigrant herself.
"We are a nation of immigrants, and in my opinion, and it is just my opinion, this administration has turned their backs on the hardworking, honest people like my father that came to this country to make a better life for themselves and their families," Curry said. "Pastor Espinal has been a pillar of our community for nearly 24 years, and his family and his congregation are devastated by his detention."
Council President Don Abbatiello ended the meeting by encouraging concerned residents to reach out to Congressman Andy Harris (R-Md.) and Sens. Angela Alsobrooks (D-Md.) and Chris Van Hollen (D-Md.).
"There is ultimately something wrong with a system where Pastor Espinal and other residents are picked up for what amounts to misdemeanors in civil violations and placed in holding cells far from their loved ones," Abbatiello said. "The way the law is written and enforced right now, this is what happens."
In a statement to The Star Democrat Tuesday evening, Harris said he is "aware of the case and believe(s) it's important to fully understand the details before drawing conclusions."
"We are trying to determine what leeway the Secretary of Homeland Security has in granting exceptions to deportation orders," Harris said. "That said, the Trump administration has been clear: individuals who are in the country illegally should self-deport and follow the proper, legal process to return."
Reporter Konner Mets contributed to this article.
This report has been updated to include comment from Rep. Andy Harris.

title: Small town on Eastern Shore grapples with increasing ICE presence
author: Konner Metz
content:
Small town on Eastern Shore grapples with increasing ICE presence

 August 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 960
 Words 

 Read News Document

 MARYDEL — Positioned directly on the Maryland-Delaware state line, Marydel is a quiet town. But last Wednesday, its sidewalks and businesses were unusually empty."This morning felt like a ghost town," said Karen Bamaca, 18, of Marydel on Aug. 6.
That morning, social media posts containing photos, videos and reports of unconfirmed immigration arrests in the town were widely shared. Many of the town's residents said people didn't feel safe going to work or nearby gas stations, and some resorted to communicating exclusively through Facebook and texting.
Around 50 people, including Bamaca, gathered on the Maryland side of the border that evening as the dust settled to protest against U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement. They marched down Route 311, past local businesses and churches and through a mobile home park, eliciting cheers and claps from the neighborhood largely made up of Hispanic families.
The loud but peaceful display was a stark contrast from that morning's silence.
Protesters, many of whom were young Hispanic residents, said they were motivated to speak out for those they say don't have a voice.
"We're just here for those who can't be," said Ashley Oliver, 24, of Greensboro.
In the days since, the impact of the immigration arrests hasn't evaporated. The town's Hispanic and immigrant communities are afraid, many say, and families and businesses are left to grapple with the effects of the Trump administration's goal to increase ICE arrests.
Nationwide, immigration arrests have surged since President Donald Trump took office in January. Trump campaigned on stepping up immigration enforcement, promising a mass deportation that targeted criminals.
"Across the country, arrests of criminal illegal immigrants have soared as President Donald Trump makes good on his promise to rid our communities of these threats to public safety," the White House said in a press release on July 22.
According to the press release, ICE arrests in Maryland have jumped 290% since Trump took office. U.S. Customs and Immigration data from June 29 shows a recent shift from focusing mainly on those with criminal records to arresting those without a record. Out of 57,861 people detained by ICE, 41,495 had no criminal convictions.
An ICE spokesperson did not respond to questions from The Star Democrat on Tuesday regarding arrest numbers and whether immigration officials have increased enforcement in Caroline County, where Marydel is located.
Marydel, Maryland, operates a small town government. The town is unincorporated on the Delaware side of the border. Census data from 2020 shows Marydel, Maryland's population as 176. Of that mark, 115, or 65%, were Hispanic or Latino.
Many of the town's Hispanic residents or immigrants in the area have been hesitant to work, shop or walk the streets like they're used to doing, business owners and residents say.
"They're scared. They don't know what's gonna happen," said Alfonso Ortiz, owner of a corner store on the Delaware end of town.
VISIBLE IMPACT
A handful of businesses serve as the go-to stops in Marydel. On the Maryland side, there are two gas stations with grocery storefronts, a post office and a popular taco truck. In Delaware, there's a Family Dollar, Marydel Ag Supply and a few restaurants.
In the days after last Wednesday, Ortiz says business at his grocery store, Tienda Frontera Variety, drastically slowed.
"They were scared for a couple days, and they stopped coming," he said on Monday. It's rebounded a bit since, but foot traffic hasn't returned to normal, Ortiz said.
Families are grappling with immigration arrests, too. Adrian, 17, who asked to share only his first name, said four of his family members — his dad, brother, uncle and cousin — were all detained last week.
"I woke up to my mom banging on my door" at 6:30 a.m. on Aug. 6, Adrian said. His family is from Guatemala, and his uncle, dad and cousin had clean criminal records, he said.
Adrian said his dad was on his way to work for a local roofing company before being arrested. Adrian and an uncle retrieved his father's truck, which had been left on the road, as well as several cars for other families.
"To take the dad, to take the mom, what happens to the children?" asked Alex, 35, a neighbor of Adrian's who preferred to only share his first name. Since last week, many in the neighborhood haven't been going to work, he said.
Protesters last Wednesday said they feel immigrants are crucial to Marydel's community and the entire Eastern Shore.
It's "very important, no matter how small their job is," Oliver said.
'SPEAKING FOR THOSE WHO CAN'T'
Many of those protesters aimed to give voice to their family members who were scared to speak out. One sign read, "My parents fought for my future now I will fight for theirs." Another person wrote on a poster, "I'm speaking for those who can't."
Selvin Cordova, 27, of Marydel, helped organize last week's protest. Seeing the fear that developed across the community that day, he was compelled to lead a show of support.
Many who came to protest were young Hispanic residents like Cordova. He said a new wave of immigrant families is driving increased involvement and activism of the local youth.
"Definitely over the last year, our Hispanic community has grown so much more," Cordova said, noting that more Hispanic families are moving to the area.
Last week's protest wasn't just for the families and businesses in Marydel impacted by surging arrests. It was for all of the small towns nestled within Caroline County's rural north corridor, protest leaders said.
Small towns on the north end of Caroline County are home to much of the county's Hispanic population. Per 2020 census data, Templeville and Henderson have Hispanic/Latino population rates at 70% and 65%, respectively.
"Viva la Henderson, viva la Marydel, viva la Templeville, viva la Greensboro," a protester shouted into a megaphone. The crowd cheered and some joined. The chant continued on.
"Viva la Guatemala, viva la Maryland, viva la Delaware."

title: Hiding the past leads to mistakes
author: Staff Writer
content:
Hiding the past leads to mistakes

 August 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 435
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Some time ago I drove down to visit Point Lookout State Park, having previously read about the Union prison camp that confined prisoners of the Confederacy in inhuman circumstances. This, even then, very narrow spit of land was entirely too small for the imprisoned population and must have collided with winter cold and intense summer sun.The recent efforts to alter our country's historical failings is, in my opinion, very dangerous. How many times have you heard parents say to their children, "Remember, we learn from our mistakes."
Should we not teach children about the Trial of Tears, where Native Americans were driven off their land and forced to relocate hundreds of miles from their homes?
Should we not talk about the fear that drove the U.S. government to relocate Japanese men, women and children into interment camps? The officials who made the decision to move this population thought at the time that these individuals posed a real threat to the general population, particularly on the West Coast of the U.S.A.
I grew up in the 1950s and 1960s. During my youth the country was trying to deal with Civil Rights issues. Every night on the news we saw demonstrations regarding this issue and heard Congress debate segregation versus integration. A decade later the Vietnam War was underway, and the country was split in many directions that were reflected in homes and on college campuses.
Like many people my age I had to earn a living, and so I had to focus on the here and now as an employee. The daily tasks did not leave much time for debating politics with friends.
I have seen in my lifetime people try to scapegoat the realities that both harmed and glorified our past.
We are an imperfect nation. Our forefathers created an engaging experiment. They created the greatest democracy ever witnessed on this planet.
We now have the opportunity to learn from our previous mistakes. I despise the fact that the Union Army starved and mistreated Southern soldiers, but that is a fact. I think it was a moral miscalculation to force Japanese families into prison campus, but that is a fact. The American Indian was relocated and forced to walk hundreds of miles from their land, but that's a fact. And old men and women can debate whether we should have ever placed ourselves in Vietnam, but we did, and that's a fact.
The role of the historian is to gather facts and tell us what took place and to provide the various options governments and individuals had when they made those decisions.
Hide the past, and it will only repeat itself.
GILBERT MASTER

title: Israeli Jews safety depends on Palestinians' safety
author: SARENA NEYMAN
content:
Israeli Jews safety depends on Palestinians' safety

 September 27, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SARENA NEYMAN | Section: Columns 
 
 818
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As we enter the 10 days between Rosh Hashanah and Yom Kippur — a time meant for reflecting on where we've strayed from compassion — I keep returning to the dehumanization of Palestinians I've witnessed among the observant Jewish community I grew up in.Over the years, I have spoken out against Israel's assault on Gaza and have been accused of spewing "ignorant, pathetic Al Jazeera-fueled antisemitic rhetoric." "You will not be admired for your performative moral integrity," they admonish. My critics are often otherwise compassionate people, yet their support for the Israeli army remains unwavering.
My devotion to Israel was once as absolute as theirs. My parents — both Holocaust survivors — loved Israel second only to their children. They sent me to Zionist schools and summer camps; I grew up immersed in Hebrew music and literature. To me, Israel was not just a country; it was our shield against another Holocaust.
Only later did I learn about the forced expulsions of Palestinians and how the Israeli army — which I had been taught was the most moral in the world — had armed death squads in Africa and Latin America. My Israeli cousin trained troops for Idi Amin, whose regime slaughtered half a million Ugandans. When I asked my mother how Israel could have done this, she said everyone hated us, so we took our support where we could get it.
Her words rattled me. How could this survivor of five concentration camps, who rebuilt her life as a beloved pediatrician, embrace a moral exceptionalism that excused Israel for abetting genocide?
Over time I came to see her response as born of unspeakable trauma. The Nazis had torn her baby sister from her arms. She had been beaten and starved and witnessed death on a daily basis. Centuries of persecution embeds a fierce tribalism: Protect your own at all costs. But as Rabbi Daniel Bogard points out, "Trauma does not give us moral clarity. It just makes us traumatized." And trauma, left unhealed, breeds more trauma.
Hamas's attack on Oct. 7 reawakened Jews' deepest wound — our ancestral fear of extermination. The Israeli government seized on this to justify a campaign of annihilation: deliberately starving and attacking civilians, restricting humanitarian aid, bombing hospitals and schools.
Even as Israel escalates its Gaza assault, defenders minimize these horrors. Despite Israeli media restrictions and unprecedented journalist deaths, the emerging evidence looks nothing like self-defense. But when dozens of human rights groups call it genocide, the messengers are discredited to deny the message. "How naive you are," comes the refrain. "Don't you understand these groups hates us?"
The ease with which my own people excuse these atrocities is chilling.
"I'm watching something that is so evidently horrific and inhumane," Jon Stewart shared on The Daily Show. Yet when he condemns these actions, he is warned that speaking out threatens Israel's survival, even though it is Israel's actions, not Jewish dissent, that endanger the country most.
And he's right. Studies show Israeli violence fuels antisemitism, which then "justifies" more militarization, creating an endless, deadly spiral that both brutalizes Palestinians and endangers Jews everywhere. Furthermore, adds Jewish Currents publisher Daniel May, the argument that Jews are "at risk no matter where they live and no matter what they do or say," distracts us from addressing the conditions that actually drive anti-Israel violence.
Among my detractors, acknowledging this context is taboo. Mention decades of occupation, and you're accused of excusing the horrific kidnappings and murders of Oct. 7.
I believe Israel has a right to exist, but survival built on another people's suffering isn't survival — it's moral collapse that sows the seeds of our own undoing. I understand that tribalism served an evolutionary purpose, forging loyalty in times of threat. But when it hardens into a moral blind spot, it justifies cruelty and brands truth-telling as betrayal.
As Israel edges toward near-total obliteration of Gaza, we must confront the trauma-fueled myth of victimhood. Backed by billions in U.S. aid, Israel is no longer David. It has become Goliath. But Goliath's strength is also his weakness; brute force creates more enemies than it destroys.
Yet the community in which I grew up still clings to the fantasy that Israel can eradicate Hamas through its military might. In fact, the opposite is true. As journalist Peter Beinart warns, our destinies are intertwined: "If you want Israeli Jews to be safe, Palestinians also have to be safe. And Palestinians cannot be safe unless they are free."
This means abandoning the dehumanizing narrative that Palestinians are terrorist monsters who use children as human shields. Because only by cultivating genuine empathy — by recognizing Palestinians as people just like us, who want safety and dignity for their families — can we break this cycle of trauma. The choice before us is stark: Continue down this path of moral blindness that endangers both peoples, or find the courage to imagine a different story — one where Jewish safety doesn't require Palestinian extinction.

title: 'Critically important': Frederick Douglass Day brings insight
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
'Critically important': Frederick Douglass Day brings insight

 September 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 529
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Cloudy and rainy weather did not stop hundreds of people from attending Frederick Douglass Day at the Talbot County Court House in Easton on Saturday.Douglass has strong roots in Talbot County and throughout the Eastern Shore.
Born in Talbot County in 1818, Frederick Augustus Washington Bailey Douglass was enslaved for 20 years in Baltimore and on Talbot County farms. He fled north in 1838 and changed his name to Frederick Douglass. His brilliance, eloquence and courage, quickly brought him to the forefront of the abolitionist movement.
He was known for his skills as an orator, with many of his speeches remembered to this day.
"I would say critically important," James Young, the event's publicist, said said about Douglass. "He's one of, if not the most respected and important figures in the history of the region. I think it's important for anybody to know more about his life and his work but especially for people who come from where he came from."
Frederick Douglass Day kicked off with a parade led by Grand Marshal Childlene Brooks, former president of the Frederick Douglass Honor Society. The parade featured local groups including Building African American Minds, Easton High School NJROTC Color Guard, Polaris Village Academy, and the Easton and Oxford Fire Departments and many more.
This year, a big focus for the Frederick Douglass Honor Society was getting the younger generation involved in celebrating Douglass.
Gabriella Thompson, the mistress of ceremony, described as a "ambitious 14-year-old entering her freshman year of high school," and Javion Jones, a 15-year-old minister at Union Baptist Church, were some of the youth featured throughout the day.
"I would say there has been some effort to get new people involved. As you know, a lot of people on the committee itself are getting up there," Young said. "So it's a thing that we want to keep going for the foreseeable future, and so at some point you've got to bring in some some fresh blood."
Multiple local leaders attended and participated in Frederick Douglass Day.
Jaelon Moaney, vice chair of the Maryland Commission on African American History and Culture, recited a famous speech by Douglass. The honor society believes having connections like Moaney are important for the success of the society and the annual event.
"Having that connection to African-American history more broadly, as well as current African-American issues, I think is very important," Young said. "That's also something that we try to focus on with the keynote speaker that we bring every year. It's somebody who can bring a perspective of speaking on Douglas but also how he kind of fits into the history of African-American intellectual philosophy."
In an email following the event, Moaney emphasized his own Eastern Shore roots, similar to those of Douglass.
"I, too, am from and decidedly of Talbot," Moaney said. "The Bailey and Moaney families remain connected today. Although two agitators separated by time, my chest began to swell with inexplicable energy while echoing the words delivered on November 25, 1878 from exactly where he stood nearly two centuries prior. As the country commemorates the semiquincentennial and Talbot reaches its 365th anniversary next year, I'm both troubled and moved by the parallels of reality that this experience has revealed."

title: Columbus Day honors Italian American resilience
author: CHRIS CORCHIARINO
content:
Columbus Day honors Italian American resilience

 October 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: CHRIS CORCHIARINO | Section: Columns 
 
 717
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Every October, the debate over Columbus Day versus Indigenous Peoples' Day resurfaces, framed as a choice between two communities. Yet Italian Americans, like Indigenous people, have endured marginalization and discrimination. These are American stories of resilience that deserve recognition. Turning their struggles into a zero-sum culture war dishonors both cultures.As the son of an Italian immigrant, I support a day for recognizing Indigenous People. I wish those pushing this narrative used the other 364 days to address Indigenous poverty, land rights and generational neglect — not just symbolic gestures. Importantly, we don't need to erase the hard-won recognition that Italian Americans fought for through Columbus Day. How it came to exist is important.
On March 14, 1891, New Orleans Police Chief David Hennessy was murdered. As he lay dying, he whispered "Dagoes" — a slur for Italians. Anti-Italian hysteria ignited. The mayor ordered police to "arrest every Italian you come across," and families hid as vigilantes roamed the streets.
When nine Italian immigrants were acquitted and three had mistrials, a mob stormed the jail, dragging 11 out—some shot, some hanged, their bodies mutilated as crowds cheered. It remains one of the largest single mass lynchings in U.S. history.
The press celebrated it as righteous justice. Theodore Roosevelt called it a "rather good thing," reflecting widespread contempt for Italians as racially inferior. To ease diplomatic tensions with Italy, President Benjamin Harrison declared a one-time Columbus Day in 1892 — an acknowledgment born from violence and tragedy.
For Italian Americans Columbus Day isn't primarily about Christopher Columbus. It is about survival, recognition, and pride in the face of discrimination. Italian immigrants had been celebrating it informally since 1866, using the explorer as a symbol of their right to belong in America.
At the turn of the 20th century, Italian immigrants were among America's lowest-paid workers, toiling in coal mines and laying railroad tracks under brutal conditions. Many fell victim to the padrone system, where labor bosses trapped them in debt, locked them in camps and withheld wages.
During World War II, thousands of Italians were designated "enemy aliens," facing curfews, travel restrictions and property seizures. Some were interned.
The Ku Klux Klan actively fought against Columbus Day recognition. They campaigned to strip it as a state holiday in Oregon, burned a cross at a 1924 celebration in Pennsylvania and blocked a Columbus statue installation in Virginia in 1927.
Yet Italian Americans persisted. Through decades of advocacy, Columbus Day became a federal holiday in 1968. Parades celebrated not just an explorer, but Italian Americans who contributed to society — scientists, artists, laborers, soldiers, entrepreneurs. A tradition started by blue-collar immigrants who scraped together money to erect statues and organize celebrations.
Today, the push to replace Columbus Day often overlooks this history. For Italian Americans, it has always been about their own resilience, not defending Columbus's atrocities. Yet those who object to the name never propose renaming the holiday to preserve Italian American recognition. Instead, they seek to eliminate it entirely — erasing the history of how Italian immigrants were treated and why this day mattered.
Even in recent history, when Columbus statues are toppled — statues funded by immigrant communities scraping together pennies — crowds cheer, but those cheers are celebrating the erasure of working-class immigrant history.
This erasure is troubling because bigotry toward Italian Americans hasn't disappeared. Mafia stereotypes remain acceptable punchlines. Mocking Italian accents is still considered harmless comedy. I grew up seeing this bigotry visited upon my father — but like other Italians, he persevered.
We shouldn't force a choice between honoring Italian American struggles and recognizing Indigenous peoples. Both histories deserve celebration.
If "Columbus" is the obstacle, the productive conversation would be about renaming the October holiday while still honoring Italian American heritage. However, when that is not the topic and the discussion ignores this history, it's difficult to pass it as anything more than anti-Italian bigotry. We shouldn't dismiss the struggles of Italian immigrants who, like my father, built lives in America fueled by the promise of the American Dream. It's a uniquely American story that should be told. Their story — the persecution, resilience and contribution to the American fabric — deserves to be remembered. Pitting groups against each other in an annual culture war is wrong and not in keeping with the promise of America.
Chris Corchiarino is a Maryland attorney and Queen Anne's County resident.
